("GCI"), received through its initial capitalization all ownership interests in subsidiaries previously held by GCI, GCI was incorporated in 1979 under the laws of the State of Alaska and has its principal executive offices at 2550 Denali Street, Suite 1000, Anchorage, AK 99503-2781 (telephone number 907-868-5600).
75679_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	GCI, Inc. is primarily a holding company and together with its direct and indirect subsidiaries, is a diversified communications provider in the State of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	Internet users can access information about the Company and its services at http://www.gci.com/, http://www.gci-industrialtelecom.com, http://www.unicom-alaska.com/, http://www.alaska-wireless.com/ and http://www.alaskaunited.com/. The Company hosts Internet services at http://www.gci.net/, broadband delivery of health services at http://www.connectmd.com, and SchoolAccess services at http://www.schoolaccess.net/. The Company hosts information about our TERRA-Southwest ( TERRA-SW ) project at http://terra.gci.com/.
75679_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	In addition, the SEC s website is http://www.sec.gov/.
75679_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	The SEC makes available on this website, free of charge, reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers, such as us, that file electronically with the SEC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P5_S2	Information on our websites or the SEC s website is not part of this document.
75679_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our five reportable segments are Consumer, Network Access, Commercial, Managed Broadband, and Regulated Operations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	For financial information about our reportable segments, see Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	Also refer to note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
75679_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	We are the largest communications provider in Alaska as measured by revenues.
75679_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	We offer facilities-based local and long-distance voice services, cable television, data and Internet access to residential and business customers across the state under our GCI brand.
75679_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	In addition, we provide wireless telephone services over our own facilities under the GCI and Alaska Wireless brand names.
75679_11_ITEM1_P8_S3	Due to the unique nature of the markets we serve, including harsh winter weather and remote geographies, our customers rely extensively on our systems to meet their communication and entertainment needs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P8_S4	We benefit from the attractive demographic and economic characteristics of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Since GCI s founding in 1979 as a competitive long distance provider, we have consistently expanded our product portfolio and facilities to become the leading integrated communication services provider in our markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our facilities include redundant and geographically diverse digital undersea fiber optic cable systems linking our Alaska terrestrial networks to the networks of other carriers in the lower 48 contiguous states.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	As of December 31, 2010, our cable systems passed 84% of Alaska s households, and we have achieved 55% basic cable penetration of the homes we reach.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S3	We believe we offer superior video services relative to digital broadcast satellite ( DBS ), which is limited by Alaska s geographic location, challenging climate and terrain features.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S4	We have continued our statewide deployment of digital local phone service ( DLPS ) utilizing our own coaxial cable facilities enabling us to move off of facilities that we previously leased from incumbent local exchange carriers ( ILEC ).
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S5	At December 31, 2010, 76% of the local access lines we served were carried on our own last mile facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P9_S6	In recent years, we expanded our efforts in wireless and presently operate the only statewide wireless network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our Consumer segment serves residential customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our Network Access segment serves other common carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P10_S2	Our Commercial segment serves small businesses, local, national and global businesses, governmental entities, and public and private educational institutions.
75679_11_ITEM1_P10_S3	Our Managed Broadband segment serves rural school districts, hospitals and health clinics.
75679_11_ITEM1_P10_S4	The financial results of the long-distance, local access and Internet services sold to consumer and commercial customers that we serve in the Bethel, Alaska area are reported in the Regulated Operations segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, we generated consolidated revenues of $651.3 million.
75679_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	We ended the period with approximately 97,500 long-distance customers, 144,800 local access lines in service, 147,100 basic cable subscribers, 138,700 wireless subscribers and 116,900 cable modem subscribers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	In January 2010 the U.S. Department of Agriculture s Rural Utilities Service ( RUS ) approved our wholly-owned subsidiary, United Utilities, Inc. s ( UUI ) application for an $88.2 million loan/grant combination to extend terrestrial broadband service for the first time to Bristol Bay and the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta, an area in Alaska roughly the size of the state of North Dakota.
75679_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	Upon completion TERRA-SW will be able to serve over 9,000 households and over 700 businesses in the 65 covered communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	institutions and entities, such as regional health care providers, school districts, and other regional and Alaska Native organizations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	The RUS award, consisting of a $44.2 million loan and a $44.0 million grant, will be made under the RUS Broadband Initiatives Program established pursuant to the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.
75679_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	The grant portion of the award will fund backbone network facilities that we would not otherwise be able to construct within our return-on-investment requirements.
75679_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	UUI began construction on TERRA-SW in 2010 and expects to complete the project in 2012 or earlier if possible.
75679_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	You should see Part I Item 1.
75679_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	We intend to continue to increase revenues using the following strategies:
75679_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	We offer innovative service bundles to meet the needs of our consumer and commercial customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	We believe that bundling our services significantly improves customer retention, increases revenue per customer and reduces customer acquisition expenses.
75679_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	Our experience indicates that our bundled customers are significantly less likely to churn, and we experience less price erosion when we effectively combine our offerings.
75679_11_ITEM1_P17_S3	Bundling improves our top line revenue growth, provides operating cost efficiencies that expand our margins and drives our overall business performance.
75679_11_ITEM1_P17_S4	As a measure of success to date, over 62,600 of our residential customers subscribe to one of our service bundles that include two or more services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	We successfully sell new and enhanced services and products between and within our business segments to our existing customer base to achieve increased revenues and penetration of our services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Through close coordination of our customer service and sales and marketing efforts, our customer service representatives suggest to our customers other services they can purchase or enhanced versions of services they already purchase.
75679_11_ITEM1_P18_S2	Many calls into our customer service centers or visits into one of our 32 retail stores result in sales of additional services and products.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	We have positioned ourselves as a customer service leader in the Alaska communications market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	We have organized our operations to effectively focus on our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	We operate our own customer service department and maintain and staff our own call centers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S3	We have empowered our customer service representatives to handle most service issues and questions on a single call.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S4	We prioritize our customer services to expedite handling of our most valuable customers issues, particularly for our largest commercial customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P19_S5	We believe our integrated approach to customer service, including service set-up, programming various network databases with the customer s information, installation, and ongoing service, allows us to provide a customer experience that fosters customer loyalty.
75679_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	We continue to expand and evolve our integrated network for the delivery of our services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Our bundled strategy and integrated approach to serving our customers creates efficiencies of scale and maximizes network utilization.
75679_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	By offering multiple services, we are better able to leverage our network assets and increase returns on our invested capital.
75679_11_ITEM1_P20_S3	We periodically evaluate our network assets and continually monitor technological developments that we can potentially deploy to increase network efficiency and performance.
75679_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	Expand Our Product Portfolio and Footprint in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	Throughout our history, we have successfully added and expect to continue to add new products to our product portfolio.
75679_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	We have a demonstrated history of new product evaluation, development and deployment for our customers, and we continue to assess revenue-enhancing opportunities that create value for our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P21_S3	In addition to new services such as additional high definition television ("HDTV") channels, video-on-demand, on-line advertising placement, on-line content delivery such as streaming music, and mobile high speed data, we are also expanding the reach of our core products to new markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P21_S4	Where feasible and where economic analysis supports geographic expansion of our network coverage, we are currently pursuing or expect to pursue opportunities to increase the scale of our facilities, enhance our ability to serve our existing customers needs and attract new customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	We have a history of making and integrating acquisitions of in-state telecommunications providers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	In 2008, we completed three acquisitions of telecommunications providers in various Alaska communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	Our management team is adept at sourcing, acquiring and integrating these acquired companies, and we will continue to actively pursue and buy companies that we believe fit with our strategy and networks and that enhance earnings.
75679_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our five reportable segments are Consumer, Network Access, Commercial, Managed Broadband, and Regulated Operations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Our reportable segments are business units that offer different products, are each managed separately, and serve distinct types of customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	Following are our segments and the services and products each offers to its customers:
75679_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Many of our networks and facilities are utilized by more than one segment to provide services and products to our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	The following description of our business by reportable segment includes a comprehensive discussion within the Consumer segment section with references to that section if such common network and facility use exists in another segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	Similarly, many of the same services and products are sold to our customers in different segments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	The following discussion includes information about significant services and products, sales and marketing, facilities, competition and seasonality for each of our five reportable segments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	For a discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations please see Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Consumer segment revenues for 2010, 2009 and 2008 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands):
75679_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Consumer segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our Consumer segment offers a full range of voice, video, data and wireless services and products to residential customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Revenues derived from Consumer segment voice services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $57.3 million, $52.7 million, and $47.0 million, respectively, or 9%, 9%, and 8% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	We are a full-service long-distance provider including intrastate, interstate and international calling.
75679_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	The value of our long-distance services is generally designed to be equal to or greater than that for comparable services provided by our competitors.
75679_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	We offer local access services in many communities and areas in Alaska, including the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau.
75679_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	Our own DLPS facilities and collocated remote facilities that access the ILEC unbundled network element ("UNE") loops allow us to offer full featured local service products to customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P32_S2	In areas where we do not have our own DLPS facilities or access to ILEC UNE loop facilities, we offer service using total service resale of the ILEC s local service or UNE platform.
75679_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Revenues derived from Consumer segment video services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $118.5 million, $111.0 million, and $105.2 million, respectively, or 18%, 19%, and 18% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our cable television systems serve 41 communities and areas in Alaska, including the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau.
75679_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	We offer a full range of video services over our broadband cable systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	Our video service offerings include the following:
75679_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our basic cable service consists of digital basic service with access to between 13 and 21 channels of programming and an expanded digital basic service with access to between 40 and 102 additional channels of programming.
75679_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	These services generally consist of programming provided by national and local broadcast networks, national and regional cable networks, and governmental and public access programming.
75679_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	We transmit an entirely digital signal for all cable television channels in all markets we serve.
75679_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Our high definition television ("HDTV") service provides our subscribers with improved, high-resolution picture quality, improved audio quality and a wide-screen, theater-like display.
75679_11_ITEM1_P38_S1	Our HDTV service offers a broad selection of high-definition programming with access of up to 82 high-definition channels including most major broadcast networks, leading national cable networks, premium channels and national sports networks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our advanced digital video recorder ("DVR") service lets digital cable subscribers select, record and store programs and play them at whatever time is convenient.
75679_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	DVR service also provides the ability to pause and rewind live television.
75679_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	Our premium channel programming service, which includes cable networks such as Home Box Office, Showtime, Starz and Cinemax, generally offers, without commercial interruption, feature motion pictures, live and taped sporting events, concerts and other special features.
75679_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our video on demand service permits our cable subscribers to order at their convenience and for a separate fee, individual feature motion pictures and special event programs, on an unedited, commercial-free basis.
75679_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Our pay-per-view service permits our cable subscribers to order, for a separate fee, scheduled individual feature motion pictures and special event programs, such as professional boxing, professional wrestling and concerts, on an unedited, commercial-free basis.
75679_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Revenues derived from Consumer segment data services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $61.4 million, $50.3 million, and $42.7 million, respectively, or 9%, 8%, and 7% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	We primarily offer four types of Internet access for consumer use: high-speed cable modem, dial-up, mobile wireless and fixed wireless.
75679_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Value-added Internet features, such as e-mail virus prevention, personal web site and domain hosting, and additional e-mail accounts, are available for additional charges.
75679_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	Our consumer high-speed cable modem Internet service offers up to 22 Mbps download and 2 Mbps upload speeds.
75679_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	Revenues derived from Consumer segment wireless services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $105.7 million, $81.0 million, and $60.7 million, respectively, or 16%, 14%, and 11% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	We offer mobile wireless voice and data services by selling services over our own facilities under the GCI and Alaska Wireless brand names.
75679_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	We offer fixed wireless local access services over our own facilities, have purchased personal communication services ("PCS") and local multipoint distribution system ("LMDS") wireless broadband licenses in Federal Communications Commission ("FCC") auctions covering markets in Alaska, and secured cellular licenses utilizing the FCC s established process.
75679_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	We offer mobile wireless service to our customers in the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau and many other small Alaska communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	We offer our customers a variety of post-paid and prepaid wireless rate plans so they can choose the plan that best fits their expected calling needs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	Consumer voice service is generally offered on a contract basis for one or two year periods.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	Under the terms of these contracts, service is billed and provided on a monthly basis according to the applicable rate plan chosen.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S2	Our offerings include regional and national rate plans at a variety of pricing tiers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S3	Our wireless voice plans generally combine a fixed monthly access charge, a designated number of minutes-of-use, per minute usage charges for minutes in excess of the included amount and additional charges for certain custom-calling features.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S4	Most of our plans include basic features such as voice messaging, caller ID, call forwarding and call waiting, and two-way text messaging.
75679_11_ITEM1_P49_S5	Wireless data service is included in certain plans or can be purchased as a feature to a plan.
75679_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	We sell a variety of handsets and personal computer wireless data cards manufactured by various suppliers for use with our wireless services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	We also sell accessories, such as carrying cases, hands-free devices, batteries, battery chargers and other items.
75679_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	We provide contract subscribers substantial equipment subsidies to initiate, continue or upgrade service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	We combine one or more of our individual service and product offerings into bundles that we sell to our Consumer segment customers at attractive prices.
75679_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	Our most popular bundled offering includes long-distance, cable television, cable modem Internet access and local access services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	In addition to several other bundled offerings, we also offer a bundle of wireless services, cable television and cable modem Internet access.
75679_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Our Consumer segment sales efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	We operate a modern, competitive communications network employing digital transmission technology over our fiber optic facilities within Alaska and between Alaska and the lower 48 states.
75679_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	Our facilities include three self-constructed digital undersea fiber optic cable systems linking our Alaska terrestrial networks to the networks of other carriers in the lower 48 states:
75679_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Alaska United Southeast was placed into service in 2008 and connects Ketchikan, Wrangell, Petersburg, Angoon and Sitka, Alaska to Alaska United West and Alaska United East.
75679_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	The combination of our Alaska United East, Alaska United West and Alaska United Southeast systems provides us with the ability to provide fully protected geographically diverse routing of service between Alaska and the lower 48 states.
75679_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	Our Alaska United Northwest self-constructed terrestrial fiber optic cable system connects Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska along the Parks Highway corridor and we own a terrestrial fiber optic cable system that extends from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska to Valdez, Alaska via Fairbanks, Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	We have indefeasible rights to use ("IRU") capacity in the Kodiak-Kenai Cable Company, LLC s undersea fiber optic cable system linking Anchorage to Kenai, Homer, Kodiak, Narrow Cape on Kodiak Island, and Seward, Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	Another carrier operates a pair of fiber optic cable facilities connecting points in Alaska to the lower 48 states.
75679_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	This additional fiber system provides direct competition to services we provide on our owned fiber optic cable facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	We serve many rural and remote Alaska locations solely via satellite communications.
75679_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	Each of our C-band and Ku-band satellite transponders is backed up on the same spacecraft with multiple backup transponders.
75679_11_ITEM1_P59_S2	The primary spacecrafts we use to provide voice, data and Internet services to our rural Alaska customers are Intelsat s Galaxy 18 for C-band and Intelsat's Horizons 1 for Ku-band, but we also lease capacity on two other spacecraft, SES Americom s AMC-7 and AMC-8.
75679_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	We also lease one 36 MHz transponder on SES Americom's AMC-7 spacecraft.
75679_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	We use this transponder to distribute multi-channel, digitally encoded video programming and services to remote locations within Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P60_S2	We may use this transponder along with two others that we reserve on AMC-7 to restore service during any fiber outage that may occur in our network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	We operate digital microwave systems to link Anchorage with the Kenai Peninsula, our Prudhoe Bay Earth Station with Deadhorse, Alaska, and to link Bethel, Alaska with 40 rural communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Virtually all switched services are computer controlled, digitally switched, and interconnected by a packet switched SS7 signaling network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	Other facilities include major earth stations at Adak, Barrow, Bethel, Cordova, Dillingham, Dutch Harbor, Eagle River, Galena, Juneau, Ketchikan, King Salmon, Kodiak, Kotzebue, McGrath, Nome, Prudhoe Bay, Sitka, Unalakleet, and Yakutat, all in Alaska, serving the communities in their vicinity, and at Issaquah, Washington, which provides interconnection to Seattle and the lower 48 states for traffic to and from major Alaska earth stations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	The Eagle River earth station is linked to the Anchorage distribution center by fiber optic facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	We use a synchronous optical network ("SONET") as a service delivery method for our terrestrial metropolitan area networks and long-haul terrestrial and undersea fiber optic cable systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	A fiber optic cable system from our Anchorage distribution center connects to the Matanuska Telephone Association ( MTA ), Eagle River central office and to our major hub earth station in Eagle River.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	The Issaquah earth station is connected with the Seattle distribution center by means of diversely-routed leased fiber optic cable transmission systems, each having the capability to restore the other in the event of failure.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S2	The Juneau earth station and distribution centers are collocated.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S3	We have digital microwave facilities serving the Kenai Peninsula communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S4	We maintain earth stations in Fairbanks (linked by digital microwave to the Fairbanks distribution center), Juneau (collocated with the Juneau distribution center), Anchorage (Benson earth station), and in Prudhoe Bay as fiber network restoration earth stations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P65_S5	Our Benson earth station also uplinks our statewide video service; such service may be pre-empted if earth station capacity is needed to restore our fiber network between Anchorage and Prudhoe Bay.
75679_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	We use our demand assigned multiple access ("DAMA") facilities to serve 69 additional locations throughout Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	villages using only one satellite hop, thereby reducing satellite delay and capacity requirements while improving quality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P67_S1	In addition, 54 (for a total of 123) C-band facilities provide dedicated Internet access and private network services to rural public schools, hospitals, health clinics, and natural resource development industries throughout Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	Our network of 83 Ku-band facilities provides dedicated Internet access and private network services to rural public schools, hospitals, health clinics, and natural resource development industries throughout Alaska, and in ten locations in the lower 48 states.
75679_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	Our Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau distribution centers contain electronic switches to route calls to and from local exchange companies and, in Seattle, to obtain access to other carriers to distribute our southbound traffic to the remaining 49 states and international destinations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P69_S1	Our extensive metropolitan area fiber network in Anchorage supports cable television, Internet and telephony services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P69_S2	The Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau facilities also include digital access cross-connect systems, frame relay data switches, Internet platforms, and in Anchorage and Fairbanks, collocation facilities for interconnecting and hosting equipment for other carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P69_S3	We also maintain an operator and customer service center in Wasilla, Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P69_S4	Our operator services traffic is processed by an integrated services platform that also hosts answering services, directory assistance, and internal conferencing services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	We utilize our coaxial cable facilities for DLPS.
75679_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	This delivery method allows us to utilize our own cable facilities to provide local access service to our customers and avoid paying local loop charges to the ILEC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	Our statewide cable systems consist of 3,057 miles of installed cable plant having 450 to 625 MHz of channel capacity.
75679_11_ITEM1_P71_S1	Our cable television businesses are located throughout Alaska and serve 41 communities and areas in Alaska, including the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau.
75679_11_ITEM1_P71_S2	Our facilities include cable plant and head-end distribution equipment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P71_S3	Some of our locations on the fiber routes are served from the head-end distribution equipment in Anchorage.
75679_11_ITEM1_P71_S4	All of our cable systems are completely digital.
75679_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	We provide access to the Internet using a platform that includes many of the latest advancements in technology.
75679_11_ITEM1_P72_S1	The physical platform is concentrated in Anchorage and is extended into many remote areas of the state.
75679_11_ITEM1_P72_S2	Our Internet platform includes the following:
75679_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	Our Anchorage facility consists of routers, a bank of servers that perform support and application functions, database servers providing authentication and user demographic data, layer 2 gigabit switch networks for intercommunications and broadband services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	Our dedicated Internet access and Internet protocol ("IP") data services are delivered to a router located at the service point.
75679_11_ITEM1_P74_S1	Our Internet management platform constantly monitors this router and continual communications are maintained with all of the core and distribution routers in the network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P74_S2	The availability and quality of service, as well as statistical information on traffic loading, are continuously monitored for quality assurance.
75679_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	The manage ment platform has the capability to remotely access routers, servers and layer two switches, permitting changes in configuration without the need to be physically located at the service point.
75679_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	We own state-wide wireless facilities that cover 98% of the population providing service to urban and rural Alaska communities and we will continue to expand these networks throughout the terrestrially and satellite served portions of Alaska in 2011.
75679_11_ITEM1_P76_S1	We own GSM and CDMA wireless facilities serving urban Alaska locations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P76_S2	Our urban network includes Ericsson and Nortel wireless switches located in Anchorage and 183 cell sites that serve the following areas of Alaska: Anchorage and Eagle River, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, Kenai Peninsula, Southeast, Kodiak and Fairbanks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	Our rural network consists of GSM facilities that are located throughout Alaska s rural villages and communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P77_S1	We extend our network coverage through roaming arrangements with other GSM and CDMA carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	A discussion of competition by product and service in our Consumer segment follows.
75679_11_ITEM1_P79_S0	The long-distance industry is intensely competitive and based upon price and bundling.
75679_11_ITEM1_P80_S0	In the intrastate, interstate and international long-distance market, we compete against AT T Alascom, Inc. ( AT T Alascom ), Alaska Communications Systems Group, Inc. ( ACS ), MTA, long-distance resellers, and certain smaller rural local telephone companies.
75679_11_ITEM1_P80_S1	AT T Alascom, as a subsidiary of AT T, Inc., has access to greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we have.
75679_11_ITEM1_P80_S2	There is also the possibility that new competitors will enter the Alaska market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P81_S0	In addition, wireless and voice over Internet protocol ("VoIP") services continue to grow as an alternative to wireline services as a means of reaching customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P81_S1	Wireless local number portability allows consumers to retain the same phone number as they change service providers allowing for interchangeable and portable fixed-line and wireless numbers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P81_S2	Some consumers now use wireless service as their primary voice phone service for local and long-distance calling.
75679_11_ITEM1_P82_S0	We have competed in the long-distance market by offering discounts from rates charged by our competitors and by providing desirable bundles of services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P83_S0	Our ability to compete successfully will depend on our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry, including new services that may be introduced, changes in consumer preferences, demographic trends, economic conditions and pricing strategies.
75679_11_ITEM1_P84_S0	We compete against ACS, the ILEC, in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks and the Kenai Peninsula area; MTA, the ILEC, in the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, and other smaller ILECs in other communities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P85_S0	In the local telephone services market, the 1996 Telecom Act, judicial decisions, state and federal legislative and regulatory developments, and new technologies have increased the overall likelihood that barriers to local telephone competition will be substantially reduced or removed.
75679_11_ITEM1_P85_S1	These initiatives include requirements that ILECs negotiate with entities, including us, to provide interconnection to the existing local telephone network, to allow the purchase, at cost-based rates, of access to UNEs, to establish dialing parity, to obtain access to rights-of-way and to resell services offered by the ILEC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P86_S0	We have been able to obtain interconnection, access and related services from the ILECs, at rates that allow us to offer competitive services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P86_S1	However, if we are unable to continue to obtain these services and access at acceptable rates, our ability to offer local access services, and our revenues and net income, could be materially adversely affected.
75679_11_ITEM1_P86_S2	To date, we have been successful in capturing a significant portion of the local telephone market in the locations where we are offering these services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P86_S3	However, there can be no assurance that we will continue to be successful in attracting or retaining these customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P87_S0	We believe that we have certain advantages over ILECs in providing communications services, including awareness by Alaskan customers of the GCI brand name, our facilities-based communications network, and our prior experience in, and knowledge of, the Alaskan market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P88_S0	See Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products below for more information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P89_S0	Our cable television systems face competition from alternative methods of receiving and distributing television signals, including direct broadcast satellite ("DBS"), digital video over telephone lines, broadband IP-based services, wireless and satellite master antenna television ("SMATV") systems, and from other sources of news, information and entertainment such as Internet services, off-air television broadcast programming, newspapers, movie theaters, live sporting events, interactive computer services, and home video products, including video disks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P89_S1	Our cable television systems also face competition from potential overbuilds of our existing cable systems by other cable television operators and municipally-owned cable systems, and alternative methods of receiving and distributing television signals.
75679_11_ITEM1_P89_S2	The extent to which our cable television systems are competitive depends, in part, upon our ability to provide quality programming and other services at competitive prices.
75679_11_ITEM1_P90_S0	We believe that the greatest source of potential competition for video services comes from the DBS industry.
75679_11_ITEM1_P90_S1	Two major companies, The DirecTV Group, Inc. and DISH DBS Corporation, are currently offering nationwide high-power DBS services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P90_S2	The ILECs in the Matanuska-Susitna Valley and Ketchikan offer digital video service over telephone lines in limited areas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P91_S0	With the addition of Anchorage local broadcast stations, increased marketing, ILEC and DBS alliances, and emerging technologies creating new opportunities, competition from these sources has increased and will likely continue to increase.
75679_11_ITEM1_P92_S0	Competitive forces will be counteracted by offering expanded programming through digital services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P93_S0	Digital delivery technology is being utilized in all of our systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P93_S1	We have retransmission agreements with Anchorage broadcasters and provide for the uplink/downlink of their signals into all our systems, and local programming for our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P94_S0	Other new technologies may become competitive with non-entertainment services that cable television systems can offer.
75679_11_ITEM1_P95_S0	The FCC has authorized television broadcast stations to transmit textual and graphic information useful to both consumers and businesses.
75679_11_ITEM1_P95_S1	The FCC also permits commercial and non-commercial FM stations to use their subcarrier frequencies to provide non-broadcast services including data transmissions.
75679_11_ITEM1_P96_S0	The FCC established an over-the-air interactive video and data service that will permit two-way interaction with commercial and educational programming along with informational and data services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P96_S1	ILECs and other common carriers also provide facilities for the transmission and distribution to homes and businesses of interactive computer-based services, including the Internet, as well as data and other non-video services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P97_S0	The FCC has conducted spectrum auctions for licenses to provide PCS, as well as other services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P97_S1	PCS and other services will enable license holders, including cable operators, to provide voice and data services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P97_S2	We own a statewide PCS license in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P98_S0	Cable television systems generally operate pursuant to franchises granted on a non-exclusive basis.
75679_11_ITEM1_P98_S1	The 1992 Cable Act gives local franchising authorities jurisdiction over basic cable service rates and equipment in the absence of effective competition.
75679_11_ITEM1_P98_S2	The 1992 Cable Act also prohibits franchising authorities from unreasonably denying requests for additional franchises and permits franchising authorities to operate cable systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P99_S0	Well-financed businesses from outside the cable industry (such as the public utilities that own certain of the poles on which cable is attached) may become competitors for franchises or providers of competing services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P100_S0	We expect to continue to provide, at reasonable prices and in competitive bundles, a greater variety of communication services than are available off-air or through other alternative delivery sources.
75679_11_ITEM1_P100_S1	Additionally, we believe we offer superior technical performance and responsive community-based customer service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P100_S2	Increased competition, however, may adversely affect our market share and results of operations from our cable services product offerings.
75679_11_ITEM1_P101_S0	The Internet industry is highly competitive, rapidly evolving and subject to constant technological change.
75679_11_ITEM1_P101_S1	Competition is based upon price and pricing plans, service bundles, the types of services offered, the technologies used, customer service, billing services, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_11_ITEM1_P101_S2	We compete with other Alaska based Internet providers and domestic, non-Alaska based providers that provide national service coverage.
75679_11_ITEM1_P101_S3	Several of the providers headquartered outside of Alaska have substantially greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
75679_11_ITEM1_P102_S0	With respect to our high-speed cable modem service, ACS and other Alaska telephone service providers are providing competitive high-speed data subscriber line services over their telephone lines in direct competition with our high-speed cable modem service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P102_S1	Competitive local fixed wireless providers are providing service in certain of our markets as is a national WiMax-based provider in Anchorage with plans for Juneau and Fairbanks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P102_S2	WiMax is a standards-based wireless technology that provides high-throughput broadband connections over long distances.
75679_11_ITEM1_P102_S3	WiMax can be used for a number of applications, including last mile broadband connections, hotspots and cellular backhaul, and high-speed enterprise connectivity for business.
75679_11_ITEM1_P102_S4	DBS providers and others provide wireless high speed Internet service in competition with our high-speed cable modem services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P103_S0	Niche providers in the industry, both local and national, compete with certain of our Internet service products, such as web hosting, list services and e-mail.
75679_11_ITEM1_P104_S0	We compete against AT T Mobility, LLC ( AT T Mobility ), ACS, MTA, and resellers of those services in Anchorage and other markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P105_S0	Regulatory policies favor robust competition in wireless markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P105_S1	Wireless local number portability, which was implemented by the FCC late in 2003, has also increased the level of competition in the industry.
75679_11_ITEM1_P105_S2	Number portability allows subscribers to switch carriers without having to change their telephone numbers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P106_S0	The communications industry continues to experience significant technological changes, as evidenced by the increasing pace of improvements in the capacity and quality of digital technology, shorter cycles for new products and enhancements and changes in consumer preferences and expectations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P106_S1	Accordingly, we expect competition in the wireless communications industry to continue to be dynamic and intense as a result of the development of new technologies, services and products.
75679_11_ITEM1_P107_S0	We compete for customers based principally upon price, bundled services, the services and enhancements offered, network quality, customer service, network coverage and capacity, the type of wireless handsets offered, and the availability of differentiated features and services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P107_S1	Our ability to compete successfully will depend, in part, on our marketing efforts and our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry.
75679_11_ITEM1_P108_S0	Our Consumer segment services and products do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P108_S1	Our ability to implement construction projects is hampered during the winter months because of cold temperatures, snow and short daylight hours.
75679_11_ITEM1_P109_S0	Network Access segment revenues for 2010, 2009 and 2008 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands ):
75679_11_ITEM1_P110_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Network Access segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P111_S0	Our Network Access segment offers wholesale voice, data, and wireless services and products to other common carrier customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P111_S1	We provide network transport, billing services and access to our network to other common carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P111_S2	These services allow other common carriers to provide services to their customers that originate or terminate on our network, or on the networks of other communication companies to which we connect.
75679_11_ITEM1_P112_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment voice services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $29.0 million, $49.8 million, and $79.7 million, respectively, or 4%, 8%, and 14% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P113_S0	We are engaged in the transmission of interstate and intrastate-switched message telephone service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P113_S1	We terminate northbound message telephone service traffic for several large resellers who do not have facilities of their own in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P113_S2	We also provide origination of southbound calling card, toll-free services, and toll services for interexchange carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P113_S3	Services are generally provided pursuant to contracts.
75679_11_ITEM1_P114_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment data services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $61.5 million, $63.9 million, and $71.4 million, respectively, or 9%, 11%, and 12% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P115_S0	Data network services include multi-protocol label switching, frame relay, private line and dedicated Internet service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P116_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment wireless services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $16.7 million, $8.4 million, and $2.7 million, respectively, or 3%, 1%, and 0% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P117_S0	We provide roaming services on our wireless network within Alaska to other GSM and CDMA wireless carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P118_S0	Our Network Access segment sales and marketing efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of other common carriers we serve, the number of billable minutes of long-distance and wireless traffic we carry over our network and the number of voice and data transmission circuits leased.
75679_11_ITEM1_P118_S1	We sell our voice, data and wireless services primarily through direct contact marketing.
75679_11_ITEM1_P119_S0	Our Network Access segment shares common facilities used for voice, data and wireless services by other segments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P119_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P120_S0	We had no major customer in 2010.
75679_11_ITEM1_P120_S1	During the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, Verizon was a major customer.
75679_11_ITEM1_P120_S2	Revenues attributed to our major customer during the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, totaled $64.5 million and $65.0 million, respectively, or 11% of total revenues for each year.
75679_11_ITEM1_P121_S0	Our Network Access segment competes against AT T Alascom, ACS, and certain smaller rural local telephone carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P121_S1	There is also the possibility that new competitors will enter the Alaska market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P122_S0	Other common carrier traffic routed to us for termination in Alaska is largely dependent on traffic routed to our carrier customers by their customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P122_S1	Pricing pressures, new program offerings, revised business plans, and market consolidation continue to evolve in the markets served by our carrier customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P122_S2	If, as a result, their traffic is reduced, or if their competitors costs to terminate or originate traffic in Alaska are reduced, our traffic will also likely be reduced, and we may have to respond to competitive pressures.
75679_11_ITEM1_P122_S3	We are unable to predict the effect of such changes on our business.
75679_11_ITEM1_P123_S0	Historically, we have competed in the Network Access segment market by offering rates comparable to or less than our competitors, by providing a comprehensive service model to meet the complete needs of our carrier customers, and by providing responsive customer service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P124_S0	Network Access segment long-distance and wireless services revenues derived from our other common carrier customers have historically been highest in the summer months because of temporary population increases attributable to tourism and increased seasonal economic activity such as construction, commercial fishing, and oil and gas activities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P124_S1	Our Network Access segment data services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P125_S0	We offer a full range of communications services and products to commercial and governmental customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P125_S1	Commercial segment revenues for 2010, 2009 and 2008 are summarized as follows :
75679_11_ITEM1_P126_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Commercial segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P127_S0	Our Commercial segment offers a full range of voice, video, data, wireless and managed services and products to small businesses, local, national and global businesses, governmental entities, and public and private educational institutions.
75679_11_ITEM1_P128_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment voice services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $31.7 million, $30.8 million, and $29.4 million, respectively, or 5% of our total revenues for each year.
75679_11_ITEM1_P129_S0	We are engaged in the transmission of interstate and intrastate-switched message telephone service between the major communities in Alaska, the remaining 49 states, and foreign countries.
75679_11_ITEM1_P129_S1	Our message toll services include intrastate, interstate and international direct dial, toll-free services, calling card, operator and enhanced conference calling services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P129_S2	Small business subscribers generally may cancel long-distance service at any time.
75679_11_ITEM1_P129_S3	Certain small business and most large business, governmental and educational institution customers generally contract with us for service over one to five year periods.
75679_11_ITEM1_P130_S0	We offer full featured local access service to our Commercial segment customers using our own fiber and coax facilities and collocated remote facilities that access the ILEC s UNE loops and wholesale facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P130_S1	In areas where we do not have our own facilities or access to ILEC loop facilities, we offer service using total service resale of the ILEC s local service or UNE platform.
75679_11_ITEM1_P131_S0	Our package offerings are competitively priced and include popular features, including caller ID, voice messaging, three-way calling, call forwarding, and call waiting.
75679_11_ITEM1_P132_S0	Small business subscribers generally may cancel local access service at any time.
75679_11_ITEM1_P133_S0	Certain small business and most large business, governmental and educational institution customers generally contract with us for service over one to five year periods.
75679_11_ITEM1_P134_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment video services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $11.2 million, $9.2 million, and $9.6 million, respectively, or 2% of our total revenues for each year.
75679_11_ITEM1_P135_S0	Commercial segment subscribers such as hospitals, hotels and motels are charged negotiated monthly service fees.
75679_11_ITEM1_P136_S0	Our video on demand platform is available to hotels in Anchorage that are connected using our fiber facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P137_S0	Programming services offered to our cable television systems subscribers differ by system as described in the Consumer segment Video Services and Products section above.
75679_11_ITEM1_P137_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P138_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment data services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $76.8 million, $63.4 million, and $70.1 million, respectively, or 12%, 11%, and 12% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P139_S0	We currently offer several Internet service packages for commercial use.
75679_11_ITEM1_P139_S1	Our business high-speed cable modem Internet service offers access of up to 22 Mbps download and upload speeds, and free 24-hour customer service and technical support.
75679_11_ITEM1_P139_S2	We also provide dedicated access Internet service to commercial and public organizations in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P140_S0	Data network services utilize voice and data transmission circuits, dedicated to particular subscribers, which link a device in one location to another in a different location.
75679_11_ITEM1_P140_S1	Private IP, private lines, metro Ethernet and frame relay offer a secure solution for frequent communication of large amounts of data between sites.
75679_11_ITEM1_P141_S0	We design, sell, install, service and operate, on behalf of certain customers, communications and computer networking equipment and provide field/depot, third party, technical support, communications consulting and outsourcing services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P141_S1	We supply integrated voice and data communications systems incorporating private IP, interstate and intrastate digital data networks, point-to-point and multipoint data network and small earth station services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P142_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment wireless services and products in 2010, 2009, and 2008 totaled $8.7 million, $6.7 million, and $5.6 million, respectively, or 1% of our total revenues for each year.
75679_11_ITEM1_P143_S0	Wireless services and products offered to our Commercial segment customers are the same as those described in the Consumer Wireless Services and Products section above.
75679_11_ITEM1_P143_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P144_S0	We combine one or more of our individual service or product offerings into bundles that we sell to our Commercial segment customers at attractive prices as described further in the Consumer segment Services and Products section above.
75679_11_ITEM1_P144_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P144_S2	Additionally, we use master service agreements with larger enterprise customers to capture the overall relationship.
75679_11_ITEM1_P145_S0	Our Commercial segment sales and marketing efforts focus on increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P145_S1	We sell our Commercial segment services and products primarily through direct contact marketing.
75679_11_ITEM1_P146_S0	Our Commercial segment uses many facilities to provide services and products that are common to the Consumer segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P146_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P147_S0	We provide our own facilities-based local access services to many of Anchorage s larger business customers through expansion and deployment of SONET, optical ethernet, and gigabit passive optical network fiber transmission facilities, digital loop carrier facilities, and leased facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P148_S0	Our dedicated Internet access and Internet protocol/Multi-Protocol Label Switching data services are delivered to an Ethernet port located at the service point.
75679_11_ITEM1_P148_S1	Our management platform constantly monitors this port and continual communications are maintained with all of the core and distribution elements in the network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P148_S2	The availability and quality of service, as well as statistical information on traffic loading, are continuously monitored for quality assurance.
75679_11_ITEM1_P149_S0	The manage ment platform has the capability to remotely access routers, servers and layer two switches, permitting changes in configuration without the need to physically be at the service point.
75679_11_ITEM1_P149_S1	This management platform allows us to offer network monitoring and management services to businesses and governmental entities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P149_S2	Many of the largest commercial networks in Alaska use this service, including the State government.
75679_11_ITEM1_P150_S0	Many of our Commercial segment voice, video, data and wireless services and products are also common to the Consumer segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P150_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Competition above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P151_S0	We expect continued competition in commercial customer telephone access, Internet access, wireless and data markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P152_S0	Competition is based upon price and pricing plans, the type of services offered, customer service, billing services, performance, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_11_ITEM1_P153_S0	Presently, there are a number of competing companies in Alaska that actively sell and maintain data and voice communications systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P154_S0	equipment has allowed us to maintain our market position based on customer support services rather than price competition alone.
75679_11_ITEM1_P154_S1	These services are blended with other transport products into unique customer solutions, including managed services and outsourcing.
75679_11_ITEM1_P155_S0	Our Commercial segment voice, video, data and wireless services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P155_S1	Our ability to implement construction projects to expand our outside plant facilities is hampered during the winter months because of cold temperatures, snow and short daylight hours.
75679_11_ITEM1_P156_S0	Managed Broadband segment revenues for 2010, 2009 and 2008 are summarized as follows:
75679_11_ITEM1_P157_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Managed Broadband segment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P158_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment offers Internet access, data network and managed services to rural schools and health organizations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P159_S0	SchoolAccess is a suite of services designed to advance the educational opportunities of students in underserved regions of the country.
75679_11_ITEM1_P159_S1	Our SchoolAccess division provides Internet and distance learning services designed exclusively for the school environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P159_S2	The Schools and Libraries Program of the Universal Service Fund ("USF") makes discounts available to eligible rural school districts for telecommunication services and monthly Internet service charges.
75679_11_ITEM1_P159_S3	The program is intended to ensure that rural school districts have access to affordable services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P160_S0	Our network, Internet and software application services provided through our Managed Broadband segment s Medical Services division are branded as ConnectMD .
75679_11_ITEM1_P160_S1	Our ConnectMD services are currently provided under contract to medical businesses in Alaska, Washington and Montana.
75679_11_ITEM1_P161_S0	The Rural Health Care Program of the USF makes discounts available to eligible rural health care providers for telecommunication services and monthly Internet service charges.
75679_11_ITEM1_P161_S1	The program is intended to ensure that rural health care providers pay no more for telecommunication services in the provision of health care services than their urban counterparts.
75679_11_ITEM1_P162_S0	Customers utilize ConnectMD services to securely move data, images, voice traffic, and real time multipoint interactive video.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S0	We offer a managed video conferencing product for use in distance learning, telemedicine and group communication and collaboration environments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S1	The product is designed to offer customers enhanced communication services that support video, audio and data presentation.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S2	Our product benefits customers by reducing travel costs, improving course equity in education and increasing the quality of health services available to patients.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S3	The product bundles our data products, video conferencing services and optional rental of video conferencing endpoint equipment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S4	Our video conferencing services include multipoint conferencing, integrated services digital network gateway and transcoding services, online scheduling and conference control, and videoconference recording, archiving and streaming.
75679_11_ITEM1_P163_S5	We provide 24-hour technical support via telephone or online.
75679_11_ITEM1_P164_S0	Our videoconferencing network is the largest in Alaska, and network coverage includes parts of the states of Washington and Montana.
75679_11_ITEM1_P164_S1	The network supports all H.323 IP videoconferencing standards including the newer H.264 standard, and supports call data rates from 128 Kb per second up to and including multi-megabit high definition calls.
75679_11_ITEM1_P165_S0	In 2010, 2009, and 2008, we terminated over 33,000, 32,000 and 30,000, respectively, videoconferencing endpoint connections amounting to over 2.5 million, 2.0 million and 1.8 million, respectively, videoconferencing minutes on our network .
75679_11_ITEM1_P166_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment sales and marketing efforts focus on increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P166_S1	We sell our Managed Broadband segment services and products primarily through direct contact marketing.
75679_11_ITEM1_P167_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment services and products are delivered using a platform including many of the latest advancements in technology through a locally available circuit, our existing lines, and/or satellite earth stations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P167_S1	Our Internet services are partially provisioned over a satellite based digital video broadcast carrier that reduces the requirement for new satellite transponder bandwidth to support growth in ConnectMD , SchoolAccess and other broadband services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P168_S0	We employ a packet data satellite transmission technology for the efficient transport of broadband data in support of our ConnectMD and SchoolAccess initiatives.
75679_11_ITEM1_P168_S1	Our SchoolAccess Internet service is delivered as follows:
75679_11_ITEM1_P169_S0	In communities where we have terrestrial interconnects or provide existing service over regional earth stations, we have configured intermediate distribution facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P170_S0	In communities or remote locations to which we have not extended communications services, SchoolAccess is provided via a dedicated (usually on premise) very small aperture terminal ("VSAT") satellite station.
75679_11_ITEM1_P170_S1	The VSAT connects to an intermediate distribution facility located in Anchorage.
75679_11_ITEM1_P171_S0	Our facilities include DeltaNet, a long-haul broadband microwave network ringing the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta a region of approximately 50,000 square miles in western Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P171_S1	DeltaNet links more than 30 villages to Bethel, the region s hub.
75679_11_ITEM1_P171_S2	We utilize DeltaNet to support growth in wireless and broadband services including ConnectMD and SchoolAccess .
75679_11_ITEM1_P172_S0	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P173_S0	There are several competing companies in Alaska that actively sell broadband services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P173_S1	Our ability to provide end-to-end broadband services solutions has allowed us to maintain our market position based on value added services and products rather than solely based on price competition.
75679_11_ITEM1_P173_S2	These services are blended with other transport and software products into unique customer solutions, including SchoolAccess and ConnectMD applications such as video conferencing and unique web content services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P174_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment does not exhibit seasonality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P175_S0	We offer voice and data services and products to commercial and residential customers in 60 rural communities primarily in Southwest Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P175_S1	Regulated Operations segment revenues were $22.7 million, $23.8 million, and $14.3 million in 2010, 2009, and from the June 1, 2008 date of acquisition of UUI and United-KUC, Inc. ( United-KUC ) through December 31, 2008, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1_P176_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment offers wireline communications services to our residential and commercial customers, including local access and Internet services and products.
75679_11_ITEM1_P177_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment sales efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of subscribers we serve.
75679_11_ITEM1_P177_S1	We sell our Regulated Operations segment services through local media advertising, retail stores, and through our website.
75679_11_ITEM1_P178_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment services are delivered by switching, outside plant, terrestrial microwave, and satellite facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P178_S1	Our outside plant is primarily aerial and buried copper and fiber optic cables.
75679_11_ITEM1_P179_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment has no competition for its local access services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P180_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_11_ITEM1_P181_S0	Our sales and marketing strategy hinges on our ability to leverage (i) our unique position as an integrated provider of multiple communications, Internet and cable services, (ii) our well-recognized and respected brand names in the Alaskan marketplace and (iii) our leading market positions in the services and products we offer.
75679_11_ITEM1_P181_S1	By continuing to pursue a marketing strategy that takes advantage of these characteristics, we believe we can increase our customer market penetration and retention rates, increase our share of our customers aggregate voice, video, data and wireless services expenditures and achieve continued growth in revenues and operating cash flow.
75679_11_ITEM1_P182_S0	We may undertake activities that, under certain circumstances may affect the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P182_S1	Accordingly, they are subject to federal, state, and local regulations designed to preserve or protect the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P183_S0	The FCC, the Bureau of Land Management, the United States Forest Service, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Park Service are required by the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 to consider the environmental impact before the commencement of facility construction.
75679_11_ITEM1_P184_S0	We believe that compliance with such regulations has had no material effect on our consolidated operations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P184_S1	The principal effect of our facilities on the environment would be in the form of construction of facilities and networks at various locations in Alaska and between Alaska, Seattle, Washington, and Warrenton, Oregon.
75679_11_ITEM1_P184_S2	Our facilities have been constructed in accordance with federal, state and local building codes and zoning regulations whenever and wherever applicable.
75679_11_ITEM1_P184_S3	Some facilities may be on lands that may be subject to state and federal wetland regulation.
75679_11_ITEM1_P185_S0	Uncertainty as to the applicability of environmental regulations is caused in major part by the federal government s decision to consider a change in the definition of wetlands.
75679_11_ITEM1_P185_S1	Most of our facilities are on leased property, and, with respect to all of these facilities, we are unaware of any violations of lease terms or federal, state or local regulations pertaining to preservation or protection of the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P186_S0	The engineered routes of our projects to construct terrestrial and undersea fiber optic cable facilities pass over wetlands and other environmentally sensitive areas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P186_S1	We believe our construction methods used for buried cable have a minimal impact on the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P186_S2	The agencies, among others, that are involved in permitting and oversight of our cable deployment efforts are the United States Army Corps of Engineers, National Marine Fisheries Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, United States Coast Guard, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Alaska Department of Natural Resources, and the Alaska Office of the Governor-Governmental Coordination.
75679_11_ITEM1_P186_S3	We are unaware of any violations of federal, state or local regulations or permits pertaining to preservation or protection of the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P187_S0	In the course of operating our cable television and communications systems, we have used various materials defined as hazardous by applicable governmental regulations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P187_S1	These materials have been used for insect repellent, paint used to mark the location of our facilities, and pole treatment, and as heating fuel, transformer oil, cable cleaner, batteries, diesel fuel, and in various other ways in the operation of those systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P187_S2	We do not believe that these materials, when used in accordance with manufacturer instructions, pose an unreasonable hazard to those who use them or to the environment.
75679_11_ITEM1_P188_S0	We do not hold patents, franchises or concessions for communications services or local access services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P188_S1	We do hold registered service marks for the letters GCI , and for the terms SchoolAccess , Alaska United Fiber Optic Cable System , GCI ConnectMD , ConnectMD , GCI Hypernet , My GCI , MyGCI , Keep Talking Alaska , Digiminutes , Unicom , Cell-ID , and United-KUC .
75679_11_ITEM1_P189_S0	The Communications Act of 1934, as amended, gives the FCC the authority to license and regulate the use of the electromagnetic spectrum for radio communications.
75679_11_ITEM1_P189_S1	We hold licenses through our subsidiary GCI Communication Corp. for our satellite and microwave transmission facilities for provision of long-distance services provided by our Consumer, Commercial and Network Access segments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P190_S0	We hold the following licenses, among others:
75679_11_ITEM1_P191_S0	Two licenses for use of a 30 MHz block of spectrum, which together authorize provision of PCS services in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P191_S1	Both licenses have an expiration date of June 23, 2015.
75679_11_ITEM1_P191_S2	Licenses may be revoked and license renewal applications may be denied for cause.
75679_11_ITEM1_P192_S0	A LMDS license which we acquired in 1998 for use of a 150 MHz block of spectrum in the 28 GHz Ka-band for providing wireless services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P193_S0	Several 25 MHz cellular B licenses are held by our subsidiary Unicom for sites located in the Wade Hampton AK-1 portion of CMA 315 and the Bethel AK-2 portion of CMA 316, throughout the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta.
75679_11_ITEM1_P194_S0	Earth stations are licensed generally for fifteen years.
75679_11_ITEM1_P194_S1	The FCC also issues a single blanket license for a large number of technically identical earth stations (e.g., VSATs).
75679_11_ITEM1_P194_S2	Our operations may require additional licenses in the future.
75679_11_ITEM1_P195_S0	We are certified through the Regulatory Commission of Alaska ( RCA ) to provide cable service by Certificates of Public Convenience and Necessity ( CPCN ).
75679_11_ITEM1_P195_S1	These CPCNs are nonexclusive certificates issued for each community.
75679_11_ITEM1_P195_S2	Although CPCNs have no stated expiration date they may be revoked due to cause.
75679_11_ITEM1_P196_S0	Our businesses are subject to substantial government regulation and oversight.
75679_11_ITEM1_P196_S1	The following summary of regulatory issues does not purport to describe all existing and proposed federal, state, and local laws and regulations, or judicial and regulatory proceedings that affect our businesses.
75679_11_ITEM1_P196_S2	Existing laws and regulations are reviewed frequently by legislative bodies, regulatory agencies, and the courts and are subject to change.
75679_11_ITEM1_P196_S3	Any change in the Act that loosened regulatory oversight of ILECs control of bottleneck facilities could have an adverse impact on our businesses.
75679_11_ITEM1_P196_S4	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of any present or future consideration of proposed changes to governing laws and regulations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P197_S0	As an Interexchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the FCC and the RCA as a non-dominant provider of interstate, international, and intrastate long-distance services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P197_S1	As a state-certificated competitive local exchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the RCA and the FCC as a non-dominant provider of local communications services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P197_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide communications services to military bases.
75679_11_ITEM1_P198_S0	A Rural Telephone Company is exempt from compliance with certain material interconnection requirements under Section 251(c) of the 1996 Telecom Act, including the obligation to negotiate Section 251(b) and (c) interconnection requirements in good faith, unless and until a state regulatory commission lifts such rural exemption or otherwise finds it not to apply.
75679_11_ITEM1_P199_S0	All ILECs in Alaska are Rural Telephone Companies except ACS in its Anchorage study area.
75679_11_ITEM1_P200_S0	Fairbanks and Juneau operating companies, MTA and Ketchikan, in order to achieve the necessary Interconnection Agreements with the remaining ILECs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P200_S1	In other cases the Interconnection Agreements were reached by negotiation without regard to the implications of the ILEC s rural exemption.
75679_11_ITEM1_P201_S0	We have completed negotiation and/or arbitration of the necessary interconnection provisions and the RCA has approved current wireline Interconnection Agreements between GCI and all of the major ILECs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P201_S1	We have entered all of the major Alaskan markets with local access services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P202_S0	See Description of Our Business by Reportable Segment Consumer Competition Voice Services and Products Competition for more information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P203_S0	Access Charges and Other Regulated Fees.
75679_11_ITEM1_P204_S0	The FCC regulates the fees that local telephone companies charge long-distance companies for access to their local networks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P204_S1	On February 8, 2011, the FCC issued its most recent proposal to restructure and possibly reduce interstate access charges.
75679_11_ITEM1_P205_S0	Changes to the interstate access charge regime or introduction of new technologies not subject to access charges could fundamentally change the economics of some aspects of our business.
75679_11_ITEM1_P205_S1	In addition, the RCA adopted intrastate access reform, which has not yet been promulgated as final rules.
75679_11_ITEM1_P205_S2	We believe the proposed reduction of intrastate access rates will result in a cost savings to us and does not present a substantial risk.
75679_11_ITEM1_P206_S0	Carriers also pay fees for switched wholesale transport services in and out of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P206_S1	The rates for such services offered by and to any provider were governed by a federal law that was effective through December 31, 2009.
75679_11_ITEM1_P206_S2	The expiration of the applicable federal law is likely to result in a decrease in the rates for services, which would result in a reduction of revenues.
75679_11_ITEM1_P207_S0	The ability to obtain UNEs is an important element of our local access services business.
75679_11_ITEM1_P207_S1	We cannot predict the extent to which existing FCC rules governing access to and pricing for UNEs will be sustained in the face of additional legal action and the impact of any further rules that are yet to be determined by the FCC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P207_S2	Moreover, the future regulatory classification of services that are transmitted over facilities may impact the extent to which we will be permitted access to such facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P207_S3	Changes to the applicable regulations could result in a change in our cost of serving new and existing markets.
75679_11_ITEM1_P208_S0	Recurring and non-recurring charges for UNE-loops and other UNEs may increase based on the rates adopted in RCA proceedings to establish new Interconnection Agreements or renew existing agreements.
75679_11_ITEM1_P208_S1	These increases could have an adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1_P209_S0	The USF pays Eligible Telecommunications Carriers ("ETC") to support the provision of facilities-based wireline telephone service in high-cost areas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P209_S1	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireline local exchange service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, and the MTA study area (which includes the Matanuska-Susitna Valley) and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P209_S2	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireline telephone services, and our net cost of providing local telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_11_ITEM1_P210_S0	On May 1, 2008, the FCC issued an order adopting the recommendation of the Federal State Joint Board on Universal Service ( Joint Board ) to impose a state-by-state interim cap on high cost funds to be distributed to competitive ETCs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P210_S1	As part of the revised policy, the FCC adopted a limited exception from the cap for competitive ETCs serving tribal lands or Alaska Native regions.
75679_11_ITEM1_P210_S2	While the operation of the cap has generally reduced the high cost fund amounts available to competitive ETCs as new competitive ETCs are designated and as existing competitive ETCs acquire new customers, providers like us who serve tribal lands or Alaska Native regions were provided some relief.
75679_11_ITEM1_P210_S3	On March 5, 2009, the FCC issued an additional order waiving a previously adopted limitation to the exception, the result of which was to provide uncapped support for all lines served by competitive ETCs for tribal lands or Alaska Native regions during the time the interim cap is in effect.
75679_11_ITEM1_P210_S4	The uncapped support for tribal lands or Alaska Native regions and the cap for all other regions will be in place until the FCC takes action on proposals for long term reform.
75679_11_ITEM1_P211_S0	On March 16, 2010, the FCC staff released the National Broadband Plan, including among its topics a proposal to transition existing USF high cost support from voice to broadband networks over a ten year period.
75679_11_ITEM1_P211_S1	On April 21, 2010, the FCC initiated a proceeding to consider interim and long-term USF reforms, including a five year phase-out of support to competitive ETCs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P212_S0	Proposed Rulemaking to consider adopting reforms to its high cost support program, including, among other things, the proposed competitive ETC phase-out and ways to fund and distribute support for broadband services.
