75679_11_ITEM1_P212_S1	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of this proceeding or its effect on high cost support available to us, but our revenue for providing local services in these areas would be materially adversely affected by the reduction of USF support.
75679_11_ITEM1_P213_S0	We may be required to obtain local permits for street opening and construction permits to install and expand our networks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P213_S1	Local zoning authorities often regulate our use of towers for microwave and other communications sites.
75679_11_ITEM1_P213_S2	We also are subject to general regulations concerning building codes and local licensing.
75679_11_ITEM1_P214_S0	The 1996 Telecom Act requires that fees charged to communications carriers be applied in a competitively neutral manner, but there can be no assurance that ILECs and others with whom we will be competing will bear costs similar to those we will bear in this regard.
75679_11_ITEM1_P215_S0	Because cable communications systems use local streets and rights-of-way, they generally are operated pursuant to franchises (which can take the form of certificates, permits or licenses) granted by a municipality or other state or local government entity.
75679_11_ITEM1_P216_S0	The RCA is the franchising authority for all of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P216_S1	We believe that we have generally met the terms of our franchises, which do not require periodic renewal, and have provided quality levels of service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P216_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide video services to military bases.
75679_11_ITEM1_P217_S0	The RCA is also certified under federal law to regulate rates for the Basic Service tier on our cable systems.
75679_11_ITEM1_P217_S1	Under state law, however, cable television service is exempt from regulation unless subscribers petition the RCA.
75679_11_ITEM1_P217_S2	At present, regulation of basic cable rates takes place only in Juneau.
75679_11_ITEM1_P218_S0	The RCA does not regulate rates for cable modem service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P219_S0	The 1992 Cable Act contains broadcast signal carriage requirements that allow local commercial television broadcast stations to elect once every three years to require a cable system to carry the station, subject to certain exceptions, or to negotiate for retransmission consent to carry the station.
75679_11_ITEM1_P220_S0	The FCC has adopted rules to require cable operators to carry the digital programming streams of broadcast television stations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P220_S1	The FCC requirement that cable operators carry both the analog and digital programming streams of broadcast television stations while broadcasters are transitioning from analog to digital transmission does not apply to all-digital systems like ours.
75679_11_ITEM1_P220_S2	Further, the FCC has declined to require any cable operator to carry multiple digital programming streams from a single broadcast television station, but should the FCC change this policy, we would be required to devote additional cable capacity to carrying broadcast television programming streams, a step that could require the removal of other programming services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P221_S0	Cable System Delivery of Internet Service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P221_S1	The FCC has defined high-speed Internet over cable as an information service not subject to local cable-franchise fees, as cable service may be, or any explicit requirements for open access.
75679_11_ITEM1_P221_S2	The Supreme Court affirmed the FCC s position in a decision issued in 2005.
75679_11_ITEM1_P222_S0	Although there is at present no significant federal regulation of cable system delivery of Internet services, this situation may change as cable systems expand their broadband delivery of Internet services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P222_S1	Proposals have been advanced at the FCC and Congress to require cable operators to provide access to unaffiliated Internet service providers and online service providers and to govern the terms under which content providers and applications are delivered by all broadband network operators.
75679_11_ITEM1_P222_S2	If such requirements were imposed on cable operators, it could burden the capacity of cable systems and frustrate our plans for providing expanded Internet access services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P222_S3	These access obligations could adversely affect our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1_P223_S0	The FCC mandated, effective July 1, 2007, that all new set-top video navigation devices must segregate the security function from the navigation function.
75679_11_ITEM1_P223_S1	The new devices are more expensive than existing equipment, and compliance would increase our cost of providing cable services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P223_S2	Subject to a waiver granted by the FCC on May 4, 2007, we may continue providing low-cost integrated set-top boxes to consumers to facilitate our all-digital cable networks.
75679_11_ITEM1_P224_S0	On April 21, 2010, the FCC adopted a Notice of Inquiry to consider ways to develop a standardized interface for accessing video content, as an alternative to set-top boxes.
75679_11_ITEM1_P224_S1	Adoption of new rules or standards in this area could affect the manner in which we deliver video products to our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P224_S2	We do not know if the FCC will propose rules for further consideration.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S0	The Communications Act requires the FCC to regulate the rates, terms and conditions imposed by public utilities for cable systems use of utility pole and conduit space unless state authorities can demonstrate that they adequately regulate pole attachment rates.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S1	In the absence of state regulation, the FCC administers pole attachment rates on a formula basis.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S2	This formula governs the maximum rate certain utilities may charge for attachments to their poles and conduit by companies providing communications services, including cable operators.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S3	The RCA, however, does not use the federal formula and instead has adopted its own formula that has been in place since 1987.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S4	This formula could be subject to further revisions upon petition to the RCA and the FCC has an open rulemaking proceeding to consider application of the federal formula.
75679_11_ITEM1_P225_S5	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of any such proceedings.
75679_11_ITEM1_P226_S0	Cable television systems are subject to federal copyright licensing covering carriage of television and radio broadcast signals.
75679_11_ITEM1_P226_S1	In exchange for filing certain reports and contributing a percentage of their revenues to a federal copyright royalty pool that varies depending on the size of the system, the number of distant broadcast television signals carried, and the location of the cable system, cable operators can obtain blanket permission to retransmit copyrighted material included in broadcast signals.
75679_11_ITEM1_P226_S2	The possible modification or elimination of this compulsory copyright license is the subject of continuing legislative review.
75679_11_ITEM1_P226_S3	We cannot predict the outcome of this legislative review, which could adversely affect our ability to obtain desired broadcast program ming.
75679_11_ITEM1_P227_S0	Copyright clearances for non-broadcast programming services are arranged through private negotiations.
75679_11_ITEM1_P228_S0	There is no one entity or organization that governs the Internet.
75679_11_ITEM1_P228_S1	Each facilities-based network provider that is interconnected with the global Internet controls operational aspects of their own network.
75679_11_ITEM1_P228_S2	Certain functions, such as IP addressing, domain name routing, and the definition of the TCP/IP protocol, are coordinated by an array of quasi-governmental, intergovernmental, and non-governmental bodies.
75679_11_ITEM1_P228_S3	The legal authority of these bodies is not precisely defined.
75679_11_ITEM1_P229_S0	Although the FCC does not regulate the prices charged by Internet service providers or Internet backbone providers, the vast majority of users connect to the Internet over facilities of existing communications carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P229_S1	Those communications carriers are subject to varying levels of regulation at both the federal and the state level.
75679_11_ITEM1_P229_S2	Thus, non-Internet-specific regulatory decisions exercise a significant influence over the economics of the Internet market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P230_S0	Many aspects of the coordination and regulation of Internet activities and the underlying networks over which those activities are conducted are evolving.
75679_11_ITEM1_P230_S1	Internet-specific and non-Internet-specific changes in the regulatory environment, including changes that affect communications costs or increase competition from ILECs or other communications services providers, could adversely affect the prices at which we sell Internet-based services.
75679_11_ITEM1_P231_S0	Recently adopted net neutrality regulations have not yet gone into effect and are subject to court appeals.
75679_11_ITEM1_P231_S1	We are currently assessing the steps required to satisfy the regulations as adopted by the FCC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P231_S2	Further legislative proposals under the banner of net neutrality , if adopted, could interfere with our ability to reasonably manage and invest in our broadband network, and could adversely affect the manner and price of providing service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P232_S0	The FCC regulates the licensing, construction, interconnection, operation, acquisition, and transfer of wireless network systems in the United States pursuant to the Communications Act.
75679_11_ITEM1_P232_S1	As a licensee of PCS, LMDS, and other wireless services, we are subject to regulation by the FCC, and must comply with certain build-out and other license conditions, as well as with the FCC s specific regulations governing the PCS and LMDS services (described above).
75679_11_ITEM1_P233_S0	The FCC does not currently regulate rates for services offered by commercial mobile radio service providers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P234_S0	and associated equipment are located and are also subject to regulation under federal environmental laws and the FCC s environmental regulations, including limits on radio frequency radiation from wireless handsets and antennas on towers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P235_S0	We have completed negotiation and the RCA has approved current direct wireless Interconnection Agreements between GCI and all of the major Alaska ILECs.
75679_11_ITEM1_P235_S1	These are in addition to indirect interconnection arrangements utilized elsewhere.
75679_11_ITEM1_P236_S0	The USF pays ETCs to support the provision of facilities-based wireless telephone service in high-cost areas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P236_S1	A wireless carrier may seek ETC status so that it can receive support from the USF.
75679_11_ITEM1_P236_S2	Several wireless carriers, including us, have successfully applied to the RCA for ETC status in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P236_S3	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireless telephone service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, and the MTA study area (which includes the Matanuska-Susitna Valley) and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P236_S4	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireless telephone services, and our net cost of providing wireless telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_11_ITEM1_P237_S0	See Description of Our Business by Reportable Segment Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products Universal Service for more information.
75679_11_ITEM1_P238_S0	The FCC has imposed rules requiring carriers to provide emergency 911 services, including enhanced 911 services that provide to local public safety dispatch agencies the caller s communications number and approximate location.
75679_11_ITEM1_P239_S0	Providers are required to transmit the geographic coordinates of the customer s location, either by means of network-based or handset-based technologies, within accuracy parameters recently revised by the FCC, to be implemented over a phase-in period.
75679_11_ITEM1_P239_S1	We are assessing the application of such parameters in Alaska s relatively low population and rural service areas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P240_S0	Providers may not demand cost recovery as a condition of doing so, although they are permitted to negotiate cost recovery if it is not mandated by the state or local governments.
75679_11_ITEM1_P241_S0	While the Communications Act generally preempts state and local governments from regulating the entry of, or the rates charged by, wireless carriers, it also permits a state to petition the FCC to allow it to impose commercial mobile radio service rate regulation when market conditions fail to adequately protect customers and such service is a replacement for a substantial portion of the telephone wireline exchange service within a state.
75679_11_ITEM1_P241_S1	No state currently has such a petition on file, and all prior efforts have been rejected.
75679_11_ITEM1_P241_S2	In addition, the Communications Act does not expressly preempt the states from regulating the terms and conditions of wireless service.
75679_11_ITEM1_P242_S0	Several states have invoked this terms and conditions authority to impose or propose various consumer protection regulations on the wireless industry.
75679_11_ITEM1_P242_S1	State attorneys general have also become more active in enforcing state consumer protection laws against sales practices and services of wireless carriers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P242_S2	States also may impose their own universal service support requirements on wireless and other communications carriers, similar to the contribution requirements that have been established by the FCC.
75679_11_ITEM1_P243_S0	States have become more active in attempting to impose new taxes and fees on wireless carriers, such as gross receipts taxes.
75679_11_ITEM1_P243_S1	Where successful, these taxes and fees are generally passed through to our customers and result in higher costs to our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1_P244_S0	At the local level, wireless facilities typically are subject to zoning and land use regulation.
75679_11_ITEM1_P244_S1	Neither local nor state governments may categorically prohibit the construction of wireless facilities in any community or take actions, such as indefinite moratoria, which have the effect of prohibiting construction.
75679_11_ITEM1_P244_S2	Nonetheless, securing state and local government approvals for new tower sites has been and is likely to continue to be difficult, lengthy and costly.
75679_11_ITEM1_P245_S0	Although we have several agreements to help originate and terminate international toll traffic, we do not have foreign operations or export sales.
75679_11_ITEM1_P245_S1	We conduct our operations throughout the western contiguous United States and Alaska and believe that any subdivision of our operations into distinct geographic areas would not be meaningful.
75679_11_ITEM1_P246_S0	We have not expended material amounts during the last three fiscal years on customer-sponsored research activities.
75679_11_ITEM1_P247_S0	We offer voice, data and wireless telecommunication services and video services to customers primarily throughout Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P247_S1	Because of this geographic concentration, growth of our business and operations depends upon economic conditions in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P248_S0	The economy of Alaska is dependent upon the natural resource industries, and in particular oil production, as well as investment earnings, tourism, government, and United States military spending.
75679_11_ITEM1_P248_S1	Any deterioration in these markets could have an adverse impact on us.
75679_11_ITEM1_P249_S0	A significant part of the Alaska economy is the state government.
75679_11_ITEM1_P249_S1	All of the federal funding and the majority of investment revenues are dedicated for specific purposes, leaving oil revenues as the primary source of general operating revenues for the State of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P249_S2	The State of Alaska reported in fiscal 2010 that oil revenues supplied 89% of the State's unrestricted revenues.
75679_11_ITEM1_P249_S3	In fiscal 2011 state economists forecast that Alaska s oil revenues will supply 87% of the State s projected unrestricted revenues.
75679_11_ITEM1_P250_S0	The volume of oil transported by the TransAlaska Oil Pipeline System over the past 20 years has been as high as 2.011 million barrels per day in fiscal 1988.
75679_11_ITEM1_P250_S1	Production has been declining over the last several years with an average of 0.644 million barrels produced per day in fiscal 2010.
75679_11_ITEM1_P250_S2	The State forecasts the production rate to decline from 0.616 million barrels produced per day in fiscal 2011 to 0.52 million barrels produced per day in fiscal 2020.
75679_11_ITEM1_P251_S0	Market prices for North Slope oil averaged $74.90 in fiscal 2010 and are forecasted to average $77.96 in fiscal 2011.
75679_11_ITEM1_P251_S1	The closing price per barrel was $111.98 on March 1, 2011.
75679_11_ITEM1_P252_S0	To the extent that actual oil prices vary materially from the State s projected prices, the State s projected revenues and deficits will change.
75679_11_ITEM1_P252_S1	The production policy of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its ability to continue to act in concert represents a key uncertainty in the State s revenue forecast.
75679_11_ITEM1_P253_S0	Should new oil discoveries or developments not materialize or the price of oil become depressed, the long term trend of continued decline in oil production from the Prudhoe Bay area is inevitable with a corresponding adverse impact on the economy of the State, in general, and on demand for telecommunications and cable television services, and, therefore, on us, in particular.
75679_11_ITEM1_P254_S0	Periodically there are renewed efforts to allow exploration and development in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge ( ANWR ).
75679_11_ITEM1_P254_S1	The United States Energy Information Agency has estimated that it could take nine years to begin oil field drilling after approval of ANWR exploration.
75679_11_ITEM1_P255_S0	No assurance can be given that the driving forces in the Alaska economy, and in particular, oil production, will continue at appropriate levels to provide an environment for expanded economic activity.
75679_11_ITEM1_P255_S1	The governor of the State of Alaska and the Alaska legislature continue to evaluate the state s oil tax structure which may also affect the oil production industry in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P256_S0	No assurance can be given that oil companies doing business in Alaska will be successful in discovering new fields or further developing existing fields which are economic to develop and produce oil with access to the pipeline or other means of transport to market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P257_S0	We are not able to predict the effect of changes in the price and production volumes of North Slope oil on Alaska s economy or on us.
75679_11_ITEM1_P258_S0	Deployment of a natural gas pipeline from the State of Alaska s North Slope to the lower 48 states has been proposed to supplement natural gas supplies.
75679_11_ITEM1_P259_S0	There are two competing companies that are studying the economic viability of a natural gas pipeline, which depends upon the price of and demand for natural gas.
75679_11_ITEM1_P259_S1	Both of the companies completed an initial open season for shipping bids during 2010.
75679_11_ITEM1_P259_S2	These open seasons were approved by government regulators and submissions are currently under evaluation by involved parties.
75679_11_ITEM1_P260_S0	The State of Alaska maintains the Constitutional Budget Reserve Fund ( CBRF ) that is intended to fund budgetary shortfalls.
75679_11_ITEM1_P260_S1	If the State s current projections are realized and no surpluses are deposited into the CBRF it is projected that the fund would not be depleted before 2020.
75679_11_ITEM1_P261_S0	The date the CBRF is depleted is highly influenced by the price of oil.
75679_11_ITEM1_P261_S1	If the fund is depleted, aggressive state action will be necessary to increase revenues and reduce spending in order to balance the budget.
75679_11_ITEM1_P261_S2	The governor of the State of Alaska and the Alaska legislature continue to evaluate cost cutting and revenue enhancing measures.
75679_11_ITEM1_P262_S0	We have, since our entry into the telecommunication marketplace, aggressively marketed our services to seek a larger share of the available market.
75679_11_ITEM1_P262_S1	The customer base in Alaska is limited, however, with a population of approximately 710,000 people.
75679_11_ITEM1_P262_S2	The State of Alaska s population is distributed as follows:
75679_11_ITEM1_P263_S0	The remaining 20% are located in other communities across the State of Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1_P264_S0	We employed 1,655 persons as of December 31, 2010, and we are not subject to any collective bargaining agreements with our employees.
75679_11_ITEM1_P264_S1	We believe our future success will depend upon our continued ability to attract and retain highly skilled and qualified employees.
75679_11_ITEM1_P264_S2	We believe that relations with our employees are satisfactory.
75679_11_ITEM1_P265_S0	No material portion of our business is subject to renegotiation of profits or termination of contracts at the election of the federal government.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business operations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We face competition that may reduce our market share and harm our financial performance.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	There is substantial competition in the telecommunications industry.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	The traditional dividing lines between long-distance, local access, wireless, Internet and video services are increasingly becoming blurred.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Through mergers and various service integration strategies, major providers are striving to provide integrated communications services offerings within and across geographic markets.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We face increasing video services competition from DBS providers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We expect competition to increase as a result of the rapid development of new technologies, services and products.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	We cannot predict which of many possible future technologies, products or services will be important to maintain our competitive position or what expenditures will be required to develop and provide these technologies, products or services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Our ability to compete successfully will depend on marketing and on our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry, including new services that may be introduced, changes in consumer preferences, economic conditions and pricing strategies by competitors.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	To the extent we do not keep pace with technological advances or fail to timely respond to changes in competitive factors in our industry and in our markets, we could lose market share or experience a decline in our revenue and net income.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Competitive conditions create a risk of market share loss and the risk that customers shift to less profitable lower margin services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Competitive pressures also create challenges for our ability to grow new businesses or introduce new services successfully and execute our business plan.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P4_S6	Each of our business segments also faces the risk of potential price cuts by our competitors that could materially adversely affect our market share and gross margins.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	For more information about competition by segment, see the sections titled Competition included in Item 1 Business Narrative Description of our Business Description of our Business by Reportable Segment.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is subject to extensive governmental legislation and regulation.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Applicable legislation and regulations and changes to them could adversely affect our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The licensing, construction, operation, sale and interconnection arrangements of wireless communications systems are regulated by the FCC and, depending on the jurisdiction, state and local regulatory agencies.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	In particular, the FCC imposes significant regulation on licensees of wireless spectrum with respect to:
75679_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Resolution of issues of interference between spectrum bands.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	The Communications Act of 1934, as amended, preempts state and local regulation of market entry by, and the rates charged by, commercial mobile radio service providers, except that states may exercise authority over such things as certain billing practices and consumer-related issues.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	These regulations could increase the costs of our wireless operations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The FCC grants wireless licenses for terms of generally ten years that are subject to renewal and revocation.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	FCC rules require all wireless licensees to meet certain build-out requirements and substantially comply with applicable FCC rules and policies and the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, in order to retain their licenses.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Failure to comply with FCC requirements in a given license area could result in revocation of the license for that license area.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P10_S3	There is no guarantee that our licenses will be renewed.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The FCC has initiated a number of proceedings to evaluate its rules and policies regarding spectrum licensing and usage.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Changes proposed by the FCC could adversely impact our utilization of our licensed spectrum and our operation costs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Commercial mobile radio service providers must implement enhanced 911 ("E911") capabilities in accordance with FCC rules.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Failure to deploy E911 service consistent with FCC requirements could subject us to significant fines.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The FCC, together with the Federal Aviation Administration, also regulates tower marking and lighting.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	In addition, tower construction is affected by federal, state and local statutes addressing zoning, environmental protection and historic preservation.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P14_S2	The FCC adopted significant changes to its rules governing historic preservation review of projects, which makes it more difficult and expensive to deploy antenna facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P14_S3	The FCC is also considering changes to its rules regarding environmental protection as related to tower construction, which, if adopted, could make it more difficult to deploy facilities.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	The cable television industry is subject to extensive regulation at various levels, and many aspects of such regulation are currently the subject of judicial proceedings and administrative or legislative proposals.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	The law permits certified local franchising authorities to order refunds of rates paid in the previous 12-month period determined to be in excess of the reasonable rates.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	It is possible that rate reductions or refunds of previously collected fees may be required of us in the future.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Currently, pursuant to Alaska law, the basic cable rates in Juneau are the only rates in Alaska subject to regulation by the local franchising authority, and the rates in Juneau were reviewed and approved by the RCA in July 2010.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Proposals may be made before Congress and the FCC to mandate cable operators provide open access over their cable systems to Internet service providers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	As of the date of this report, the FCC has declined to impose such requirements.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	If the FCC or other authorities mandate additional access to our cable systems, we cannot predict the effect that this would have on our Internet service offerings.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Other existing federal regulations, currently the subject of judicial, legislative, and administrative review, could change, in varying degrees, the manner in which cable television systems operate.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Neither the outcome of these proceedings nor their impact upon the cable television industry in general, or on our activities and prospects in the cable television business in particular, can be predicted at this time.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	There can be no assurance that future regulatory actions taken by Congress, the FCC or other federal, state or local government authorities will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Changes in the regulatory environment relating to the Internet access market, including changes in legislation, FCC regulation, judicial action or local regulation that affect communications costs or increase competition from the ILEC or other communications services providers, could adversely affect the prices at which we sell Internet services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our success in the local telephone market depends on our continued ability to obtain interconnection, access and related services from local exchange carriers on terms that are reasonable and that are based on the cost of providing these services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Our local telephone services business faces the risk of the impact of the implementation of current regulations and legislation, unfavorable changes in regulation or legislation or the introduction of new regulations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	Our ability to enter into the local telephone market depends on our negotiation or arbitration with local exchange carriers to allow interconnection to the carrier s existing local telephone network, to establish dialing parity, to obtain access to rights-of-way, to resell services offered by the local exchange carrier, and in some cases, to allow the purchase, at cost-based rates, of access to UNEs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P21_S3	In some Alaska markets, it also depends on our ability to gain interconnection at economic costs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Future arbitration proceedings with respect to new or existing markets could result in a change in our cost of serving these markets via the facilities of the ILEC or via wholesale offerings.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	For more information about Regulations affecting our operations, see Competition contained in Item 1 Business Regulation.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Loss of our ETC status would disqualify us for USF support.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The USF pays support to ETCs to support the provision of facilities-based wireline and wireless telephone service in high-cost areas.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	If we were to lose our ETC status in any of the study areas where we are currently an authorized ETC, we would be ineligible to receive USF support for providing service in that area.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Loss of our ETC status could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Revenues and accounts receivable from USF support may be reduced or lost.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We receive support from each of the various USF programs: high-cost, low income, rural health care, and schools and libraries.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P26_S1	This support was 18%, 14%, and 10% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P26_S2	The programs are subject to change by regulatory actions taken by the FCC or legislative actions.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P26_S3	The FCC has proposed phasing out support for voice services and targeting support to broadband services, as well as phasing out support for competitive ETCs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P26_S4	In addition, members of Congress have indicated that they may seek enactment of legislation addressing universal service reform, including legislation to limit growth of explicit universal service support funds.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Changes to any of the USF programs that we participate in could result in a material decrease in revenue and accounts receivable, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	See Description of Our Business by Reportable Segment Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products Universal Service for more information.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We may not be able to satisfy the requirements of the loan/grant we obtained to build TERRA-SW and/or we may have to spend considerably more than expected to complete the project.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The TERRA-SW project requires us to construct network facilities in rural areas of Alaska where extensive network facilities have never been built.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Our ability to complete the TERRA-SW project will require us to obtain permits from various government agencies as well as construct facilities in rural locations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S2	We will be unable to meet the requirements of the grant if we are unable to obtain necessary construction permits and if we are unable to construct the necessary facilities in the rural locations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S3	Additionally, we may be required to incur significant unplanned costs if we encounter unplanned construction challenges.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S4	These additional unplanned costs may require us to modify our other network expansion plans so that we may meet the requirements of the grant.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P30_S5	Our inability to meet the requirements of the grant and/or significant cost overruns in the construction of TERRA-SW could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Failure to complete development, testing and deployment of new technology that supports new services could affect our ability to compete in the industry.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	In addition, the technology we use may place us at a competitive disadvantage.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We develop, test and deploy various new technologies and support systems intended to enhance our competitiveness by both supporting new services and features and reducing the costs associated with providing those services or features.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Successful development and implementation of technology upgrades depend, in part, on the willingness of third parties to develop new applications in a timely manner.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	We may not successfully complete the development and rollout of new technology and related features or services in a timely manner, and they may not be widely accepted by our customers or may not be profitable, in which case we could not recover our investment in the technology.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P33_S2	Deployment of technology supporting new service offerings may also adversely affect the performance or reliability of our networks with respect to both the new and existing services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Any resulting customer dissatisfaction could affect our ability to retain customers and may have an adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Unfavorable general economic conditions in the United States could have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Unfavorable general economic conditions, including the current economic downturn in the United States, could negatively affect our business.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	While it is often difficult for us to predict the impact of general economic conditions on our business, these conditions could adversely affect the affordability of and demand for some of our products and services and could cause customers to shift to lower priced products and services or to delay or forgo purchases of our products and services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P35_S2	One or more of these circumstances could cause our revenue to decline.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Also, our customers may not be able to obtain adequate access to credit, which could affect their ability to make timely payments to us.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P35_S4	If that were to occur, we could be required to increase our allowance for doubtful accounts, and the number of days outstanding for our accounts receivable could increase.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	The government has taken various measures in an attempt to help improve the economy, however, we are unable to predict the success or outcome of such programs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	For these reasons, among others, if the current economic conditions persist or decline, this could adversely affect our financial position, results of operations, or liquidity, as well as our ability to service debt, pay other obligations and enhance shareholder returns.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Our business is geographically concentrated in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Any deterioration in the economic conditions in Alaska could have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We offer voice, data and wireless communication and video services to customers primarily in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	Because of this geographic concentration, our growth and operations depend upon economic conditions in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	The economy of Alaska is dependent upon natural resource industries, in particular oil production, as well as tourism, and government spending, including substantial amounts for the United States military.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Any deterioration in these markets could have an adverse impact on the demand for communication and cable television services and on our results of operations and financial condition.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P39_S2	In addition, the customer base in Alaska is limited.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Alaska has a population of approximately 710,000 people, 54% of whom are located in the Anchorage and Matanuska-Susitna Borough region.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P40_S1	We have already achieved significant market penetration with respect to our service offerings in Anchorage and in other locations in Alaska.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We may not be able to continue to increase our market share of the existing markets for our services, and no assurance can be given that the Alaskan economy will continue to grow and increase the size of the markets we serve or increase the demand for the services we offer.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P41_S1	As a result, the best opportunities for expanding our business may arise in other geographic areas such as the lower 49 states.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P41_S2	There can be no assurance that we will find attractive opportunities to grow our businesses outside of Alaska or that we will have the necessary expertise to take advantage of such opportunities.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The markets in Alaska for voice, data and wireless communications and video services are unique and distinct within the United States due to Alaska s large geographical size, its sparse population located in a limited number of clusters, and its distance from the rest of the United States.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P42_S1	The expertise we have developed in operating our businesses in Alaska may not provide us with the necessary expertise to successfully enter other geographic markets.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Prolonged service interruptions could affect our business.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	We rely heavily on our network equipment, communications providers, data and software to support all of our functions.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S1	We rely on our networks and the networks of others for substantially all of our revenues.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S2	We are able to deliver services only to the extent that we can protect our network systems against damage from power or communication failures, computer viruses, natural disasters, unauthorized access and other disruptions.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S3	While we endeavor to provide for failures in the network by providing back-up systems and procedures, we cannot guarantee that these back-up systems and procedures will operate satisfactorily in an emergency.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S4	Should we experience a prolonged failure, it could seriously jeopardize our ability to continue operations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P44_S5	In particular, should a significant service interruption occur, our ongoing customers may choose a different provider, and our reputation may be damaged, reducing our attractiveness to new customers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P45_S0	To the extent that any disruption or security breach results in a loss or damage to our customers data or applications, or inappropriate disclosure of confidential information, we may incur liability and suffer from adverse publicity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P45_S1	In addition, we may incur additional costs to remedy the damage caused by these disruptions or security breaches.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P46_S0	If failures occur in our undersea fiber optic cable systems, our ability to immediately restore the entirety of our service may be limited and we could incur significant costs, which could lead to a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our communications facilities include undersea fiber optic cable systems that carry a large portion of our traffic to and from the contiguous lower 48 states one of which provides an alternative geographically diverse backup communication facility to the other.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P47_S1	If a failure of both sides of the ring of our undersea fiber optic facilities occurs and we are not able to secure alternative facilities, some of the communications services we offer to our customers could be interrupted which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Damage to an undersea fiber optic cable system can result in significant unplanned expense which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P48_S0	If a failure occurs in our satellite communications systems, our ability to immediately restore the entirety of our service may be limited.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our communications facilities include satellite transponders that we use to serve many rural and remote Alaska locations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Each of our C-band and Ku-band satellite transponders is backed up on the same spacecraft with multiple backup transponders.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P49_S2	If a failure of our satellite transponders occurs and we are not able to secure alternative facilities, some of the communications services we offer to our customers could be interrupted which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We depend on a limited number of third-party vendors to supply communications equipment.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P50_S1	If we do not obtain the necessary communications equipment, we will not be able to meet the needs of our customers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We depend on a limited number of third-party vendors to supply cable, Internet, DLPS, wireless and other telephony-related equipment.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P51_S1	If our providers of this equipment are unable to timely supply the equipment necessary to meet our needs or provide them at an acceptable cost, we may not be able to satisfy demand for our services and competitors may fulfill this demand.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Due to the unique characteristics of the Alaska communications markets (i.e., remote locations, rural, satellite-served, low density populations, and our leading edge services and products), in many situations we deploy and utilize specialized, advanced technology and equipment that may not have a large market or demand.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Our vendors may not succeed in developing sufficient market penetration to sustain continuing production and may fail.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P52_S2	Vendor bankruptcy, or acquisition without continuing product support by the acquiring company, may require us to replace technology before its otherwise useful end of life due to lack of on-going vendor support and product development.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We do not have insurance to cover certain risks to which we are subject, which could lead to the incurrence of uninsured liabilities that adversely affect our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P54_S0	As is typical in the communications industry, we are self-insured for damage or loss to certain of our transmission facilities, including our buried, undersea and above-ground transmission lines.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P54_S1	If we become subject to substantial uninsured liabilities due to damage or loss to such facilities, our financial position, results of operations or liquidity may be adversely affected.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Our significant debt could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations under our Senior Notes.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P56_S0	We have and will continue to have a significant amount of debt.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P56_S1	On December 31, 2010, we had total debt of $786.7 million.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P56_S2	Our debt balance is expected to increase by $44.2 million with the construction of TERRA-SW between 2011 and 2012.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P56_S3	Our high level of debt could have important consequences, including the following:
75679_11_ITEM1A_P57_S0	Limit, along with the financial and other restrictive covenants in our debt, among other things, our ability to borrow additional funds, dispose of assets or pay cash dividends.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P58_S0	We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt, complete our planned network expansion and to meet other obligations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Our ability to generate cash depends on many factors beyond our control.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P59_S1	If we are unable to meet our future capital needs it may be necessary for us to curtail, delay or abandon our business growth plans.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P59_S2	If we incur significant additional indebtedness to fund our plans, it could cause a decline in our credit rating and could increase our borrowing costs or limit our ability to raise additional capital.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S0	We will continue to require a significant amount of cash to satisfy our debt service requirements and to meet other obligations.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S1	We expect to incur $44.2 million in additional debt for the construction of TERRA-SW in 2011-2012 and, to meet our capital needs, we may incur additional debt in the future.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S2	Our ability to make payments on and to refinance our debt and to fund planned capital expenditures and acquisitions will depend on our ability to generate cash and to arrange additional financing in the future.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S3	These abilities are subject to, among other factors, our credit rating, our financial performance, general economic conditions, prevailing market conditions, the state of competition in our market, the outcome of certain legislative and regulatory issues and other factors that may be beyond our control.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S4	Our business may not generate sufficient cash flow from operations and future borrowings may not be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debt or to fund our other liquidity needs.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S5	We may need to refinance all or a portion of our debt on or before maturity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P60_S6	We may not be able to refinance any of our debt on commercially reasonable terms or at all.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P61_S0	The terms of our debt impose restrictions on us that may affect our ability to successfully operate our business and our ability to make payments on the Senior Notes.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P62_S0	The indentures governing our Senior Notes and/or the credit agreements governing our Senior Credit Facility and other loans contain various covenants that could materially and adversely affect our ability to finance our future operations or capital needs and to engage in other business activities that may be in our best interest.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P63_S0	All of these covenants may restrict our ability to expand or to pursue our business strategies.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P63_S1	Our ability to comply with these covenants may be affected by events beyond our control, such as prevailing economic conditions and changes in regulations, and if such events occur, we cannot be sure that we will be able to comply.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Notes and/or the Senior Credit Facility.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P64_S1	If there were an event of default under the indentures for the Senior Notes and/or the Senior Credit Facility, holders of such defaulted debt could cause all amounts borrowed under these instruments to be due and payable immediately.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P64_S2	Additionally, if we fail to repay the debt under the Senior Credit Facility when it becomes due, the lenders under the Senior Credit Facility could proceed against certain of our assets and capital stock of our subsidiaries that we have pledged to them as security.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P64_S3	Our assets or cash flow may not be sufficient to repay borrowings under our outstanding debt instruments in the event of a default thereunder.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P65_S0	Concerns about health risks associated with wireless equipment may reduce the demand for our wireless services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P66_S0	Portable communications devices have been alleged to pose health risks, including cancer, due to radio frequency emissions from these devices.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P66_S1	Purported class actions and other lawsuits have been filed against numerous other wireless carriers seeking not only damages but also remedies that could increase the cost of doing business.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P66_S2	We cannot be sure of the outcome of those cases or that the industry will not be adversely affected by litigation of this nature or public perception about health risks.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P66_S3	The actual or perceived risk of mobile communications devices could adversely affect us through a reduction in subscribers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P66_S4	Further research and studies are ongoing, and we cannot be sure that additional studies will not demonstrate a link between radio frequency emissions and health concerns.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P67_S0	Additionally, new government regulations on the use of a wireless device while driving may affect us through a reduction in subscribers.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P68_S0	Studies have indicated that using wireless devices while driving may impair a driver s attention.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P68_S1	Many state and local legislative bodies have passed or proposed legislation to restrict the use of wireless telephones while driving vehicles.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P68_S2	Concerns over safety and the effect of future legislation, if adopted and enforced in the areas we serve, could limit our ability to market and sell our wireless services.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P68_S3	Litigation relating to accidents, deaths or serious bodily injuries allegedly incurred as a result of wireless telephone use while driving could result in adverse publicity and further governmental regulation.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P68_S4	Any of these results could have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P69_S0	A significant percentage of GCI s voting securities are owned by a small number of shareholders and these shareholders can control shareholder decisions on very important matters.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P70_S0	As of December 31, 2010, our executive officers and directors and their affiliates owned 9% of GCI s combined outstanding Class A and class B common stock, representing 20% of the combined voting power of that stock.
75679_11_ITEM1A_P70_S1	These shareholders can significantly influence, if not control, our management policy and all fundamental corporate actions, including mergers, substantial acquisitions and dispositions, and election of directors to GCI s Board.
75679_12_ITEM2_P0_S0	Our properties do not lend themselves to description by location of principal units.
75679_12_ITEM2_P0_S1	The majority of our properties are located in Alaska.
75679_12_ITEM2_P0_S2	It is not practicable to allocate our properties to our reportable segments since many of our properties are employed by more than one segment to provide common services and products.
75679_12_ITEM2_P0_S3	Additionally our properties are managed at the consolidated company level rather than at the segment level.
75679_12_ITEM2_P1_S0	We lease our executive, corporate and administrative facilities and business offices.
75679_12_ITEM2_P1_S1	Our operating, executive, corporate and administrative properties are in good condition.
75679_12_ITEM2_P1_S2	We consider our properties suitable and adequate for our present needs and they are being fully utilized.
75679_12_ITEM2_P2_S0	Our properties consist primarily of undersea and terrestrial fiber optic cable networks, switching equipment, satellite transponders and earth stations, microwave radio, cable and wire facilities, cable head-end equipment, wireless towers and equipment, coaxial distribution networks, connecting lines (aerial, underground and buried cable), routers, servers, transportation equipment, computer equipment, general office equipment, land, land improvements, landing stations and other buildings.
75679_12_ITEM2_P2_S1	Substantially all of our properties are located on or in leased real property or facilities.
75679_12_ITEM2_P2_S2	Substantially all of our properties secure our Senior Credit Facility.
75679_12_ITEM2_P2_S3	See note 6 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information.
75679_12_ITEM3_P0_S0	We are involved in various lawsuits, billing disputes, legal proceedings, and regulatory matters that have arisen from time to time in the normal course of business.
75679_12_ITEM3_P0_S1	While the ultimate results of these items cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not expect at this time for the resolution of them to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_12_ITEM3_P0_S2	In addition we are involved in the following matters:
75679_12_ITEM3_P1_S0	In September 2008, the FCC's Office of Inspector General ("OIG") initiated an investigation regarding Alaska DigiTel LLC s ( Alaska DigiTel ) compliance with program rules and requirements under the Lifeline Program.
75679_12_ITEM3_P1_S1	The request covered the period beginning January 1, 2004 through August 31, 2008 and related to amounts received for Lifeline service.
75679_12_ITEM3_P2_S0	Alaska DigiTel was an Alaska based wireless communications company of which we acquired an 81.9% equity interest on January 2, 2007 and the remaining 18.1% equity interest on August 18, 2008 and was subsequently merged with one of our wholly owned subsidiaries in April 2009.
75679_12_ITEM3_P2_S1	Prior to August 18, 2008, our control over the operations of Alaska DigiTel was limited as required by the FCC upon its approval of our initial acquisition completed in January 2007.
75679_12_ITEM3_P2_S2	We responded to this request on behalf of Alaska DigiTel and the GCI companies as affiliates.
75679_12_ITEM3_P2_S3	On January 18, 2011 we reached an agreement with the FCC and the Department of Justice to settle the matter, which required us to contribute $1.6 million to the United States Treasury and granted us a broad release of claims including those under the False Claims Act.
75679_12_ITEM3_P3_S0	In August 2010, a company-owned aircraft was involved in an accident resulting in five fatalities and injuries to the remaining four passengers on board.
75679_12_ITEM3_P3_S1	We had aircraft and liability insurance coverage in effect at the time of the accident.
75679_12_ITEM3_P3_S2	As of December 31, 2011, all claims paid out have been covered by insurance and were recorded net of these recoveries in our Consolidated Income Statements.
75679_12_ITEM3_P3_S3	While some of the claims have been resolved, we cannot predict the likelihood or nature of the total remaining claims, including environmental remediation, related to the accident.
75679_12_ITEM5_P0_S0	All issued and outstanding shares of GCI, Inc's Class A common stock are held by GCI and are not publicly traded.
75679_12_ITEM5_P0_S1	GCI's Class A and Class B common stock are publicly traded.
75679_12_ITEM5_P1_S0	GCI and GCI, Inc. have never paid cash dividends on GCI s common stock, and we have no present intention of doing so.
75679_12_ITEM5_P1_S1	Payment of cash dividends in the future, if any, will be determined by GCI s Board of Directors in light of our earnings, financial condition and other relevant considerations.
75679_12_ITEM5_P1_S2	Our existing debt agreements contain provisions that limit payment of dividends on common stock, other than stock dividends (see note 6 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information) .
75679_12_ITEM5_P2_S0	Computershare is GCI s stock transfer agent and registrar.
75679_12_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following table presents selected historical information relating to financial condition and results of operations over the past five years.
75679_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	The Selected Financial Data should be read in conjunction with Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
75679_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	In the following discussion, GCI, Inc. and its direct and indirect subsidiaries are referred to as we, us and our.
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations discusses our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ).
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S2	On an on-going basis, we evaluate our estimates and judgments, including those related to the allowance for doubtful receivables, unbilled revenues, accrual of the USF high cost Remote area program support, share-based compensation, inventory at lower of cost or market, reserve for future customer credits, valuation allowances for deferred income tax assets, depreciable and amortizable lives of assets, the carrying value of long-lived assets including goodwill, cable certificates and wireless licenses, our effective tax rate, purchase price allocations, the accrual of cost of goods sold (exclusive of depreciation and amortization expense) ("Cost of Goods Sold"), depreciation, and contingencies and litigation.
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S3	We base our estimates and judgments on historical experience and on various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
75679_12_ITEM7_P1_S5	See also our Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.
75679_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	GCI, Inc. was incorporated under the laws of the State of Alaska in 1997 to affect the issuance of Senior Notes.
75679_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	GCI, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of GCI, received through its initial capitalization all ownership interests in subsidiaries previously held by GCI.
75679_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	Shares of GCI s Class A common stock are traded on the Nasdaq National Market tier of the Nasdaq Stock Market under the symbol of GNCMA.
75679_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	Shares of GCI s Class B common stock are traded on the Over-the-Counter market.
75679_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	Shares of GCI, Inc. s common stock are wholly owned by GCI and are not publicly traded.
75679_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	The GCI and GCI, Inc. consolidated financial statements include substantially the same account activity.
75679_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	The following discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and supplementary data as presented in Part IV of this Form 10-K.
75679_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Through our focus on long-term results, acquisitions, and strategic capital investments, we strive to consistently grow our revenues and expand our margins.
75679_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	We have historically met our cash needs for operations, regular capital expenditures and maintenance capital expenditures through our cash flows from operating activities.
75679_12_ITEM7_P5_S2	Historically, cash requirements for significant acquisitions and major capital expenditures have been provided largely through our financing activities.
75679_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	The national economy continues to see persistent unemployment and slow economic growth and even once stabilized is not expected to return quickly to a period of strong growth.
75679_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Should the national economy deteriorate further, it could lead to reductions in consumer spending which could impact our revenue growth.
75679_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	We believe the Alaska economy continues to perform well compared to most other states at the current time.
75679_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	The State of Alaska has large cash reserves that should enable it to maintain its budget for at least the short-term.
75679_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	This cash reserve is important for Alaska s economy as the State is the largest employer and second largest source of gross state product.
75679_12_ITEM7_P7_S3	The majority of our revenue is driven by the strength of the Alaska economy which appears to have weathered the recessionary pressures relatively well to date.
75679_12_ITEM7_P7_S4	Nonetheless we cannot predict the impact the nation s future economic situation may have on us in the future.
75679_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	As part of an agreement signed in December 2007 with AT T Mobility, AT T Mobility has provided to us a large block of wireless network usage at no charge that we use for roaming.
75679_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	This block of minutes expired in January 2012 and we expect our wireless Cost of Goods Sold to increase $4.8 million to $5.3 million before factoring in the impact of 2012 subscriber growth .
75679_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	Our future wireless Cost of Goods Sold will depend on several factors including: the impact and timing of our wireless network build-out, the pattern of usage by our wireless subscribers, and negotiated rates with our roaming partners.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	As an ETC, we receive support from the USF to support the provision of wireline local access and wireless service in high cost areas.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	On November 29, 2011, the FCC published a final rule to reform the methodology for distributing USF high cost support for voice and broadband services, as well as to the access charge regime for terminating traffic between carriers ( High Cost Order ).
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S2	The High Cost Order divided support to Alaska between Urban and Remote areas.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S3	Support for CETCs serving Urban areas that generally include Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau will follow national reforms, capping support per provider per service area as of January 1, 2012, and commencing a five-step phase-down on July 1, 2012.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S4	In addition to broader reforms, the FCC tailored revisions specifically for CETCs serving Remote Alaska, intended to address the unique challenges for serving these areas.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S5	Support to these locations will be capped and distributed on a per-line basis until the later of July 1, 2014, or the implementation of a successor funding mechanism.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S6	A further rulemaking to consider successor funding mechanisms is underway.
75679_12_ITEM7_P9_S7	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of this proceeding or its effect on Remote high cost support available to us, but our revenue for providing local services in these areas would be materially adversely affected by a substantial reduction of USF support.
75679_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	The High Cost Order Remote and Urban program changes decreased our revenue $3.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, primarily impacting our Consumer segment.
75679_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	The High Cost Order Remote and Urban program changes will decrease our 2012 revenue approximately $4 .0 million as compared to 2011.
75679_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	At December 31, 2011, we have $33.1 million and $8.5 million in Remote and Urban high cost accounts receivable, respectively.
75679_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	In November 2010, Verizon acquired a license for 700 MHz wireless spectrum covering Alaska.
75679_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	We expect Verizon will build an LTE network in 2012 and subsequently they will be an additional competitor where our markets overlap.
75679_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	We cannot predict the potential impact this new competition may have on us in the future.
75679_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	The following table sets forth selected financial data as a percentage of total revenues for the periods indicated (underlying data rounded to the nearest thousand):
75679_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	We evaluate performance and allocate resources based on earnings before depreciation and amortization expense, net interest expense, income taxes, share-based compensation expense, accretion expense, loss attributable to non-controlling interest and non-cash contribution adjustment ( Adjusted EBITDA ).
75679_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	Management believes that this measure is useful to investors and other users of our financial information in evaluating operating profitability as an analytical indicator of income generated to service debt and fund capital expenditures.
75679_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	In addition, multiples of current or projected EBITDA are used to estimate current or prospective enterprise value.
75679_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	See note 10 in the "Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements" included in Part IV of this annual report on Form 10-K for a reconciliation of consolidated Adjusted EBITDA, a non-GAAP financial measure, to consolidated income before income taxes .
75679_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	Total revenues increased 4% from $651.3 million in 2010 to $679.4 million in 2011.
75679_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	Revenue increases in our Consumer, Commercial and Managed Broadband segments were partially offset by decreased revenue in our Network Access and Regulated Operations segments.

75679_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	See note 10 in the "Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements" included in Part IV of this annual report on Form 10-K for a reconciliation of consolidated Adjusted EBITDA, a non-GAAP financial measure, to consolidated income before income taxes.
75679_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	Selected key performance indicators for our Consumer segment follow:
75679_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	1 A long-distance subscriber is defined as a customer account that is invoiced a monthly long-distance plan fee or has made a long-distance call during the month.
75679_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	2 A local access line in service is defined as a revenue generating circuit or channel connecting a customer to the public switched telephone network.
75679_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	3 A basic subscriber is defined as one basic tier of service delivered to an address or separate subunits thereof regardless of the number of outlets purchased.
75679_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	4 A digital programming tier subscriber is defined as one digital programming tier of service delivered to an address or separate subunits thereof regardless of the number of outlets or digital programming tiers purchased.
75679_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Digital programming tier subscribers are a subset of basic subscribers.
75679_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	5 A high-definition/digital video recorder ("HD/DVR") converter box is defined as one box rented by a digital programming or basic tier subscriber.
75679_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	A digital programming or basic tier subscriber is not required to rent an HD/DVR converter box to receive service.
75679_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	6 Average monthly consumer video revenues divided by the average of consumer basic subscribers at the beginning and end of each month in the period.
75679_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	7 A cable modem subscriber is defined by the purchase of cable modem service regardless of the level of service purchased.
75679_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	If one entity purchases multiple cable modem service access points, each access point is counted as a subscriber.
75679_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	Cable modem subscribers may also be video basic subscribers though basic cable service is not required to receive cable modem service.
75679_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	8 A wireless line in service is defined as a revenue generating wireless device.
75679_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	9 Average monthly consumer wireless revenues divided by the average of consumer wireless subscribers at the beginning and end of each month in the period.
75679_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	The increase in data revenue is primarily due to a 19% increase in cable modem revenue to $63.4 million due to increased subscribers, rate increases in May and August 2010 and in May 2011 and our subscribers selection of plans that offer higher speeds.
75679_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	As discussed in the General Overview section of this Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations the FCC published the High Cost Order in November 2011.
75679_12_ITEM7_P34_S1	The High Cost Order Remote and Urban program changes decreased our Consumer Segment Voice revenue $617,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011 , and decreased our Consumer Segment Wireless revenue $2.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
75679_12_ITEM7_P34_S2	The High Cost Order Remote and Urban program changes will result in decreased Consumer Segment Voice revenue of approximately $1.6 million and decreased Consumer Segment Wireless revenue of approximately $1.7 million for the year ending December 31, 2012 .
75679_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	On February 6, 2012, the FCC released its Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking to comprehensively reform and modernize the USF s Lifeline program.
75679_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	The Lifeline program is administered by the USAC and is designed to ensure that quality telecommunications services are available to low-income customers at just, reasonable, and affordable rates.
75679_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	We participate in the Lifeline program and recognized $16.9 million in Consumer Wireless Lifeline program support revenue during the year ended December 31, 2011.
75679_12_ITEM7_P36_S2	Following are the reforms included in the order that we expect to impact 2012 Consumer Segment Wireless revenue:
75679_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	The order adopted on an interim basis a flat rate of $9.25 to replace the support previously available under Tier I through Tier III support mechanisms.
75679_12_ITEM7_P37_S1	The replacement support reduces the wireless subscriber per line support $0.75 which we expect will result in a $300,000 reduction in our revenue for the year ending December 31, 2012.
75679_12_ITEM7_P37_S2	The FCC intends to further investigate whether this support amount is reasonable over the long term in further rulemaking.
75679_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	The order adopted a requirement for annual recertification of all Lifeline subscribers enrolled as of June 1, 2012 to be completed by the end of 2012.
75679_12_ITEM7_P38_S1	We are evaluating this requirement and possible processes and cannot predict whether this new rule will have a material impact on our income statement, financial position or cash flows.
75679_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	The increase in video Cost of Goods Sold is primarily due to increased channels offered to our subscribers, increased rates paid to programmers and increased costs associated with delivery of digital services offered through our HD/DVR converter boxes.
75679_12_ITEM7_P39_S1	This increase was partially offset by decreased costs due to a decrease in subscribers.
75679_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	The wireless Cost of Goods Sold increase is primarily due to increased costs for wireless handset equipment sales and a change in the allocation of network maintenance costs.
75679_12_ITEM7_P40_S1	The increased wireless handset equipment sale costs are associated with an increased number of premium wireless handsets which have higher costs and an increased number of handsets issued to new customers and those extending their service.
75679_12_ITEM7_P40_S2	The change in allocation of network maintenance costs resulted in an increase to our Consumer segment and a decrease to our Network Access, Commercial and Managed Broadband segments.
75679_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	The decrease in Adjusted EBITDA is primarily due to increased Cost of Goods Sold as described above in Consumer Segment Cost of Goods Sold and an increase in the selling, general and administrative expense that was allocated to our Consumer segment due to an increase in the 2010 segment margin upon which the selling, general and administrative expense allocation is based and an increase in consolidated selling, general and administrative expense.
75679_12_ITEM7_P41_S1	These increases are partially offset by increased revenue as described above in "Consumer Segment Revenues.

75679_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	Selected key performance indicators for our Network Access segment follow:

75679_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	Beginning in 2011 these Cost of Goods Sold were reclassified to data Cost of Goods Sold for a more accurate presentation.
75679_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	The increase in data Cost of Goods Sold is primarily due to:
75679_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	A $5.3 million Cost of Goods Sold classification change.
75679_12_ITEM7_P49_S1	Prior to 2011 certain Cost of Goods Sold were classified as Network Access segment voice Cost of Goods Sold.
75679_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	$1.8 million in Cost of Goods Sold related to special project work.
75679_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	The Adjusted EBITDA decrease is primarily due to decreased revenue and increased Cost of Goods Sold as described above in Network Access Segment Cost of Goods Sold.
75679_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	These changes are partially offset by a decrease in the selling, general and administrative expense that was allocated to our Network Access segment primarily due to a decrease in the 2010 segment margin upon which the selling, general and administrative expense allocation is based.

75679_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	This latter category can vary significantly based on project activity.
