75679_13_ITEM1_P59_S0	We offer local access services in many communities and areas in Alaska, including the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau.
75679_13_ITEM1_P59_S1	Our own digital local phone service ( DLPS ) facilities and collocated remote facilities that access the incumbent local exchange carrier ( ILEC ) unbundled network element ("UNE") loops allow us to offer full featured local service products to customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P59_S2	In areas where we do not have our own DLPS facilities or access to ILEC UNE loop facilities, we offer service using total service resale of the ILEC s local service or UNE platform.
75679_13_ITEM1_P60_S0	We combine one or more of our individual service and product offerings into bundles that we sell to our Consumer segment customers at attractive prices.
75679_13_ITEM1_P60_S1	Our most popular bundled offering includes cable modem Internet access, video service, long-distance and local access services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P60_S2	In addition to several other bundled offerings, we also offer a bundle of wireless services, cable modem Internet access and video service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P61_S0	Our Consumer segment sales efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P62_S0	We operate a modern, competitive communications network employing digital transmission technology over our fiber optic facilities within Alaska and between Alaska and the lower 48 states.
75679_13_ITEM1_P62_S1	Our facilities include three self-constructed digital undersea fiber optic cable systems linking our Alaska terrestrial networks to the networks of other carriers in the lower 48 states:
75679_13_ITEM1_P63_S0	Alaska United Southeast was placed into service in 2008 and connects Ketchikan, Wrangell, Petersburg, Angoon and Sitka, Alaska to Alaska United West and Alaska United East.
75679_13_ITEM1_P64_S0	The combination of our Alaska United East, Alaska United West and Alaska United Southeast systems provides us with the ability to provide fully protected geographically diverse routing of service between Alaska and the lower 48 states.
75679_13_ITEM1_P65_S0	Our Alaska United Northwest self-constructed terrestrial fiber optic cable system connects Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska along the Parks Highway corridor and we own a terrestrial fiber optic cable system that extends from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska to Valdez, Alaska via Fairbanks, Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P66_S0	We have Indefeasible Right to Use ("IRU") capacity in the Kodiak-Kenai Cable Company, LLC s undersea fiber optic cable system linking Anchorage to Kenai, Homer, Kodiak, Narrow Cape on Kodiak Island, and Seward, Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P67_S0	We serve many rural and remote Alaska locations solely via satellite communications.
75679_13_ITEM1_P67_S1	Each of our C-band and Ku-band satellite transponders is backed up on alternate spacecraft with multiple backup transponders.
75679_13_ITEM1_P67_S2	The primary spacecraft we use to provide voice, data and Internet services to our rural Alaska customers are Intelsat s Galaxy 18 for C-band and Intelsat's Horizons 1 for Ku-band, but we also lease capacity on two other spacecraft, SES Americom s AMC-7 and AMC-8.
75679_13_ITEM1_P68_S0	We lease one 36 MHz transponder on SES Americom's AMC-7 spacecraft.
75679_13_ITEM1_P68_S1	We use this transponder to distribute multi-channel, digitally encoded video programming and other services to remote locations within Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P68_S2	We may use this transponder along with four others that we reserve on AMC-7 to restore service during any fiber outage that may occur in our network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P69_S0	We operate digital microwave systems to link Anchorage with the Kenai Peninsula, and our Prudhoe Bay Earth Station with Deadhorse, Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P70_S0	Virtually all switched services are computer controlled, digitally switched, and interconnected by a packet switched SS7 signaling network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P71_S0	We operate a hybrid fiber optic cable and digital microwave system ( TERRA ) linking Anchorage with the Bristol Bay and Yukon-Kuskokwim regions of the state.
75679_13_ITEM1_P71_S1	This system serves 67 communities with interstate Ethernet and TDM services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P71_S2	The network is computer controlled, centrally monitored and supports multiple services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P72_S0	Other facilities include major earth stations at Adak, Barrow, Bethel, Dillingham, Dutch Harbor, Eagle River, Fairbanks, Galena, King Salmon, Kodiak, Kotzebue, McGrath, Nome, Prudhoe Bay, Sitka, Unalakleet, and Yakutat, all in Alaska, serving the communities in their vicinity.
75679_13_ITEM1_P72_S1	The Eagle River earth station is linked to the Anchorage distribution center by fiber optic facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P73_S0	We use a synchronous optical network ("SONET") and Optical Ethernet as service delivery methods for our terrestrial metropolitan area networks and long-haul terrestrial and undersea fiber optic cable systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P74_S0	A fiber optic cable system from our Anchorage distribution center connects to the Matanuska Telephone Association ( MTA ), Eagle River central office and to our major hub earth station in Eagle River.
75679_13_ITEM1_P74_S1	We have digital microwave and fiber IRU facilities serving the Kenai Peninsula communities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P74_S2	We maintain earth stations in Fairbanks (connected via SONET fiber facilities), Anchorage (Benson earth station), and in Prudhoe Bay, Unalakleet and Bethel as terrestrial network restoration earth stations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P74_S3	Our Benson earth station also uplinks our statewide video service; such service may be pre-empted if earth station capacity is needed to restore our fiber network between Anchorage and Prudhoe Bay, and Anchorage and TERRA-SW communities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P75_S0	We use our demand assigned multiple access ("DAMA") facilities to serve 56 additional locations throughout Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P75_S1	DAMA is a digital satellite earth station technology that allows calls to be made between remote villages using only one satellite hop, thereby reducing satellite delay and capacity requirements while improving quality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P75_S2	In addition, 89 (for a total of 145) C-band facilities provide dedicated Internet access and private network services to rural public schools, hospitals, health clinics, and natural resource development industries throughout Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P76_S0	Our network of 213 Ku-band facilities provides dedicated Internet access and private network services to rural public schools, hospitals, health clinics, and natural resource development industries throughout Alaska, and in ten locations in the lower 48 states.
75679_13_ITEM1_P77_S0	Our Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau distribution centers contain electronic switches to route calls to and from local exchange companies and other long-distance carriers and, in Seattle, to obtain access to other carriers to distribute our southbound traffic to the remaining 49 states and international destinations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P77_S1	Our digital switching systems also provide local service in Anchorage, Fairbanks, Juneau and 14 smaller communities throughout Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P77_S2	Our extensive metropolitan area fiber network in Anchorage supports video, Internet and telephony services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P77_S3	The Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau facilities also include digital access cross-connect systems, Internet platforms, frame relay, optical ethernet and multi-protocol label switching ( MPLS ) data switches.
75679_13_ITEM1_P77_S4	The Anchorage and Fairbanks facilities also include collocation facilities for interconnecting and hosting equipment for other carriers and commercial entities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P78_S0	We utilize our coaxial cable facilities for DLPS.
75679_13_ITEM1_P78_S1	This delivery method allows us to utilize our own cable facilities to provide local access service to our customers and avoid paying local loop charges to the ILEC.
75679_13_ITEM1_P79_S0	Our statewide cable systems consist of 3,234 miles of installed cable plant having 450 to 860 MHz of channel capacity.
75679_13_ITEM1_P79_S1	Our video businesses are located throughout Alaska and serve 41 communities and areas in Alaska, including the state s five largest population centers, Anchorage, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, the Kenai Peninsula, and Juneau.
75679_13_ITEM1_P79_S2	Our facilities include cable plant and head-end distribution equipment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P79_S3	Some of our locations on the fiber routes are served from the head-end distribution equipment in Anchorage.
75679_13_ITEM1_P79_S4	All of our cable systems are completely digital.
75679_13_ITEM1_P80_S0	We provide access to the Internet using a platform that includes many of the latest advancements in technology.
75679_13_ITEM1_P80_S1	The physical platform is concentrated in Anchorage and is extended into many remote areas of the state.
75679_13_ITEM1_P80_S2	Our Internet platform includes the following:
75679_13_ITEM1_P81_S0	Our Anchorage facility consists of routers, a bank of servers that perform support and application functions, database servers providing authentication and user demographic data, layer two and layer three gigabit, 10 gigabit and 100 gigabit switch networks for intercommunications and broadband services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P82_S0	Our dedicated Internet access and Internet protocol ("IP") data services are delivered to routers located at the multiple service points throughout our service area.
75679_13_ITEM1_P82_S1	Our Internet management platform constantly monitors these routers and continual communications are maintained with all of the core and distribution devices in the network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P82_S2	The availability and quality of service, as well as statistical information on traffic loading, are continuously monitored for quality assurance.
75679_13_ITEM1_P83_S0	The manage ment platform has the capability to remotely access routers, servers and layer two switches, permitting changes in configuration without the need to be physically located at the service point.
75679_13_ITEM1_P84_S0	We own statewide wireless facilities that cover most of the population providing service to urban and rural Alaska communities and we will continue to expand these networks throughout the terrestrially and satellite served portions of Alaska in 2013.
75679_13_ITEM1_P84_S1	We own GSM/HSPA+ and CDMA/EVDO wireless facilities serving urban Alaska locations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P84_S2	Our urban network includes Ericsson and Nortel wireless switches located in Anchorage and 218 cell sites that serve the following areas of Alaska: Anchorage and Eagle River, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, Kenai Peninsula, Southeast, Kodiak and Fairbanks.
75679_13_ITEM1_P85_S0	Our rural network consists of 164 GSM facilities that are located throughout Alaska s rural villages and communities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P85_S1	We extend our network coverage through roaming arrangements with other GSM and CDMA carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P85_S2	In addition, under an agreement with ACS, we have integrated all of our GSM/HSPA+ sites with all 48 of their Long Term Evolution ( LTE ) network sites to enhance the speed of our data traffic.
75679_13_ITEM1_P85_S3	These integrated sites are located in Anchorage, Fairbanks, Juneau and the Kenai Peninsula.
75679_13_ITEM1_P86_S0	We own 1,212 wireless access points in Anchorage, Fairbanks, Juneau, Kodiak, Ketchikan, Kenai-Soldotna, Matanuska-Susitna valley, and other areas of the State to support our TurboZone product.
75679_13_ITEM1_P87_S0	A discussion of competition by product and service in our Consumer segment follows.
75679_13_ITEM1_P88_S0	We compete against AT T Mobility, ACS, MTA, and resellers of those services in Anchorage and other markets.
75679_13_ITEM1_P89_S0	In November 2010, Verizon acquired a license for 700 MHz wireless spectrum covering Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P89_S1	We expect Verizon will complete their build of a LTE network in 2013 and subsequently they will be an additional competitor where our markets overlap.
75679_13_ITEM1_P90_S0	Regulatory policies favor robust competition in wireless markets.
75679_13_ITEM1_P90_S1	Wireless local number portability helps to maintain a high level of competition in the industry.
75679_13_ITEM1_P91_S0	Number portability allows subscribers to switch carriers without having to change their telephone numbers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P92_S0	The communications industry continues to experience significant technological changes, as evidenced by the increasing pace of improvements in the capacity and quality of digital technology, shorter cycles for new products and enhancements and changes in consumer preferences and expectations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P92_S1	Accordingly, we expect competition in the wireless communications industry to continue to be dynamic and intense as a result of the development of new technologies, services and products.
75679_13_ITEM1_P93_S0	The national wireless carriers against whom we compete or expect to compete, AT T Mobility and Verizon, have resources that are substantially greater than ours.
75679_13_ITEM1_P93_S1	These companies have significantly greater spectrum, capital, financial, marketing, human capital, distribution and other resources than we do.
75679_13_ITEM1_P93_S2	Specifically, as a regional wireless carrier we may not have immediate access to some wireless handsets that are available to these national wireless carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P93_S3	In 2012, along with other regional wireless carriers in Alaska, we gained access to, and began offering, the iPhone-series of wireless handsets to our subscribers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P93_S4	In addition, as discussed in Development of Our Business During the Past Fiscal Year section of this Item 1, we have entered into an agreement with ACS to create AWN, which will allow us to compete better against the national carriers on all resource fronts.
75679_13_ITEM1_P94_S0	We compete for customers based principally upon price, bundled services, the services and enhancements offered, network quality, customer service, network coverage and capacity, the type of wireless handsets offered, and the availability of differentiated features and services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P94_S1	Our ability to compete successfully will depend, in part, on our marketing efforts and our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry.
75679_13_ITEM1_P95_S0	The Internet industry is highly competitive, rapidly evolving and subject to constant technological change.
75679_13_ITEM1_P95_S1	Competition is based upon price and pricing plans, service bundles, the types of services offered, the technologies used, customer service, billing services, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_13_ITEM1_P95_S2	We compete with other Alaska based Internet providers and domestic, non-Alaska based providers that provide national service coverage.
75679_13_ITEM1_P95_S3	Several of the providers headquartered outside of Alaska have substantially greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
75679_13_ITEM1_P96_S0	With respect to our high-speed cable modem service, ACS and other Alaska telephone service providers are providing competitive high-speed data subscriber line services over their telephone lines in direct competition with our high-speed cable modem service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P96_S1	DBS providers and local fixed wireless providers supply wireless high-speed Internet service in competition with our high-speed cable modem services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P97_S0	Niche providers in the industry, both local and national, compete with certain of our Internet service products, such as web hosting, list services and e-mail.
75679_13_ITEM1_P98_S0	We expect to continue to provide, at reasonable prices and in competitive bundles, a greater variety of data services than are available through other alternative delivery sources.
75679_13_ITEM1_P98_S1	Additionally, we believe we offer superior technical performance and speed, and responsive community-based customer service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P98_S2	Increased competition, however, may adversely affect our market share and results of operations from our data services product offerings.
75679_13_ITEM1_P99_S0	Our video systems face competition from online services and devices that offer Internet video streaming and distribution of movies, television shows and other video programming, as well as alternative methods of receiving and distributing television signals, including DBS, digital video over telephone lines, broadband IP-based services, wireless and satellite master antenna television ("SMATV") systems, and from other sources of news, information and entertainment such as off-air television broadcast programming, newspapers, movie theaters, live sporting events, interactive computer services, and home video products, including video discs.
75679_13_ITEM1_P99_S1	Our video systems also face competition from potential overbuilds of our existing cable systems by other cable television operators and municipally-owned cable systems, and alternative methods of receiving and distributing television signals.
75679_13_ITEM1_P99_S2	The extent to which our video systems are competitive depends, in part, upon our ability to provide quality programming and other services at competitive prices.
75679_13_ITEM1_P100_S0	Online video services via the Internet are a major growing source of competition for our video services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P100_S1	However, as a major Internet-provider ourselves, the competition may result in additional data service subscriber revenue to the extent we grow Internet average revenue per subscriber.
75679_13_ITEM1_P101_S0	We believe that the greatest source of external competition for our video services comes from the DBS industry.
75679_13_ITEM1_P101_S1	Two major companies, DIRECTV and DISH DBS Corporation, are currently offering nationwide high-power DBS services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P101_S2	The ILECs in the Matanuska-Susitna Valley and Ketchikan offer digital video service over telephone lines in limited areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P101_S3	Their product offerings and price points are similar to our product offerings.
75679_13_ITEM1_P101_S4	With the addition of Anchorage local broadcast stations, increased marketing, ILEC and DBS alliances, and emerging technologies creating new opportunities, competition from these sources has increased and will likely continue to increase.
75679_13_ITEM1_P102_S0	Competitive forces will be counteracted by offering expanded programming through digital services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P103_S0	Digital delivery technology is being utilized in all of our systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P103_S1	We have retransmission agreements with Anchorage broadcasters and provide for the uplink/downlink of their signals into all our systems, and local programming for our customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P103_S2	Additionally, in November 2012 we entered into the Media Agreements as a method to provide unique content and value to video subscribers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P104_S0	Other new technologies may become competitive with non-entertainment services that video systems can offer.
75679_13_ITEM1_P105_S0	The FCC has authorized television broadcast stations to transmit textual and graphic information useful to both consumers and businesses.
75679_13_ITEM1_P105_S1	The FCC also permits commercial and non-commercial FM radio stations to use their subcarrier frequencies to provide non-broadcast services including data transmissions.
75679_13_ITEM1_P106_S0	The FCC established an over-the-air interactive video and data service that will permit two-way interaction with commercial and educational programming along with informational and data services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P106_S1	ILECs and other common carriers also provide facilities for the transmission and distribution to homes and businesses of interactive computer-based services, including the Internet, as well as data and other non-video services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P107_S0	The FCC has conducted spectrum auctions for licenses to provide personal communication services ( PCS ) as well as other services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P107_S1	PCS and other services will enable license holders, including cable operators, to provide voice and data services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P107_S2	We own a statewide PCS license in Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P108_S0	Video systems generally operate pursuant to franchises granted on a non-exclusive basis.
75679_13_ITEM1_P108_S1	The 1992 Cable Act gives local franchising authorities jurisdiction over basic video service rates and equipment in the absence of effective competition.
75679_13_ITEM1_P108_S2	The 1992 Cable Act also prohibits franchising authorities from unreasonably denying requests for additional franchises and permits franchising authorities to operate video systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P109_S0	Well-financed businesses from outside the video industry (such as the public utilities that own certain of the poles on which cable is attached) may become competitors for franchises or providers of competing services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P110_S0	We expect to continue to provide, at reasonable prices and in competitive bundles, a greater variety of communication services than are available off-air or through other alternative delivery sources.
75679_13_ITEM1_P110_S1	Additionally, we believe we offer superior technical performance and responsive community-based customer service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P110_S2	Increased competition, however, may adversely affect our market share and results of operations from our video services product offerings.
75679_13_ITEM1_P111_S0	We compete against ACS, the ILEC in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks and the Kenai Peninsula area; MTA, the ILEC in the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, and other smaller ILECs in other communities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P112_S0	In the local telephone services market, the 1996 Telecom Act, judicial decisions, state and federal legislative and regulatory developments, and new technologies have increased the overall likelihood that barriers to local telephone competition will be substantially reduced or removed.
75679_13_ITEM1_P112_S1	These initiatives include requirements that ILECs negotiate with entities, including us, to provide interconnection to the existing local telephone network, to allow the purchase, at cost-based rates, of access to UNEs, to establish dialing parity, to obtain access to rights-of-way and to resell services offered by the ILEC.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S0	We have been able to obtain interconnection, access and related services from the ILECs, at rates that allow us to offer competitive services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S1	However, if we are unable to continue to obtain these services and access at acceptable rates, our ability to offer local access services, and our revenues and net income, could be materially adversely affected.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S2	To date, we have been successful in capturing a significant portion of the local telephone market in the locations where we are offering these services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S3	However, there can be no assurance that we will continue to be successful in attracting or retaining these customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S4	In addition, wireless and VoIP services continue to grow as an alternative to wireline services as a means of reaching customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S5	Wireless local number portability allows consumers to retain the same phone number as they change service providers allowing for interchangeable and portable fixed-line and wireless numbers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P113_S6	A growing number of consumers now use wireless service as their primary voice phone service for local calling.
75679_13_ITEM1_P114_S0	The long-distance industry is intensely competitive, with service offerings based upon price and bundling.
75679_13_ITEM1_P115_S0	In the intrastate, interstate and international long-distance market, we compete against ACS, MTA, long-distance resellers, and certain smaller rural local telephone companies.
75679_13_ITEM1_P115_S1	There is also the possibility that new competitors will enter the Alaska market.
75679_13_ITEM1_P116_S0	In addition, wireless and voice over Internet protocol ("VoIP") services continue to grow as an alternative to wireline services as a means of reaching customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P116_S1	Wireless local number portability allows consumers to retain the same phone number as they change service providers allowing for interchangeable and portable fixed-line and wireless numbers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P116_S2	A growing number of consumers now use wireless service as their primary voice phone service for long-distance calling.
75679_13_ITEM1_P117_S0	We have competed in the long-distance market by offering discounts from rates charged by our competitors and by providing desirable bundles of services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P118_S0	Our ability to compete successfully will depend on our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry, including new services that may be introduced, changes in consumer preferences, demographic trends, economic conditions and pricing strategies.
75679_13_ITEM1_P119_S0	We believe that we have certain advantages over ILECs in providing communications services, including awareness by Alaskan customers of the GCI brand name, our facilities-based communications network, and our prior experience in, and knowledge of, the Alaskan market.
75679_13_ITEM1_P120_S0	See Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products below for more information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P121_S0	Our Consumer segment services and products do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P121_S1	Our ability to implement construction projects is hampered during the winter months because of cold temperatures, snow and short daylight hours.
75679_13_ITEM1_P122_S0	Network Access segment revenues for 2012, 2011 and 2010 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands ):
75679_13_ITEM1_P123_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Network Access segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P124_S0	Our Network Access segment offers wholesale wireless, data and voice services and products to other common carrier customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P124_S1	We provide network transport, billing services and access to our network to other common carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P124_S2	These services allow other common carriers to provide services to their customers that originate or terminate on our network, or on the networks of other communication companies to which we connect.
75679_13_ITEM1_P125_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment wireless services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $26.8 million, $19.4 million, and $16.7 million, respectively, or 4%, 3%, and 3% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_13_ITEM1_P126_S0	We provide roaming services on our wireless network within Alaska to other GSM and CDMA wireless carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P127_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment data services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $56.2 million, $62.5 million, and $61.5 million, respectively, or 8%, 9%, and 9% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_13_ITEM1_P128_S0	Data network services include MPLS, frame relay, private line and dedicated Internet service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P129_S0	Revenues derived from Network Access segment voice services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $22.5 million, $23.6 million, and $29.0 million, respectively, or 3%, 3%, and 4% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_13_ITEM1_P130_S0	We are engaged in the transmission of interstate and intrastate-switched message telephone service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P130_S1	We terminate northbound message telephone service traffic for several large resellers who do not have facilities of their own in Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P130_S2	We also provide origination of southbound calling card, toll-free services, and toll services for interexchange carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P130_S3	Services are generally provided pursuant to contracts.
75679_13_ITEM1_P131_S0	Our Network Access segment sales and marketing efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of other common carriers we serve, the number of billable minutes of wireless and long-distance traffic, and the number of billable megabytes of wireless data traffic we carry over our network and the number of voice and data transmission circuits leased.
75679_13_ITEM1_P131_S1	We sell our voice, data and wireless services primarily through direct contact marketing.
75679_13_ITEM1_P132_S0	Our Network Access segment shares common facilities used for wireless, data and voice services by other segments.
75679_13_ITEM1_P132_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P133_S0	We had no major customer in 2012, 2011 or 2010.
75679_13_ITEM1_P134_S0	Our Network Access segment competes against AT T Alascom, ACS, and certain smaller rural local telephone carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P134_S1	There is also the possibility that new competitors will enter the Alaska market.
75679_13_ITEM1_P135_S0	Other common carrier traffic routed to us for termination in Alaska is largely dependent on traffic routed to our carrier customers by their customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P135_S1	Pricing pressures, new program offerings, revised business plans, and market consolidation continue to evolve in the markets served by our carrier customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P135_S2	If, as a result, their traffic is reduced, or if their competitors costs to terminate or originate traffic in Alaska are reduced, our traffic will also likely be reduced, and we may have to respond to competitive pressures.
75679_13_ITEM1_P135_S3	We are unable to predict the effect of such changes on our business.
75679_13_ITEM1_P136_S0	Historically, we have competed in the Network Access segment market by offering rates comparable to or less than our competitors, by providing a comprehensive service model to meet the complete needs of our carrier customers, and by providing responsive customer service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P137_S0	Another carrier operates a pair of fiber optic cable facilities connecting points in Alaska to the lower 48 states.
75679_13_ITEM1_P137_S1	This additional fiber system provides direct competition to services we provide on our owned fiber optic cable facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P138_S0	Network Access segment long-distance and wireless services revenues derived from our other common carrier customers have historically been highest in the summer months because of temporary population increases attributable to tourism and increased seasonal economic activity such as construction, commercial fishing, and oil and gas activities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P138_S1	Our Network Access segment data services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P139_S0	We offer a full range of communications services and products to commercial and governmental customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P139_S1	Commercial segment revenues for 2012, 2011 and 2010 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands):
75679_13_ITEM1_P140_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Commercial segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P141_S0	Our Commercial segment offers a full range of wireless, data, video and voice services and products to local, national and global businesses, governmental entities, and public and private educational institutions.
75679_13_ITEM1_P142_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment wireless services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $9.9 million, $9.8 million, and $8.7 million, respectively, or 1% of our total revenues for each year.
75679_13_ITEM1_P143_S0	Wireless services and products offered to our Commercial segment customers are the same as those described in the Consumer Wireless Services and Products section above.
75679_13_ITEM1_P143_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P144_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment data services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $93.4 million, $86.0 million, and $76.8 million, respectively, or 13%, 13% and 12% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_13_ITEM1_P145_S0	We currently offer several Internet service packages for commercial use.
75679_13_ITEM1_P145_S1	Our business high-speed cable modem Internet service offers access of up to 50 Mbps download and 5 Mbps upload speeds, and free 24-hour customer service and technical support.
75679_13_ITEM1_P145_S2	We also provide dedicated Internet access service to commercial and public organizations in Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P146_S0	Data network services utilize voice and data transmission circuits, dedicated to particular subscribers, which link a device in one location to another in a different location.
75679_13_ITEM1_P146_S1	Private IP, private lines, metro Ethernet and frame relay offer a secure solution for frequent communication of large amounts of data between sites.
75679_13_ITEM1_P147_S0	We design, sell, install, service and operate, on behalf of certain customers, communications and computer networking equipment and provide field/depot, third party, technical support, communications consulting and outsourcing services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P147_S1	We supply integrated voice and data communications systems incorporating private IP, interstate and intrastate digital data networks, point-to-point and multipoint data network and small earth station services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P147_S2	In 2012 we began offering hosting services to customers wishing to have data-center technology in a secure location with redundant space, power and bandwidth.
75679_13_ITEM1_P148_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment video services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $12.8 million, $11.6 million, and $11.2 million, respectively, or 2% of our total revenues for each year.
75679_13_ITEM1_P149_S0	Commercial segment subscribers such as hospitals, hotels and motels are charged negotiated monthly service fees.
75679_13_ITEM1_P150_S0	Our video on demand platform is available to hotels in Anchorage that are connected using our fiber facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P151_S0	Programming services offered to our video systems subscribers differ by system as described in the Consumer segment Video Services and Products section above.
75679_13_ITEM1_P151_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P152_S0	Commercial segment also manages our advertising sales.
75679_13_ITEM1_P152_S1	As part of our programming license agreements with programming networks, we generally receive an allocation of scheduled advertising time that we may sell to local, regional and national advertisers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P152_S2	In most cases, the available advertising time is sold by our sales force.
75679_13_ITEM1_P153_S0	Revenues derived from Commercial segment voice services and products in 2012, 2011, and 2010 totaled $27.4 million, $28.7 million, and $31.7 million, respectively, or 4%, 4% and 5% of our total revenues, respectively.
75679_13_ITEM1_P154_S0	We are engaged in the transmission of interstate and intrastate-switched message telephone service between the major communities in Alaska, the remaining 49 states, and foreign countries.
75679_13_ITEM1_P154_S1	Our message toll services include intrastate, interstate and international direct dial, toll-free services, calling card, operator and enhanced conference calling services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P154_S2	Small business subscribers generally may cancel long-distance service at any time.
75679_13_ITEM1_P154_S3	Certain small business and most large business, governmental and educational institution customers generally contract with us for service over one to five year periods.
75679_13_ITEM1_P155_S0	We offer full featured local access service to our Commercial segment customers using our own fiber and coax facilities and collocated remote facilities that access the ILEC s UNE loops and wholesale facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P155_S1	In areas where we do not have our own facilities or access to ILEC loop facilities, we offer service using total service resale of the ILEC s local service or UNE platform.
75679_13_ITEM1_P156_S0	Our package offerings are competitively priced and include popular features, including caller ID, voice messaging, three-way calling, call forwarding, and call waiting.
75679_13_ITEM1_P157_S0	Small business subscribers generally may cancel local access service at any time.
75679_13_ITEM1_P158_S0	Certain small business and most large business, governmental and educational institution customers generally contract with us for service over one to five year periods.
75679_13_ITEM1_P159_S0	We combine one or more of our individual service or product offerings into bundles that we sell to our Commercial segment customers at attractive prices as described further in the Consumer segment Services and Products section above.
75679_13_ITEM1_P159_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Services and Products above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P159_S2	Additionally, we use master service agreements with larger enterprise customers to capture the overall relationship.
75679_13_ITEM1_P160_S0	Our Commercial segment sales and marketing efforts focus on increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P160_S1	We sell our Commercial segment services and products primarily through direct contact marketing.
75679_13_ITEM1_P161_S0	Our Commercial segment uses many facilities to provide services and products that are common to the Consumer segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P161_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P162_S0	We provide our own facilities-based local access services to many of Anchorage s larger business customers through expansion and deployment of SONET, optical ethernet, and passive optical network fiber transmission facilities, digital loop carrier facilities, and leased facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P163_S0	Our dedicated Internet access and Internet protocol/MPLS data services are delivered to an Ethernet port located at the service point.
75679_13_ITEM1_P163_S1	Our management platform constantly monitors this port and continual communications are maintained with all of the core and distribution elements in the network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P163_S2	The availability and quality of service, as well as statistical information on traffic loading, are continuously monitored for quality assurance.
75679_13_ITEM1_P164_S0	The manage ment platform has the capability to remotely access routers, servers and layer two switches, permitting changes in configuration without the need to physically be at the service point.
75679_13_ITEM1_P164_S1	This management platform allows us to offer network monitoring and management services to businesses and governmental entities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P164_S2	Many of the largest commercial networks in Alaska use this service, including the State of Alaska government.
75679_13_ITEM1_P165_S0	Beginning in 2012 we provide a hosting center in Alaska designed to support the emerging trends in virtualized servers and cloud-based systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P165_S1	Our Data Services Center brings data-center technologies and services together by offering space, power and bandwidth in a redundant and secure location.
75679_13_ITEM1_P166_S0	Many of our Commercial segment wireless, data, video and voice services and products are also common to the Consumer segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P166_S1	You should refer to Consumer Segment Competition above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P167_S0	We expect continued competition in commercial customer wireless, data, Internet access and telephone access markets.
75679_13_ITEM1_P168_S0	Competition is based upon price and pricing plans, the type of services offered, customer service, billing services, performance, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_13_ITEM1_P169_S0	Presently, there are a number of competing companies in Alaska that actively sell and maintain data and voice communications systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P169_S1	Our ability to integrate communications networks and data communications equipment has allowed us to maintain our market position based on customer support services rather than price competition alone.
75679_13_ITEM1_P169_S2	These services are blended with other transport products into unique customer solutions, including managed services and outsourcing.
75679_13_ITEM1_P170_S0	Our Commercial segment wireless, data, video, and voice services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P170_S1	Our ability to implement construction projects to expand our outside plant facilities is hampered during the winter months because of cold temperatures, snow and short daylight hours.
75679_13_ITEM1_P171_S0	Managed Broadband segment revenues for 2012, 2011 and 2010 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands):
75679_13_ITEM1_P172_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Managed Broadband segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P173_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment offers Internet access, data network and managed services to rural schools and health organizations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P174_S0	SchoolAccess is a suite of services designed to advance the educational opportunities of students in underserved regions of the country.
75679_13_ITEM1_P174_S1	Our SchoolAccess division provides Internet and distance learning services designed exclusively for the school environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P174_S2	The Schools and Libraries Program of the USF makes discounts available to eligible rural school districts for telecommunication services and monthly Internet service charges.
75679_13_ITEM1_P174_S3	The program is intended to ensure that rural school districts have access to affordable services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P175_S0	Our network, Internet and software application services provided through our Managed Broadband segment s Medical Services division are branded as ConnectMD .
75679_13_ITEM1_P176_S0	The Rural Health Care Program of the USF makes discounts available to eligible rural health care providers for telecommunication services and monthly Internet service charges.
75679_13_ITEM1_P176_S1	The program is intended to ensure that rural health care providers pay no more for telecommunication services in the provision of health care services than their urban counterparts.
75679_13_ITEM1_P177_S0	Customers utilize ConnectMD services to securely move data and images, and for voice traffic and real time multipoint interactive video.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S0	We offer a managed video conferencing product for use in distance learning, telemedicine and group communication and collaboration environments.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S1	The product is designed to offer customers enhanced communication services that support video, audio and data presentation.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S2	Our product benefits customers by reducing travel costs, improving course equity in education and increasing the quality of health services available to patients.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S3	The product bundles our data products, video conferencing services and optional rental of video conferencing endpoint equipment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S4	Our video conferencing services include multipoint conferencing, integrated services digital network gateway and transcoding services, online scheduling and conference control, and videoconference recording, archiving and streaming.
75679_13_ITEM1_P178_S5	We provide 24-hour technical support via telephone or online.
75679_13_ITEM1_P179_S0	Our videoconferencing network is the largest in Alaska with additional sites in several other states .
75679_13_ITEM1_P179_S1	The network supports all H.323 IP videoconferencing standards including the newer H.264 standard, and supports call data rates from 128 Kb per second up to and including multi-megabit high definition calls.
75679_13_ITEM1_P180_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment sales and marketing efforts focus on increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P180_S1	We sell our Managed Broadband segment services and products primarily through direct contact marketing followed by competitive bidding.
75679_13_ITEM1_P181_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment services and products are delivered using a platform including many of the latest advancements in technology through a locally available circuit, our existing lines, and/or satellite earth stations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P181_S1	Our Internet services are partially provisioned over a satellite based digital video broadcast carrier that reduces the requirement for new satellite transponder bandwidth to support growth in ConnectMD , SchoolAccess and other broadband services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P182_S0	We employ a packet data satellite transmission technology for the efficient transport of broadband data in support of our ConnectMD and SchoolAccess initiatives.
75679_13_ITEM1_P182_S1	Our SchoolAccess Internet service is delivered as follows:
75679_13_ITEM1_P183_S0	In communities where we have terrestrial interconnects or provide existing service over regional earth stations, we have configured intermediate distribution facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P184_S0	In communities or remote locations to which we have not extended communications services, SchoolAccess is provided via a dedicated (usually on premise) very small aperture terminal ("VSAT") satellite station.
75679_13_ITEM1_P184_S1	The VSAT connects to an intermediate distribution facility located in Anchorage.
75679_13_ITEM1_P185_S0	Our facilities include TERRA-SW, a middle mile long haul broadband network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P185_S1	TERRA-SW provides terrestrial telecommunication service to 65 remote rural Alaska communities located in southwest Alaska through a hybrid microwave and fiber optic network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P185_S2	TERRA-SW includes 395 miles of fiber optic cable stretching from Homer, Alaska to Levelock , Alaska, microwave towers in certain communities and four remote mountaintop microwave repeaters.
75679_13_ITEM1_P185_S3	We utilize TERRA-SW to support growth in wireless and broadband services including ConnectMD and SchoolAccess .
75679_13_ITEM1_P186_S0	You should refer to Consumer Segment Facilities above for additional information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P187_S0	There are several competing companies in Alaska that actively sell broadband services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P187_S1	Our ability to provide end-to-end broadband services solutions has allowed us to maintain our market position based on value added services and products rather than solely based on price competition.
75679_13_ITEM1_P187_S2	These services are blended with other transport and software products into unique customer solutions, including SchoolAccess and ConnectMD applications such as video conferencing and unique web content services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P188_S0	Our Managed Broadband segment does not exhibit seasonality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P189_S0	Regulated Operations segment revenues for 2012, 2011 and 2010 are summarized as follows (amounts in thousands):
75679_13_ITEM1_P190_S0	1 See Part II Item 7 Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and note 10 included in Part II Item 8 Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data for more information regarding the financial performance of our Regulated Operations segment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P191_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment offers wireline communications services , including local access and long-distance, to our residential and commercial customers in 61 rural communities primarily in Southwest Alaska, under our United Utilities, Inc. ( UUI ) and United-KUC, Inc. ( United-KUC ) brands.
75679_13_ITEM1_P192_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment sales efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of subscribers we serve.
75679_13_ITEM1_P192_S1	We sell our Regulated Operations segment services through local media advertising, retail stores, and through our website.
75679_13_ITEM1_P193_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment services are delivered by switching, outside plant, terrestrial microwave, and satellite facilities.
75679_13_ITEM1_P193_S1	Our outside plant is primarily aerial and buried copper and fiber optic cables.
75679_13_ITEM1_P194_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment s competition results from a growing number of consumers using wireless service as the primary source for their voice phone service .
75679_13_ITEM1_P194_S1	However, the only wireless provider in their service area is ourselves, and thus the competition source is internal as our Consumer and Commercial segment subscriber revenue replaces Regulated Operations segment subscriber revenue.
75679_13_ITEM1_P195_S0	Our Regulated Operations segment services do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_13_ITEM1_P196_S0	Our sales and marketing strategy hinges on our ability to leverage (i) our unique position as an integrated provider of multiple communications, Internet and video services, (ii) our well-recognized and respected brand names in the Alaskan marketplace and (iii) our leading market positions in the services and products we offer.
75679_13_ITEM1_P196_S1	By continuing to pursue a marketing strategy that takes advantage of these characteristics, we believe we can increase our customer market penetration and retention rates, increase our share of our customers aggregate voice, video, data and wireless services expenditures and achieve continued growth in revenues and operating cash flow.
75679_13_ITEM1_P197_S0	We may undertake activities that, under certain circumstances, may affect the environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P197_S1	Accordingly, they are subject to federal, state, and local regulations designed to preserve or protect the environment, including the Clean Water Act and the Clean Air Act.
75679_13_ITEM1_P198_S0	The FCC, Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Forest Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and National Park Service are among the federal agencies required by the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 to consider the environmental impact of actions they authorize, including facility construction.
75679_13_ITEM1_P199_S0	We believe that compliance with such regulations has had no material effect on our consolidated operations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P199_S1	The principal effect of our facilities on the environment would be in the form of construction of facilities and networks at various locations in Alaska and between Alaska, Seattle, Washington, and Warrenton, Oregon.
75679_13_ITEM1_P199_S2	Our facilities have been constructed in accordance with federal, state and local building codes and zoning regulations whenever and wherever applicable.
75679_13_ITEM1_P199_S3	Some facilities may be on wetlands that may be subject to state and/or federal regulation.
75679_13_ITEM1_P200_S0	Most of our facilities are on leased property, and, with respect to all of these facilities, we are unaware of any violations of lease terms or federal, state or local regulations pertaining to preservation or protection of the environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P201_S0	The engineered routes of our projects to construct terrestrial and undersea fiber optic cable facilities pass over wetlands and other environmentally sensitive areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P201_S1	We believe our construction methods used for buried cable have a minimal impact on the environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P201_S2	The agencies, among others, that are involved in permitting and oversight of our cable deployment efforts are the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, National Marine Fisheries Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Coast Guard, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and the Alaska Department of Natural Resources.
75679_13_ITEM1_P201_S3	We are unaware of any violations of federal, state or local regulations or permits pertaining to preservation or protection of the environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P202_S0	In the course of operating our video and communications systems, we have used various materials defined as hazardous by applicable governmental regulations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P202_S1	These materials have been used for insect repellent, paint used to mark the location of our facilities, and pole treatment, and as heating fuel, transformer oil, cable cleaner, batteries, diesel fuel, and in various other ways in the operation of those systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P202_S2	We do not believe that these materials, when used in accordance with manufacturer instructions, pose an unreasonable hazard to those who use them or to the environment.
75679_13_ITEM1_P202_S3	Where present at levels above applicable thresholds, we submit annual reports detailing hazardous substance quantities and locations to emergency responders under the Emergency Planning Community Right-to-Know Act.
75679_13_ITEM1_P203_S0	Our construction activities and operations include transporting fuel via helicopter to remote locations within Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P203_S1	To any extent not covered by our insurance or that of our contractors, we could incur cleanup costs and third-party claims for property damage if fuel were to be released to underlying lands or water while in flight.
75679_13_ITEM1_P203_S2	New laws and regulations, more stringent enforcement of existing laws and regulations, or the discovery of previously unknown contamination could result in additional costs.
75679_13_ITEM1_P204_S0	We do not hold patents, franchises (with the exception of video services as described below) or concessions for communications services or local access services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P204_S1	We do hold federally registered service marks, used by each of our reportable segments, for the marks GCI , SchoolAccess , Alaska United Fiber Optic Cable System , GCI ConnectMD , ConnectMD , GCI Hypernet , My GCI , MyGCI , Keep Talking Alaska , Unicom , and United-KUC .
75679_13_ITEM1_P204_S2	The original deadline to renew the registration for the mark Unicom for a new 10-year term has expired; however, the registration is in a grace period and our intention is to renew the registration before the end of the grace period.
75679_13_ITEM1_P204_S3	We also own two pending applications to register the mark GCI TurboZone.
75679_13_ITEM1_P204_S4	Both applications have been approved for publication.
75679_13_ITEM1_P205_S0	The Communications Act of 1934, as amended, gives the FCC the authority to license and regulate the use of the electromagnetic spectrum for radio communications.
75679_13_ITEM1_P206_S0	We hold licenses through our subsidiary GCI Communication Corp. ( GCICC ) for our satellite and microwave transmission facilities for provision of long-distance services provided by our Consumer, Commercial and Network Access segments.
75679_13_ITEM1_P207_S0	We hold the following licenses, among others:
75679_13_ITEM1_P208_S0	Two licenses for use of a 30 MHz block of spectrum, which together authorize provision of PCS services in Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P208_S1	Both licenses have an expiration date of June 23, 2015.
75679_13_ITEM1_P208_S2	Licenses may be revoked and license renewal applications may be denied for cause.
75679_13_ITEM1_P209_S0	A local multipoint distribution system ("LMDS") license which we acquired in 1998 for use of a 150 MHz block of spectrum in the 28 GHz Ka-band for providing wireless services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P209_S1	The LMDS license was renewed in 2008 for an additional 10-year term, following the grant of an extension until June 1, 2012, of the requirement to provide substantial service in the service region.
75679_13_ITEM1_P209_S2	We timely satisfied this condition, as reflected in the required FCC filing on June 1, 2012.
75679_13_ITEM1_P210_S0	Several 25 MHz cellular B licenses are held by our subsidiary Unicom for sites located in the Wade Hampton AK-1 portion of CMA 315 and the Bethel AK-2 portion of CMA 316, and operated by GCICC pursuant to a de facto long-term spectrum lease.
75679_13_ITEM1_P211_S0	Earth stations are licensed generally for fifteen years.
75679_13_ITEM1_P211_S1	The FCC also issues a single blanket license for a large number of technically identical earth stations (e.g., VSATs).
75679_13_ITEM1_P211_S2	Our operations may require additional licenses in the future.
75679_13_ITEM1_P212_S0	We are certified through the RCA to provide video service by Certificates of Public Convenience and Necessity ( CPCN ).
75679_13_ITEM1_P212_S1	These CPCNs are nonexclusive certificates issued for each community.
75679_13_ITEM1_P212_S2	Although CPCNs have no stated expiration date, they may be revoked due to cause.
75679_13_ITEM1_P213_S0	Our businesses are subject to substantial government regulation and oversight.
75679_13_ITEM1_P213_S1	The following summary of regulatory issues does not purport to describe all existing and proposed federal, state, and local laws and regulations, or judicial and regulatory proceedings that affect our businesses.
75679_13_ITEM1_P213_S2	Existing laws and regulations are reviewed frequently by legislative bodies, regulatory agencies, and the courts and are subject to change.
75679_13_ITEM1_P213_S3	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of any present or future consideration of proposed changes to governing laws and regulations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P214_S0	The FCC regulates the licensing, construction, interconnection, operation, acquisition, and transfer of wireless network systems in the United States pursuant to the Communications Act.
75679_13_ITEM1_P214_S1	As a licensee of PCS, LMDS, and other wireless services, we are subject to regulation by the FCC, and must comply with certain build-out and other license conditions, as well as with the FCC s specific regulations governing wireless services, including the PCS and LMDS services (as discussed above in the Patents, Trademarks and Licenses section of this Item 1).
75679_13_ITEM1_P215_S0	The FCC does not currently regulate rates for services offered by commercial mobile radio service providers (the official legal description for wireless service providers).
75679_13_ITEM1_P216_S0	Commercial mobile radio service wireless systems are subject to Federal Aviation Administration and FCC regulations governing the location, lighting, construction, and registration of antenna structures on which our antennas and associated equipment are located and are also subject to regulation under federal environmental laws and the FCC s environmental regulations, including limits on radio frequency radiation from wireless handsets and antennas on towers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P217_S0	The USF pays Eligible Telecommunications Carriers ("ETCs") to support the provision of facilities-based wireless telephone service in high cost areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P217_S1	A wireless carrier may seek ETC status so that it can receive support from the USF.
75679_13_ITEM1_P217_S2	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireless telephone service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, and the MTA study area (which includes the Matanuska-Susitna Valley) and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P217_S3	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireless telephone services, and our net cost of providing wireless telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S0	On November 29, 2011, the FCC published a final rule to reform the methodology for distributing USF high cost support for voice and broadband services, as well as to the access charge regime for terminating traffic between carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S1	Support for competitive eligible telecommunications carriers ( CETCs ) serving areas that generally include Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau followed national reforms and had support per provider per service area capped as of January 1, 2012, and a five-step phase-down commenced on July 1, 2012.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S2	In addition to broader reforms, the FCC tailored revisions specifically for CETCs serving Remote Alaska, intended to address the unique challenges for serving these areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S3	Support to these locations is capped and distributed on a per-line basis until the later of July 1, 2014, or the implementation of a successor funding mechanism.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S4	A further rulemaking to consider successor funding mechanisms is underway.
75679_13_ITEM1_P218_S5	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of this proceeding or its effect on Remote high cost support available to us, but our revenue for providing local services in these areas would be materially adversely affected by a substantial reduction of USF support.
75679_13_ITEM1_P219_S0	On February 6, 2012, the FCC released its Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking to comprehensively reform and modernize the USF s Lifeline program.
75679_13_ITEM1_P220_S0	The Lifeline program is administered by the USAC and is designed to ensure that quality telecommunications services are available to low-income customers at just, reasonable, and affordable rates.
75679_13_ITEM1_P220_S1	The order adopted several reforms, but the only reform with a significant 2012 impact was a requirement for annual recertification of all Lifeline subscribers enrolled as of June 1, 2012 to be completed by the end of 2012.
75679_13_ITEM1_P220_S2	In an order released on December 27, 2012, the FCC s Wireline Competition Bureau granted GCI a waiver to permit early recertification of subscribers (those recertified prior to June 1, 2012), subject to the condition that certain address information be verified for a subset of those subscribers by January 31, 2013.
75679_13_ITEM1_P221_S0	We have completed negotiation and the RCA has approved current direct wireless interconnection agreements between GCI and all of the major Alaska ILECs.
75679_13_ITEM1_P221_S1	These are in addition to indirect interconnection arrangements utilized elsewhere.
75679_13_ITEM1_P222_S0	See Description of Our Business by Reportable Segment Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products Universal Service and Regulatory Regime Applicable to IP-based Networks for more information.
75679_13_ITEM1_P223_S0	The FCC has imposed rules requiring carriers to provide emergency 911 services, including enhanced 911 ( E911 ) services that provide to local public safety dispatch agencies the caller s phone number and approximate location.
75679_13_ITEM1_P224_S0	Providers are required to transmit the geographic coordinates of the customer s location, either by means of network-based or handset-based technologies, within accuracy parameters recently revised by the FCC, to be implemented over a phase-in period.
75679_13_ITEM1_P225_S0	Due to Alaska s relatively low population and low cell-site densities, we have excluded certain areas from E911 coverage where cell triangulation is not feasible, pursuant to FCC rule.
75679_13_ITEM1_P225_S1	We have also filed for a waiver, which remains pending, for remaining areas where triangulation may be technically feasible, but where the cell-site densities are insufficient to reach the FCC s standard.
75679_13_ITEM1_P226_S0	Providers may not demand cost recovery as a condition of providing E911, although they are permitted to negotiate cost recovery if it is not mandated by the state or local governments.
75679_13_ITEM1_P227_S0	While the Communications Act generally preempts state and local governments from regulating the entry of, and the rates charged by, wireless carriers, it also permits a state to petition the FCC to allow it to impose commercial mobile radio service rate regulation when market conditions fail to adequately protect customers and such service is a replacement for a substantial portion of the telephone wireline exchange service within a state.
75679_13_ITEM1_P227_S1	No state currently has such a petition on file, and all prior efforts have been rejected.
75679_13_ITEM1_P227_S2	In addition, the Communications Act does not expressly preempt the states from regulating the terms and conditions of wireless service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P228_S0	Several states have invoked this terms and conditions authority to impose or propose various consumer protection regulations on the wireless industry.
75679_13_ITEM1_P228_S1	State attorneys general have also become more active in enforcing state consumer protection laws against sales practices and services of wireless carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P228_S2	States also may impose their own universal service support requirements on wireless and other communications carriers, similar to the contribution requirements that have been established by the FCC.
75679_13_ITEM1_P229_S0	States have become more active in attempting to impose new taxes and fees on wireless carriers, such as gross receipts taxes.
75679_13_ITEM1_P229_S1	Where successful, these taxes and fees are generally passed through to our customers and result in higher costs to our customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P230_S0	At the local level, wireless facilities typically are subject to zoning and land use regulation.
75679_13_ITEM1_P230_S1	Neither local nor state governments may categorically prohibit the construction of wireless facilities in any community or take actions, such as indefinite moratoria, which have the effect of prohibiting construction.
75679_13_ITEM1_P230_S2	Nonetheless, securing state and local government approvals for new tower sites has been and is likely to continue to be difficult, lengthy and costly.
75679_13_ITEM1_P231_S0	There is no one entity or organization that governs the Internet.
75679_13_ITEM1_P231_S1	Each facilities-based network provider that is interconnected with the global Internet controls operational aspects of their own network.
75679_13_ITEM1_P231_S2	Certain functions, such as IP addressing, domain name routing, and the definition of the TCP/IP protocol, are coordinated by an array of quasi-governmental, intergovernmental, and non-governmental bodies.
75679_13_ITEM1_P231_S3	The legal authority of these bodies is not precisely defined.
75679_13_ITEM1_P232_S0	Although the FCC does not regulate the prices charged by Internet service providers or Internet backbone providers, the vast majority of users connect to the Internet over facilities of existing communications carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P232_S1	Those communications carriers are subject to varying levels of regulation at both the federal and state level.
75679_13_ITEM1_P232_S2	Thus, non-Internet-specific regulatory decisions exercise a significant influence over the economics of the Internet market.
75679_13_ITEM1_P233_S0	Many aspects of the coordination and regulation of Internet activities and the underlying networks over which those activities are conducted are evolving.
75679_13_ITEM1_P233_S1	Internet-specific and non-Internet-specific changes in the regulatory environment, including changes that affect communications costs or increase competition from ILECs or other communications services providers, could adversely affect the prices at which we sell Internet-based services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P234_S0	On November 20, 2011, the FCC issued rules governing the activities of cable operators and other Internet service providers in connection with the provision of Internet service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P234_S1	The rules generally prohibit blocking lawful content and prohibiting unreasonable discrimination, outside of reasonable network management, as well as imposing transparency and related disclosure requirements.
75679_13_ITEM1_P234_S2	We do not believe at this time that these requirements represent significant federal regulation of cable system delivery of Internet services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P234_S3	In addition, these rules are subject to court appeals.
75679_13_ITEM1_P235_S0	Further legislative proposals under the banner of net neutrality, if adopted, could interfere with our ability to reasonably manage and invest in our broadband network, and could adversely affect the manner and price of providing service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P236_S0	Because video communications systems use local streets and rights-of-way, they generally are operated pursuant to franchises (which can take the form of certificates, permits or licenses) granted by a municipality or other state or local government entity.
75679_13_ITEM1_P237_S0	The RCA is the franchising authority for all of Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P237_S1	We believe that we have generally met the terms of our franchises, which do not require periodic renewal, and have provided quality levels of service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P237_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide video services to military bases.
75679_13_ITEM1_P238_S0	The RCA is also certified under federal law to regulate rates for the Basic Service tier on our video systems.
75679_13_ITEM1_P238_S1	Under state law, however, video service is exempt from regulation unless subscribers petition the RCA.
75679_13_ITEM1_P238_S2	At present, regulation of basic video rates takes place only in Juneau.
75679_13_ITEM1_P239_S0	The RCA does not regulate rates for cable modem service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P240_S0	The 1992 Cable Act contains broadcast signal carriage requirements that allow local commercial television broadcast stations to elect once every three years to require a cable system to carry the station, subject to certain exceptions, or to negotiate for retransmission consent to carry the station.
75679_13_ITEM1_P241_S0	The FCC has adopted rules to require cable operators to carry the digital programming streams of broadcast television stations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P241_S1	The FCC requirement that cable operators carry both the analog and digital programming streams of broadcast television stations while broadcasters are transitioning from analog to digital transmission does not apply to all-digital systems like ours.
75679_13_ITEM1_P241_S2	Further, the FCC has declined to require any cable operator to carry multiple digital programming streams from a single broadcast television station, but should the FCC change this policy, we would be required to devote additional cable capacity to carrying broadcast television programming streams, a step that could require the removal of other programming services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P242_S0	Cable System Delivery of Internet Service.
75679_13_ITEM1_P242_S1	The FCC has defined high-speed Internet over cable as an information service not subject to local cable franchise fees, as video service may be, or any explicit requirements for open access.
75679_13_ITEM1_P242_S2	The Supreme Court affirmed the FCC s position in a decision issued in 2005.
75679_13_ITEM1_P243_S0	Although there is at present no significant federal regulation of cable system delivery of Internet services, proposals previously have been advanced at the FCC and before Congress to require cable operators to provide access to unaffiliated Internet service providers and online service providers and to govern the terms under which content providers and applications are delivered by all broadband network operators.
75679_13_ITEM1_P243_S1	If such requirements were imposed on cable operators, it could burden the capacity of cable systems and frustrate our plans for providing expanded Internet access services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P243_S2	These access obligations could adversely affect our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_13_ITEM1_P244_S0	The FCC mandated, effective July 1, 2007, that all new set-top video navigation devices must segregate the security function from the navigation function.
75679_13_ITEM1_P244_S1	The new devices are more expensive than existing equipment, and compliance would increase our cost of providing video services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P244_S2	Subject to a waiver granted by the FCC on May 4, 2007, we may continue providing low-cost integrated set-top boxes to consumers to facilitate our all-digital cable networks.
75679_13_ITEM1_P245_S0	On April 21, 2010, the FCC adopted a Notice of Inquiry to consider ways to develop a standardized interface for accessing video content, as an alternative to set-top boxes.
75679_13_ITEM1_P245_S1	Adoption of new rules or standards in this area could affect the manner in which we deliver video products to our customers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P245_S2	We do not know if the FCC will propose rules for further consideration.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S0	The Communications Act requires the FCC to regulate the rates, terms and conditions imposed by public utilities for cable systems use of utility pole and conduit space unless state authorities can demonstrate that they adequately regulate pole attachment rates.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S1	In the absence of state regulation, the FCC administers pole attachment rates on a formula basis.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S2	This formula governs the maximum rate certain utilities may charge for attachments to their poles and conduit by companies providing communications services, including cable operators.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S3	The RCA, however, does not use the federal formula and instead has adopted its own formula that has been in place since 1987.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S4	This formula could be subject to further revisions upon petition to the RCA.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S5	In addition, on April 7, 2011, the FCC adopted an order to rationalize different pole attachment rates among types of services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P246_S6	The United States Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit, recently upheld the FCC s rules, denying challenges from several utility companies.
75679_13_ITEM1_P247_S0	Though the general purpose of rule changes was to ensure pole attachment rates as low and as uniform as possible, we do not expect the rules to have an immediate impact on the terms under which we access poles.
75679_13_ITEM1_P248_S0	Cable television systems are subject to federal copyright licensing covering carriage of television and radio broadcast signals.
75679_13_ITEM1_P248_S1	In exchange for filing certain reports and contributing a percentage of their revenues to a federal copyright royalty pool that varies depending on the size of the system, the number of distant broadcast television signals carried, and the location of the cable system, cable operators can obtain blanket permission to retransmit copyrighted material included in broadcast signals.
75679_13_ITEM1_P248_S2	The possible modification or elimination of this compulsory copyright license is the subject of continuing legislative review.
75679_13_ITEM1_P248_S3	We cannot predict the outcome of this legislative review, which could adversely affect our ability to obtain desired broadcast program ming.
75679_13_ITEM1_P249_S0	Copyright clearances for non-broadcast programming services are arranged through private negotiations.
75679_13_ITEM1_P250_S0	As an interexchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the FCC and the RCA as a non-dominant provider of interstate, international, and intrastate long-distance services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P250_S1	As a state-certificated competitive local exchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the RCA and the FCC as a non-dominant provider of local communications services.
75679_13_ITEM1_P250_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide communications services to military bases.
75679_13_ITEM1_P251_S0	The USF pays ETCs to support the provision of facilities-based wireline telephone service in high cost areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P251_S1	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireline local exchange service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, and the MTA study area (which includes the Matanuska-Susitna Valley) and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_13_ITEM1_P251_S2	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireline telephone services, and our net cost of providing local telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S0	On November 29, 2011, the FCC published a final rule to reform the methodology for distributing USF high cost support for voice and broadband services, as well as to the access charge regime for terminating traffic between carriers.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S1	Support for CETCs serving areas that generally include Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau followed national reforms and had support per provider per service area capped as of January 1, 2012, and a five-step phase-down commenced on July 1, 2012.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S2	In addition to broader reforms, the FCC tailored revisions specifically for CETCs serving Remote Alaska, intended to address the unique challenges for serving these areas.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S3	Support to these locations is capped and distributed on a per-line basis until the later of July 1, 2014, or the implementation of a successor funding mechanism.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S4	A further rulemaking to consider successor funding mechanisms is underway.
75679_13_ITEM1_P252_S5	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of this proceeding or its effect on Remote high cost support available to us, but our revenue for providing local services in these areas would be materially adversely affected by a substantial reduction of USF support.
75679_13_ITEM1_P253_S0	On February 6, 2012, the FCC released its Report and Order and Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking to comprehensively reform and modernize the USF s Lifeline program.
75679_13_ITEM1_P254_S0	The Lifeline program is administered by the USAC and is designed to ensure that quality telecommunications services are available to low-income customers at just, reasonable, and affordable rates.
75679_13_ITEM1_P254_S1	The order adopted several reforms, but the only reform with a significant 2012 impact was a requirement for annual recertification of all Lifeline subscribers enrolled as of June 1, 2012 to be completed by the end of 2012.
75679_13_ITEM1_P254_S2	In an order released on December 27, 2012, the FCC s Wireline Competition Bureau granted GCI a waiver to permit early recertification of subscribers (those recertified prior to June 1, 2012), subject to the condition that certain address information be verified for a subset of those subscribers by January 31, 2013.
