75679_18_ITEM1_P12_S2	The exchange ratios were determined based on total consideration of $32.50 per share in respect of each share of existing GCI common stock, comprised of $27.50 per share in GCI Liberty Class A common stock and $5.00 per share in newly issued GCI Liberty Series A Cumulative Redeemable preferred stock, based upon a Liberty Ventures reference price of $43.65 (with no premium paid for shares of GCI Class B common stock) and an initial liquidation price of $25.00 per share of GCI Liberty Series A Cumulative Redeemable preferred stock.
75679_18_ITEM1_P12_S3	The GCI Liberty Series A Cumulative Redeemable preferred stock will accrue dividends at an initial rate of 5% per annum (which would increase to 7% in connection with a future reincorporation of GCI Liberty in Delaware) and will be redeemable upon the 21 st anniversary of the closing.
75679_18_ITEM1_P12_S4	The closing of the Transactions are expected to be consummated on March 9, 2018, subject to the satisfaction of customary closing conditions.
75679_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	You should see Part I Item 1.
75679_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	Business Regulation for additional regulatory developments.
75679_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	We intend to grow the company using the following strategies:
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	Expand Our Product Portfolio and Footprint in Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S1	Throughout our history, we have successfully added and expect to continue to add new products to our product portfolio.
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S2	We have a demonstrated history of new product evaluation, development and deployment for our customers, and we continue to assess revenue-enhancing opportunities that create value for our customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S3	Where feasible and where economic analysis supports geographic expansion of our network coverage, we are currently pursuing or expect to pursue opportunities to increase the scale of our facilities, enhance our ability to serve our existing customers needs and attract new customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S4	Additionally, due to the unique market conditions in Alaska, we, and in some cases our customers, participate in several federal (and to a lesser extent locally) subsidized programs designed to financially support the implementation and purchase of telecommunications services like ours in high cost areas.
75679_18_ITEM1_P15_S5	With these programs we have been able to expand our network into previously undeveloped areas of Alaska and, for the first time, offer comprehensive communications services in many rural parts of the state where we would not otherwise be able to construct facilities within appropriate return-on-investment requirements.
75679_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	We have a history of making and integrating acquisitions of telecommunications providers and other providers of complementary services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our management team will continue to actively pursue and make investments that we believe fit with our strategy and networks and that enhance earnings.
75679_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	We sell new and enhanced services and products to our existing customer base to achieve increased revenues and penetration of our services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P17_S1	Through close coordination of our customer service and sales and marketing efforts, our customer service representatives suggest to our customers other services they can purchase or enhanced versions of services they already purchase.
75679_18_ITEM1_P17_S2	Many calls into our customer service centers or visits into one of our retail stores result in sales of additional services and products.
75679_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	We have positioned ourselves as a customer service leader in the Alaska communications market.
75679_18_ITEM1_P18_S1	We operate our own customer service department and have empowered our customer service representatives to handle most service issues and questions on a single call.
75679_18_ITEM1_P18_S2	We prioritize our customer services to expedite handling of our most valuable customers issues, particularly for our largest commercial customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P18_S3	We believe our integrated approach to customer service, including service set-up, programming various network databases with the customer s information, installation, and ongoing service, allows us to provide a customer experience that fosters customer loyalty.
75679_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	We continue to expand and evolve our integrated network for the delivery of our services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P19_S1	Our bundled strategy and integrated approach to serving our customers creates efficiencies of scale and maximizes network utilization.
75679_18_ITEM1_P19_S2	By offering multiple services, we are better able to leverage our network assets and increase returns on our invested capital.
75679_18_ITEM1_P19_S3	We periodically evaluate our network assets and continually monitor technological developments that we can potentially deploy to increase network efficiency and performance.
75679_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	We operate our business under a single reportable segment.
75679_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	Effective in the first quarter of 2017, we reassessed and reorganized our management and internal reporting structures in order to make our operations more efficient, which triggered an analysis of our reportable segments.
75679_18_ITEM1_P20_S2	As a result of our assessment, we merged our former Wireless and Wireline segments into one operating segment.
75679_18_ITEM1_P20_S3	We realigned our external financial reporting to support this change.
75679_18_ITEM1_P20_S4	Our chief operating decision maker assesses our financial performance as follows:
75679_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	Prior to 2017, we operated our business under two reportable segments - Wireline and Wireless.
75679_18_ITEM1_P21_S1	As a result of the reorganization of our reporting structure, assets, including goodwill, and liabilities were reassigned to a single reporting unit.
75679_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	Services and Products We offer services and products to two major customer groups as follows:
75679_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	Consumer - We offer a full range of retail wireless, data, video, and voice services to residential customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P24_S0	Business - We offer a full range of wireless, data, video, voice, and managed services to businesses, governmental entities, and educational institutions, wholesale data, voice, and wireless services to common carrier customers, and regulated voice services to residential and commercial customers in rural communities primarily in Southwest Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P25_S0	Sales and Marketing We offer our services directly to consumer and business customers through our call center, direct mail advertising, television advertising, Internet advertising, local media advertising, and through our retail stores.
75679_18_ITEM1_P25_S1	Our sales efforts are primarily directed toward increasing the number of subscribers we serve, selling bundled services, and generating incremental revenues through product and feature up-sell opportunities.
75679_18_ITEM1_P25_S2	We sell our managed services, wholesale data, voice, and wireless services, and data services to rural schools and health organizations through direct contact marketing.
75679_18_ITEM1_P26_S0	Our sales and marketing strategy hinges on our ability to leverage (i) our unique position as an integrated provider of multiple communications, data and video services, (ii) our well-recognized and respected brand names in the Alaskan marketplace and (iii) our leading market positions in the services and products we offer.
75679_18_ITEM1_P26_S1	By continuing to pursue a marketing strategy that takes advantage of these characteristics, we believe we can increase our customer market penetration and retention rates, increase our share of our customers aggregate voice, video, data and wireless services expenditures and managed services expenditures, and achieve continued growth in revenues and operating cash flow.
75679_18_ITEM1_P27_S0	Facilities We operate a modern, competitive communications network providing switched and dedicated voice and broadband services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P27_S1	Our fiber network employs digital transmission technology over our fiber optic facilities within Alaska and between Alaska and the lower 48 states.
75679_18_ITEM1_P28_S0	We serve many rural and remote Alaska locations solely via satellite communications.
75679_18_ITEM1_P28_S1	Each of our satellite transponders is backed up on alternate spacecraft with multiple backup transponders.
75679_18_ITEM1_P29_S0	optic cable and digital microwave system ( TERRA ) linking Anchorage with the Bristol Bay, Yukon-Kuskokwim, and northwest regions of the state.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S0	We own and operate a statewide network providing voice and data services to the urban and rural communities of Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S1	Our statewide wireless network provides 4G LTE data service, EVDO, 3G UMTS/HSPA+, 2G CDMA, and 2G GSM/EDGE service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S2	We continue to expand and upgrade these services to provide a modern network for Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S3	We own and operate Wi-Fi access points that create a Wi-Fi network branded as TurboZone in Anchorage, Fairbanks, Juneau, Kenai-Soldotna, Matanuska-Susitna Valley, and other areas of the State ("TurboZone").
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S4	Our dedicated Internet access and Internet protocol data services are delivered to an Ethernet port located at the service end-point.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S5	Our management platform continuously monitors the network and service end-points for performance.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S6	The availability and quality of service, as well as statistical information on traffic loading, are continuously monitored for quality assurance.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S7	The management platform has the capability to remotely access network elements and service end-points, permitting changes in configuration without the need to physically be at the service end-point.
75679_18_ITEM1_P30_S8	This management platform allows us to offer network monitoring and management services to businesses and governmental entities.
75679_18_ITEM1_P31_S0	Our video businesses are located throughout Alaska and serve the majority of the population.
75679_18_ITEM1_P31_S1	Our facilities include hybrid-fiber-coax plant and head-end distribution equipment.
75679_18_ITEM1_P31_S2	The majority of our locations on the fiber routes are served from head-end distribution equipment in Anchorage.
75679_18_ITEM1_P31_S3	All of our cable systems are completely digital.
75679_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	Competition We operate in intensely competitive industries and compete with a number of companies that provide a broad range of communication, entertainment, and information products and services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P32_S1	Technological changes are further intensifying and complicating the competitive landscape and consumer behavior.
75679_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	Retail Wireless Services and Products Competition We compete with AT T, Verizon, and other community or regional-based wireless providers, and resellers of those services in Anchorage and other markets.
75679_18_ITEM1_P33_S1	Regulatory policies favor robust competition in wireless markets.
75679_18_ITEM1_P33_S2	Wireless local number portability helps to maintain a high level of competition in the industry because it allows subscribers to switch carriers without having to change their telephone numbers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	The communications industry continues to experience significant technological changes, as evidenced by the increasing pace of improvements in the capacity and quality of digital technology, shorter cycles for new products and enhancements and changes in consumer preferences and expectations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P34_S1	Accordingly, we expect competition in the wireless communications industry to continue to be dynamic and intense as a result of the development of new technologies, services and products.
75679_18_ITEM1_P35_S0	The national wireless carriers with whom we compete, AT T and Verizon, have resources that are greater than ours.
75679_18_ITEM1_P35_S1	These companies have significantly greater capital, financial, marketing, human capital, distribution and other resources than we do.
75679_18_ITEM1_P35_S2	Specifically, as a regional wireless carrier we may not have immediate access to some wireless handsets that are available to these national wireless carriers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P36_S0	We compete for customers based principally upon price, service bundles, the services and enhancements offered, network quality, customer service, billing services, statewide network coverage and capacity, TurboZone, the type of wireless handsets offered, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_18_ITEM1_P36_S1	Our ability to compete successfully will depend, in part, on our marketing efforts and our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry.
75679_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	The Internet industry is highly competitive, rapidly evolving and subject to constant technological change.
75679_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	Competition is based upon price, service bundles, the services and enhancements offered, the technologies used, customer service, billing services, and perceived quality, reliability and availability.
75679_18_ITEM1_P37_S2	We compete with other providers some of which are headquartered outside of Alaska and have substantially greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
75679_18_ITEM1_P38_S0	We expect to continue to provide, at reasonable prices and in competitive bundles, a greater variety of data services than are available through other alternative delivery sources.
75679_18_ITEM1_P39_S0	performance and speed, and responsive community-based customer service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P39_S1	Increased competition, however, may adversely affect our market share and results of operations from our data services product offerings.
75679_18_ITEM1_P40_S0	Presently, there are a number of competing companies in Alaska that actively sell and maintain data and voice communications systems.
75679_18_ITEM1_P40_S1	Our ability to integrate communications networks and data communications equipment has allowed us to maintain our market position based on customer support services rather than price competition alone.
75679_18_ITEM1_P40_S2	These services are blended with other transport products into unique customer solutions, including managed services and outsourcing.
75679_18_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our video systems face competition from services and devices that offer distribution of movies, television shows and other video programming, using alternative methods such as Internet video streaming and direct broadcast satellite ("DBS").
75679_18_ITEM1_P41_S1	Our video systems also face competition from potential overbuilds of our existing cable systems.
75679_18_ITEM1_P41_S2	The extent to which our video systems are competitive depends, in part, upon our ability to provide quality programming and other services at competitive prices.
75679_18_ITEM1_P42_S0	Internet video streaming is a major source of competition for our video services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P42_S1	Additionally, some online video services produce or acquire their own original content.
75679_18_ITEM1_P42_S2	However, as a major Internet-provider ourselves, the competition may result in additional data service subscriber revenue to the extent we grow average Internet revenue per subscriber.
75679_18_ITEM1_P43_S0	The DBS industry is another major source of competition for our video services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P43_S1	Two major companies, AT T-owned DIRECTV and DISH DBS Corporation, are currently offering high-power DBS services in Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P44_S0	Competitive forces may be counteracted by offering subscribers expanded programming.
75679_18_ITEM1_P44_S1	We have retransmission agreements with various broadcasters and provide for the uplink/downlink of their signals into certain of our systems, and local programming for our customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P44_S2	Additionally, our ownership of television stations provides us the opportunity to create unique content for our subscribers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P45_S0	Video systems generally operate pursuant to franchises granted on a non-exclusive basis.
75679_18_ITEM1_P45_S1	The 1992 Cable Act gives local franchising authorities jurisdiction over basic video service rates and equipment in the absence of effective competition.
75679_18_ITEM1_P45_S2	The 1992 Cable Act also prohibits franchising authorities from unreasonably denying requests for additional franchises and permits franchising authorities to operate video systems.
75679_18_ITEM1_P46_S0	Well-financed businesses from outside the video industry may become competitors for franchises or providers of competing services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P47_S0	We expect to continue to provide, at reasonable prices and in competitive bundles, a greater variety of video services than are available off-air or through other alternative delivery sources.
75679_18_ITEM1_P47_S1	Additionally, we believe we offer superior technical performance and responsive community-based customer service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P47_S2	Increased competition, however, may adversely affect our market share and results of operations from our video services product offerings.
75679_18_ITEM1_P48_S0	Voice Services and Products Competition Our most significant competition for local access and long-distance comes from wireless substitution and voice over Internet protocol services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P48_S1	Wireless local number portability allows consumers to retain the same phone number as they change service providers allowing for interchangeable and portable fixed-line and wireless numbers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P48_S2	A growing number of consumers now use wireless service as their primary voice phone service for local calling.
75679_18_ITEM1_P48_S3	We also compete against Incumbent Local Exchange Carriers ("ILECs"), long-distance resellers and certain smaller rural local telephone companies for local access and long-distance.
75679_18_ITEM1_P48_S4	We have competed by offering what we believe is excellent customer service and by providing desirable bundles of services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P49_S0	See Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products below for more information.
75679_18_ITEM1_P50_S0	Seasonality Our services and products do not exhibit significant seasonality.
75679_18_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our ability to implement construction projects is hampered during the winter months because of cold temperatures, snow and short daylight hours.
75679_18_ITEM1_P51_S0	Major Customer We had no major customer in 2017 and 2016.
75679_18_ITEM1_P51_S1	Verizon was a major customer in 2015.
75679_18_ITEM1_P52_S0	Environmental Regulations We undertake activities that may, under certain circumstances, affect the environment.
75679_18_ITEM1_P52_S1	Accordingly, they may be subject to federal, state, and local laws designed to preserve or protect the environment, including the Clean Water Act and the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act.
75679_18_ITEM1_P53_S0	The FCC, Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Forest Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and National Park Service are among the federal agencies required by the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and National Historic Preservation Act to consider the environmental impact of actions they authorize, including facility construction.
75679_18_ITEM1_P54_S0	The principal effect of our facilities on the environment would be in the form of construction of facilities and networks at various locations in Alaska and between Alaska, Washington, and Oregon.
75679_18_ITEM1_P54_S1	Our facilities have been constructed in accordance with federal, state and local building codes and zoning regulations whenever and wherever applicable.
75679_18_ITEM1_P54_S2	We obtain federal, state, and local permits, as required, for our projects and operations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P54_S3	We are unaware of any material violations of federal, state or local regulations or permits.
75679_18_ITEM1_P55_S0	Patents, Trademarks, and Licenses We do not hold franchises (with the exception of video services as described below) or concessions for communications services or local access services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P55_S1	We hold a number of federally registered service marks used by our business.
75679_18_ITEM1_P55_S2	We own two utility patents issued in 2017 pertaining to device diagnostics and network connectivity.
75679_18_ITEM1_P56_S0	The Communications Act of 1934, as amended, gives the FCC the authority to license and regulate the use of the electromagnetic spectrum for radio communications.
75679_18_ITEM1_P57_S0	We hold licenses for our satellite and microwave transmission facilities for provision of long-distance services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P57_S1	We hold various licenses for spectrum and broadcast television use.
75679_18_ITEM1_P57_S2	These licenses may be revoked and license renewal applications may be denied for cause.
75679_18_ITEM1_P57_S3	However, we expect these licenses to be renewed in due course when, at the end of the license period, a renewal application will be filed.
75679_18_ITEM1_P58_S0	We hold licenses for earth stations that are generally licensed for fifteen years.
75679_18_ITEM1_P58_S1	The FCC also issues a single blanket license for a large number of technically identical earth stations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P58_S2	Our operations may require additional licenses in the future.
75679_18_ITEM1_P59_S0	We are certified through the Regulatory Commission of Alaska ("RCA") to provide local, long distance, and video service by Certificates of Public Convenience and Necessity ( CPCN ).
75679_18_ITEM1_P59_S1	These CPCNs are nonexclusive certificates defining each authorized service area.
75679_18_ITEM1_P59_S2	Although CPCNs have no stated expiration date, they may be revoked due to cause.
75679_18_ITEM1_P60_S0	Regulation Our businesses are subject to substantial government regulation and oversight.
75679_18_ITEM1_P60_S1	The following summary of regulatory issues does not purport to describe all existing and proposed federal, state, and local laws and regulations, or judicial and regulatory proceedings that affect our businesses.
75679_18_ITEM1_P60_S2	Existing laws and regulations are reviewed frequently by legislative bodies, regulatory agencies, and the courts and are subject to change.
75679_18_ITEM1_P60_S3	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of any present or future consideration of proposed changes to governing laws and regulations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P61_S0	Wireless Services and Products General .
75679_18_ITEM1_P62_S0	The FCC regulates the licensing, construction, interconnection, operation, acquisition, and transfer of wireless network systems in the United States pursuant to the Communications Act.
75679_18_ITEM1_P62_S1	As wireless licensees, we are subject to regulation by the FCC, and must comply with certain build-out and other license conditions, as well as with the FCC s specific regulations governing wireless services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P62_S2	The FCC does not currently regulate rates for services offered by commercial mobile radio service providers (the official legal description for wireless service providers).
75679_18_ITEM1_P63_S0	environmental laws and the FCC s environmental regulations, including limits on radio frequency radiation from wireless handsets and antennas.
75679_18_ITEM1_P64_S0	The High Cost Program of the Universal Service Fund ("USF") pays Eligible Telecommunications Carriers ("ETCs") to support the provision of facilities-based wireless telephone service in high cost areas.
75679_18_ITEM1_P64_S1	A wireless carrier may seek ETC status so that it can receive support from the USF.
75679_18_ITEM1_P64_S2	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireless telephone service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P64_S3	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireless telephone services, and our net cost of providing wireless telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_18_ITEM1_P65_S0	On August 31, 2016, the FCC published the Alaska High Cost Order.
75679_18_ITEM1_P65_S1	Per the Alaska High Cost Order, as of January 1, 2017, Remote high cost support payments to Alaska High Cost participants are frozen on a per-company basis at adjusted December 2014 levels for a ten-year term in exchange for meeting individualized performance obligations to offer voice and broadband services meeting the service obligations at specified minimum speeds by five-year and ten-year service milestones to a specified number of locations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P65_S2	Remote high cost support is no longer dependent upon line counts and line count filings are no longer required.
75679_18_ITEM1_P66_S0	Prior to the Alaska High Cost Order, Urban high cost support payments were frozen and had phased down to 60% of the monthly average of the 2011 annual support.
75679_18_ITEM1_P66_S1	The Alaska High Cost Order mandated that as of January 1, 2017, Urban high cost support for 2017 and 2018 would be two-thirds and one-third of the December 2014 level of support received, respectively, with Urban high cost support ending effective December 31, 2018.
75679_18_ITEM1_P67_S0	On April 27, 2016, the FCC released a Third Report and Order to reform and modernize the USF s Lifeline program ("Lifeline Order").
75679_18_ITEM1_P68_S0	The Lifeline program is administered by the Universal Service Administrative Company ("USAC") and is designed to ensure that quality telecommunications services are available to low-income customers at just, reasonable, and affordable rates.
75679_18_ITEM1_P69_S0	The Lifeline Order adopted several reforms, including incentivizing and sometimes requiring broadband providers to offer fixed and/or mobile broadband service to Lifeline subscribers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P69_S1	The Lifeline Order also limited the number of federal programs that confer Lifeline eligibility, and made small changes to the requirement for annual recertification of all Lifeline subscribers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P69_S2	Failure to correctly judge eligibility and recertify Lifeline subscribers could materially adversely affect our Lifeline revenues and/or increase our costs in the form of FCC fines for failure to comply with Lifeline rules.
75679_18_ITEM1_P70_S0	We have completed negotiations and the RCA has approved current direct wireless interconnection agreements with all of the major Alaska ILECs.
75679_18_ITEM1_P70_S1	These are in addition to indirect interconnection arrangements utilized elsewhere.
75679_18_ITEM1_P71_S0	See Description of Our Business Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products Regulatory Regime Applicable to IP-based Networks for more information.
75679_18_ITEM1_P72_S0	The FCC has imposed rules requiring carriers to provide emergency 911 services, including enhanced 911 ( E911 ) services that provide to local public safety dispatch agencies the caller s phone number and approximate location.
75679_18_ITEM1_P73_S0	Providers are required to transmit the geographic coordinates of the customer s location, either by means of network-based or handset-based technologies, within accuracy parameters revised by the FCC, to be implemented over a phase-in period.
75679_18_ITEM1_P74_S0	Due to Alaska s relatively low population and low cell-site densities, we have excluded certain areas from E911 coverage where cell triangulation is not feasible, pursuant to FCC rule.
75679_18_ITEM1_P74_S1	We have also filed for a waiver, which remains pending, for remaining areas where triangulation may be technically feasible, but where the cell-site densities are insufficient to reach the FCC s standard.
75679_18_ITEM1_P75_S0	The FCC also imposed requirements to allow users to text-to-911 if the local public safety dispatch agency requests and is able to receive such texts.
75679_18_ITEM1_P75_S1	We have developed a text-to-911 technical solution and have certified to the FCC that we are now capable of meeting the FCC requirements.
75679_18_ITEM1_P76_S0	Providers may not demand cost recovery as a condition of providing E911, although they are permitted to negotiate cost recovery if it is not mandated by the state or local governments.
75679_18_ITEM1_P77_S0	While the Communications Act generally preempts state and local governments from regulating the entry of, and the rates charged by, wireless carriers, it also permits a state to petition the FCC to allow it to impose commercial mobile radio service rate regulation when market conditions fail to adequately protect customers and such service is a replacement for a substantial portion of the telephone wireline exchange service within a state.
75679_18_ITEM1_P77_S1	No state currently has such a petition on file, and all prior efforts have been rejected.
75679_18_ITEM1_P78_S0	In addition, the Communications Act does not expressly preempt the states from regulating the terms and conditions of wireless service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P78_S1	Several states have invoked this terms and conditions authority to impose or propose various consumer protection regulations on the wireless industry.
75679_18_ITEM1_P78_S2	State attorneys general have also become more active in enforcing state consumer protection laws against sales practices and services of wireless carriers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P78_S3	States also may impose their own universal service support requirements on wireless and other communications carriers, similar to the contribution requirements that have been established by the FCC.
75679_18_ITEM1_P79_S0	States have become more active in attempting to impose new taxes and fees on wireless carriers, such as gross receipts taxes.
75679_18_ITEM1_P79_S1	Where successful, these taxes and fees are generally passed through to customers and result in higher costs to customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P80_S0	At the local level, wireless facilities typically are subject to zoning and land use regulation.
75679_18_ITEM1_P80_S1	Neither local nor state governments may categorically prohibit the construction of wireless facilities in any community or take actions, such as indefinite moratoria, which have the effect of prohibiting construction.
75679_18_ITEM1_P81_S0	Pursuant to Section 6409(a) of the Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2012, state and local governments are further constrained in their regulation of changes to existing wireless infrastructure.
75679_18_ITEM1_P81_S1	Nonetheless, securing state and local government approvals for new antenna structures has been and is likely to continue to be difficult, lengthy and costly.
75679_18_ITEM1_P82_S0	Data Services and Products General .
75679_18_ITEM1_P83_S0	There is no one entity or organization that governs the global operation of the Internet.
75679_18_ITEM1_P83_S1	Each facilities-based network provider that is interconnected with the global Internet controls operational aspects of their own network.
75679_18_ITEM1_P83_S2	Certain functions, such as IP addressing, domain name routing, and the definition of the TCP/IP protocol, are coordinated by an array of quasi-governmental, intergovernmental, and non-governmental bodies.
75679_18_ITEM1_P83_S3	The legal authority of these bodies is not precisely defined.
75679_18_ITEM1_P84_S0	The vast majority of users connect to the Internet over facilities of existing communications carriers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P84_S1	Those communications carriers are subject to varying levels of regulation at both the federal and state level.
75679_18_ITEM1_P84_S2	Thus, non-Internet-specific regulatory decisions exercise a significant influence over the economics of the Internet market.
75679_18_ITEM1_P85_S0	Many aspects of the coordination and regulation of Internet activities and the underlying networks over which those activities are conducted are evolving.
75679_18_ITEM1_P85_S1	Internet-specific and non-Internet-specific changes in the regulatory environment, including changes that affect communications costs or increase competition from ILECs or other communications services providers, could adversely affect our costs and the prices at which we sell Internet-based services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S0	On February 26, 2015, the FCC adopted an order reclassifying Internet service as a telecommunications service under Title II of the Communications Act.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S1	This order prohibited broadband providers from blocking or throttling most lawful public Internet traffic, from engaging in paid prioritization of that traffic, and from unreasonably interfering with or disadvantaging end users' and edge providers ability to send traffic to, from, and among each other.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S2	The order also strengthened the FCC s transparency rules, which require accurate and truthful service disclosures, sufficient for consumers to make informed choices, for example, about speed, price and fees, latency, and network management practices.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S3	The order allowed broadband providers to engage in reasonable network management, including using techniques to address traffic congestion.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S4	These rules applied equally to wired and wireless broadband services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S5	The order refrained from applying rate regulation and tariff requirements on broadband services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S6	On January 4, 2018, the FCC released an order that returned to a Title I classification of Internet service and eliminated many of the requirements described above.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S7	There are various efforts in Congress, through the federal courts of appeal, and through state legislation to re-impose the rules adopted in 2015.
75679_18_ITEM1_P86_S8	While we do not believe that the 2015 FCC order conflicts with our existing practices or offerings, the re-imposition of that regulatory framework would impose regulatory burdens, likely would increase our costs, and could adversely affect the manner and price of providing service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P87_S0	The USF Rural Health Care ("RHC") Program subsidizes the rates for services provided to rural health care providers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P87_S1	For the funding year that ran from July 1, 2016 through June 30, 2017, USAC received requests for funds that exceeded the funding available for the RHC Program.
75679_18_ITEM1_P87_S2	USAC allocated the funding on a pro-rata basis to rural health care providers who submitted their funding requests during a certain period.
75679_18_ITEM1_P87_S3	We provide services to rural health care providers who were impacted by the pro-rata allocation and as a result certain of our customers did not receive the full subsidy that was expected under the program.
75679_18_ITEM1_P88_S0	published an order on June 30, 2017 to assist eligible remote Alaska rural health care providers by allowing Alaska service providers, such as us, to retroactively lower their rates, or effectively giving a credit against amounts owed, for services provided.
75679_18_ITEM1_P88_S1	Based on these specific circumstances, we decided to retroactively lower our rates to these customers pursuant to the FCC waiver, and as a result we reduced revenue by $5.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2017, to aid our rural health care provider customers who were impacted by the pro-rata allocation.
75679_18_ITEM1_P89_S0	The FCC issued an Order and Notice of Proposed Rulemaking ( NPRM ) on December 18, 2017 and announced that requests for funds has exceeded the amount available for the funding year that runs from July 1, 2017 through June 30, 2018 ( FY2017 ).
75679_18_ITEM1_P89_S1	The Order specifically addresses relief if a FY2017 proration is needed and directs USAC to use unused RHC program funding available at the time of proration to lower or eliminate the proration factor first for all qualifying funding requests from non-consortia health care providers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P89_S2	All of our customers in the FY2017 and included in our December 31, 2017 accounts receivable are non-consortia health care providers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P89_S3	The FCC and USAC have given no guidance as to the amount of unused funding available, thus we cannot predict the amount of any such shortfall.
75679_18_ITEM1_P90_S0	The NPRM seeks comment about potential reforms to the RHC program to address future program shortfalls.
75679_18_ITEM1_P90_S1	We cannot predict at this time what changes, if any, that the FCC will adopt or the impact of any such changes.
75679_18_ITEM1_P91_S0	In 2014, the FCC adopted orders modernizing the USF Schools and Libraries Program ("E-Rate").
75679_18_ITEM1_P91_S1	These orders, among other things, increased the annual E-Rate cap by approximately $1.5 billion, designated funds for internal connections within schools and libraries, and eliminated funding for certain legacy services, such as voice, to increase the availability of 21st century connectivity to support digital learning in schools nationwide.
75679_18_ITEM1_P91_S2	These orders did not have a material effect on the overall E-Rate support available to our schools and libraries customers, and therefore did not materially affect our revenue from such customers.
75679_18_ITEM1_P92_S0	Because video communications systems use local streets and rights-of-way, they generally are operated pursuant to franchises (which can take the form of certificates, permits or licenses) granted by a municipality or other state or local government entity.
75679_18_ITEM1_P93_S0	The RCA is the franchising authority for all of Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P93_S1	We believe that we have generally met the terms of our franchises, which do not require periodic renewal, and have provided quality levels of service.
75679_18_ITEM1_P93_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide video services to military bases.
75679_18_ITEM1_P94_S0	The 1992 Cable Act contains broadcast signal carriage requirements that allow local commercial television broadcast stations to elect once every three years to require a cable system to carry the station, subject to certain exceptions, or to negotiate for retransmission consent to carry the station.
75679_18_ITEM1_P95_S0	The FCC has adopted rules to require cable operators to carry the digital programming streams of broadcast television stations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P95_S1	Further, the FCC has declined to require any cable operator to carry multiple digital programming streams from a single broadcast television station, but should the FCC change this policy, we would be required to devote additional cable capacity to carrying broadcast television programming streams, a step that could require the removal of other programming services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S0	The Communications Act requires the FCC to regulate the rates, terms and conditions imposed by public utilities for cable systems use of utility pole and conduit space unless state authorities can demonstrate that they adequately regulate pole attachment rates.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S1	In the absence of state regulation, the FCC administers pole attachment rates on a formula basis.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S2	This formula governs the maximum rate certain utilities may charge for attachments to their poles and conduit by companies providing communications services, including cable operators.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S3	The RCA, however, does not use the federal formula and instead has adopted its own formula that has been in place since 1987.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S4	This formula could be subject to further revisions upon petition to the RCA.
75679_18_ITEM1_P96_S5	In addition, in 2011, the FCC adopted an order to rationalize different pole attachment rates among types of services, and on November 17, 2015, took further steps to bring telecommunications and cable pole attachment rates into parity.
75679_18_ITEM1_P97_S0	Though the general purpose of the rule changes was to ensure pole attachment rates as low and as uniform as possible, we do not expect the rules to have an immediate impact on the terms under which we access poles.
75679_18_ITEM1_P97_S1	We cannot predict the likelihood of the RCA changing its formula, adopting the federal formula, or relinquishing its oversight of pole attachments to the FCC, any of which could increase the cost of our operations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P98_S0	Cable television systems are subject to federal copyright licensing covering carriage of television and radio broadcast signals.
75679_18_ITEM1_P99_S0	federal copyright royalty pool that varies depending on the size of the system, the number of distant broadcast television signals carried, and the location of the cable system, cable operators can obtain blanket permission to retransmit copyrighted material included in broadcast signals.
75679_18_ITEM1_P99_S1	The possible modification or elimination of this compulsory copyright license is the subject of continuing legislative review.
75679_18_ITEM1_P99_S2	We cannot predict the outcome of this legislative review, which could adversely affect our ability to obtain desired broadcast programming.
75679_18_ITEM1_P100_S0	Copyright clearances for non-broadcast programming services are arranged through private negotiations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P101_S0	Wireline Voice Services and Products General.
75679_18_ITEM1_P102_S0	As an interexchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the FCC and the RCA as a non-dominant provider of interstate, international, and intrastate long-distance services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P102_S1	As a state-certificated competitive local exchange carrier, we are subject to regulation by the FCC and the RCA as a non-dominant provider of local communications services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P102_S2	Military franchise requirements also affect our ability to provide communications services to military bases.
75679_18_ITEM1_P103_S0	The USF pays ETCs to support the provision of facilities-based wireline telephone service in high cost areas.
75679_18_ITEM1_P103_S1	Under FCC regulations and RCA orders, we are an authorized ETC for purposes of providing wireline local exchange service in Anchorage, Juneau, Fairbanks, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, and other small areas throughout Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1_P103_S2	Without ETC status, we would not qualify for USF support in these areas or other rural areas where we propose to offer facilities-based wireline telephone services, and our net cost of providing local telephone services in these areas would be materially adversely affected.
75679_18_ITEM1_P103_S3	See Description of Our Business - Regulation - Wireless Services and Products - Universal Service for information on USF reform.
75679_18_ITEM1_P104_S0	A Rural Telephone Company is exempt from compliance with certain material interconnection requirements under Section 251(c) of the 1996 Telecom Act, including the obligation to negotiate Section 251(b) and (c) interconnection requirements in good faith, unless and until a state regulatory commission lifts such rural exemption or otherwise finds it not to apply.
75679_18_ITEM1_P105_S0	All ILECs in Alaska are Rural Telephone Companies except Alaska Communications Systems Group, Inc.'s ( ACS ) in its Anchorage study area.
75679_18_ITEM1_P105_S1	We participated in numerous proceedings regarding the rural exemptions of various ILECs in order to achieve the necessary interconnection agreements with the remaining ILECs.
75679_18_ITEM1_P105_S2	In other cases the interconnection agreements were reached by negotiation without regard to the implications of the ILEC s rural exemption.
75679_18_ITEM1_P106_S0	We have completed negotiation and/or arbitration of the necessary interconnection provisions and the RCA has approved current wireline Interconnection Agreements between GCI and all of the major ILECs.
75679_18_ITEM1_P106_S1	We have entered all of the major Alaskan markets with local access services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P107_S0	See Description of Our Business Competition Voice Services and Products Competition for more information.
75679_18_ITEM1_P108_S0	Access Charges and Other Regulated Fees.
75679_18_ITEM1_P109_S0	The FCC regulates the fees that local telephone companies charge long-distance companies for access to their local networks.
75679_18_ITEM1_P109_S1	In 2011, the FCC released rules to restructure and reduce over time originating interstate access charges, along with a proposal to adopt similar reforms applicable to terminating interstate access charges.
75679_18_ITEM1_P109_S2	The details of implementation in general and between different classes of technology continue to be addressed, and could affect the economics of some aspects of our business.
75679_18_ITEM1_P109_S3	We cannot predict at this time the impact of this implementation or future implementation of adopted reforms, but we do not expect it to have a material adverse impact on our operations.
75679_18_ITEM1_P110_S0	The ability to obtain unbundled network elements ("UNEs") is an important element of our local access services business.
75679_18_ITEM1_P110_S1	We cannot predict the extent to which existing FCC rules governing access to and pricing for UNEs will be changed in the face of additional legal action and the impact of any further rule modifications that are yet to be determined by the FCC.
75679_18_ITEM1_P110_S2	Moreover, the future regulatory classification of services that are transmitted over facilities may impact the extent to which we will be permitted access to such facilities.
75679_18_ITEM1_P110_S3	Changes to the applicable regulations could result in a change in our cost of serving new and existing markets.
75679_18_ITEM1_P111_S0	On July 7, 2017, ACS filed a petition in which it asked the FCC to regulate us as an ILEC pursuant to section 251(h)(2) of the Communications Act, including the requirement to provide competitors with access to unbundled network elements.
75679_18_ITEM1_P111_S1	We cannot predict at this time the outcome of this proceeding.
75679_18_ITEM1_P111_S2	However, grant of the petition in its entirety may subject us to regulatory burdens that could materially impact our costs.
75679_18_ITEM1_P112_S0	We may be required to obtain local permits for street opening and construction permits to install and expand our networks.
75679_18_ITEM1_P112_S1	Local zoning authorities often regulate our use of towers for microwave and other communications sites.
75679_18_ITEM1_P112_S2	We also are subject to general regulations concerning building codes and local licensing.
75679_18_ITEM1_P113_S0	The Communications Act requires that fees charged to communications carriers be applied in a competitively neutral manner, but there can be no assurance that ILECs and others with whom we will be competing will bear costs similar to those we will bear in this regard.
75679_18_ITEM1_P114_S0	Regulatory Regime Applicable to IP-based Networks.
75679_18_ITEM1_P114_S1	In 2014, the FCC adopted an order calling for experiments to examine how best to accelerate the technological and regulatory transitions from traditional TDM-based networks to IP-based technologies.
75679_18_ITEM1_P114_S2	Although no entity has proposed conducting a technology transition experiment in our service territory in response to the FCC s 2014 order, additional proposals for experiments are possible.
75679_18_ITEM1_P114_S3	We cannot predict whether additional proposals for experiments might be submitted to the FCC nor any resulting proceedings or their effect on us.
75679_18_ITEM1_P115_S0	The FCC also has other open dockets through which it might make changes to the regulatory regime applicable to IP-based networks.
75679_18_ITEM1_P115_S1	A change in regulatory obligation or classification that interferes with our ability to exchange traffic with other providers, that raises the cost of doing so, or that adversely affects eligibility for USF support could materially affect our net cost of and revenue from providing local services.
75679_18_ITEM1_P116_S0	We do not have significant foreign operations or export sales.
75679_18_ITEM1_P116_S1	We conduct our operations throughout the contiguous United States and Alaska and believe that any subdivision of our operations into distinct geographic areas would not be meaningful.
75679_18_ITEM1_P117_S0	Company-Sponsored Research We have not expended material amounts during the last three fiscal years on company-sponsored research activities.
75679_18_ITEM1_P118_S0	Employees We employed 2,208 persons as of December 31, 2017, and we are not subject to any collective bargaining agreements with our employees.
75679_18_ITEM1_P118_S1	We believe our future success will depend upon our continued ability to attract and retain highly skilled and qualified employees.
75679_18_ITEM1_P118_S2	We believe that relations with our employees are satisfactory.
75679_18_ITEM1_P119_S0	Other No material portion of our business is subject to renegotiation of profits or termination of contracts at the election of the federal government.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Any of the following risks could materially and adversely affect our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We face competition that may reduce our market share and harm our financial performance.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	There is substantial competition in the telecommunications and entertainment industries.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Through mergers, various service integration strategies, and business alliances, major providers are striving to strengthen their competitive positions.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	We face increased wireless services competition from national carriers in the Alaska market and increasing video services competition from DBS providers and over-the-top content providers who are often able to offer more flexible subscription packages and exclusive content.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We expect competition to increase as a result of the rapid development of new technologies, services and products.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We cannot predict which of many possible future technologies, products or services will be important to maintain our competitive position or what expenditures will be required to develop and provide these technologies, products or services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Our ability to compete successfully will depend on marketing and on our ability to anticipate and respond to various competitive factors affecting the industry, including new services that may be introduced, changes in consumer preferences, economic conditions and pricing strategies by competitors.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	not keep pace with technological advances or fail to timely respond to changes in competitive factors in our industry and in our markets, we could lose market share or experience a decline in our revenue and net income.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Competitive conditions create a risk of market share loss and the risk that customers shift to less profitable lower margin services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Competitive pressures also create challenges for our ability to grow new businesses or introduce new services successfully and execute our business plan.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P4_S3	We also face the risk of potential price cuts by our competitors that could materially adversely affect our market share and gross margins.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our wholesale customers including our major roaming customers may construct facilities in locations where they contract with us to use our network to provide service on their behalf.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	We would experience a decline in revenue and net income if any of our wholesale customers constructed or expanded their existing networks in places where service is provided on our network.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Some of our wholesale customers have greater access to financial, technical, and other resources than we do.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S3	We expect to continue to offer competitive alternatives to such customers in order to retain significant traffic on our network.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S4	We cannot predict whether such negotiations will be successful.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P5_S5	Our inability to negotiate such contracts could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	For more information about competition, see the section titled Competition included in Part 1 Item 1 Business Description of our Business.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	If we experience low or negative rates of subscriber acquisition or high rates of turnover, our financial performance will be impaired.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We are in the business of selling communications and entertainment services to subscribers, and our economic success is based on our ability to retain current subscribers and attract new subscribers.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	If we are unable to retain and attract subscribers, our financial performance will be impaired.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Our rates of subscriber acquisition and turnover are affected by a number of competitive factors including the size of our service areas, network performance and reliability issues, our device and service offerings, subscribers perceptions of our services, and customer care quality.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Managing these factors and subscribers expectations is essential in attracting and retaining subscribers.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Although we have implemented programs to attract new subscribers and address subscriber turnover, we cannot assure you that these programs or our strategies to address subscriber acquisition and turnover will be successful.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P8_S5	A high rate of turnover or low or negative rate of new subscriber acquisition would reduce revenues and increase the total marketing expenditures required to attract the minimum number of subscribers required to sustain our business plan which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We may be unable to obtain or maintain the roaming services we need from other carriers to remain competitive.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Some of our competitors have national networks that enable them to offer nationwide coverage to their subscribers at a lower cost than we can offer.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	The networks we operate do not, by themselves, provide national coverage and we must pay fees to other carriers who provide roaming services to us.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	We currently rely on roaming agreements with several carriers for the majority of our roaming services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The FCC requires commercial mobile radio service providers to provide roaming, upon request, for voice and SMS text messaging services on just, reasonable and non-discriminatory terms.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The FCC also requires carriers to offer data roaming services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	The rules do not provide or mandate any specific mechanism for determining the reasonableness of roaming rates for voice, SMS text messaging or data services and require that roaming complaints be resolved on a case-by-case basis, based on a non-exclusive list of factors that can be taken into account in determining the reasonableness of particular conduct or rates.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	If we were to lose the benefit of one or more key roaming or wholesale agreements unexpectedly, we may be unable to obtain similar replacement agreements and as a result may be unable to continue providing nationwide voice and data roaming services for our customers or may be unable to provide such services on a cost-effective basis.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Our inability to obtain new or replacement roaming services on a cost-effective basis may limit our ability to compete effectively for wireless customers, which may increase our turnover and decrease our revenues, which in turn could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our business is subject to extensive governmental legislation and regulation.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Applicable legislation and regulations and changes to them could adversely affect our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The licensing, construction, operation, sale and interconnection arrangements of wireless communications systems are regulated by the FCC and, depending on the jurisdiction, state and local regulatory agencies.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	In particular, the FCC imposes significant regulation on licensees of wireless spectrum with respect to:
75679_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Resolution of issues of interference between spectrum bands.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Although the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, preempts state and local regulation of market entry and the rates charged by commercial mobile radio service providers, states may exercise authority over such things as certain billing practices and consumer-related issues.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	These regulations could increase the costs of our wireless operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The FCC grants wireless licenses for terms of generally ten years that are subject to renewal and revocation.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	FCC rules require all wireless licensees to meet certain build-out requirements and substantially comply with applicable FCC rules and policies and the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, in order to retain their licenses.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Failure to comply with FCC requirements in a given license area could result in revocation of the license for that license area.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	There is no guarantee that our licenses will be renewed.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Commercial mobile radio service providers must implement E911 capabilities in accordance with FCC rules.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P18_S1	While we believe that we are currently in compliance with such FCC rules, the failure to deploy E911 service consistent with FCC requirements could subject us to significant fines.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We use tower facilities for the provision of our wireless services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The FCC, together with the Federal Aviation Administration, also regulates tower marking and lighting.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S2	In addition, tower construction is affected by federal, state and local statutes addressing zoning, environmental protection and historic preservation.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S3	The FCC requires local notice in any community in which an applicant is seeking FCC Antenna Structure Registration to build a tower.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Local notice provides members of the community with an opportunity to comment on or challenge the tower construction for environmental reasons.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P19_S5	This rule could cause delay for certain tower construction projects.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	In 2015, the FCC adopted an order reclassifying Internet service as a telecommunications service under Title II of the Communications Act.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	The order prohibited broadband providers from blocking or throttling most lawful public Internet traffic, from engaging in paid prioritization of that traffic, and from unreasonably interfering with or disadvantaging end users' and edge providers' ability to send traffic to, from, and among each other.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S2	The order also strengthened the FCC's transparency rules, which require accurate and truthful service disclosures, sufficient for consumers to make informed choices, for example, about speed, price and fees, latency, and network management practices.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S3	The order allowed broadband providers to engage in reasonable network management, including using techniques to address traffic congestion.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S4	The new rules applied equally to wired and wireless broadband services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P20_S5	The order refrained from imposing rate regulation or tariff requirements on broadband services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	On January 4, 2018, the FCC released an order that returned to a Title I classification of Internet service and eliminated many of the requirements described above.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	There are various efforts in Congress, through the federal courts of appeal, and through state legislation to re-impose the rules adopted in 2015.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P21_S2	We cannot predict whether the FCC will re-impose the 2015 rules, but if it did, it is possible that the FCC could interpret or apply those rules in a way that has a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	The cable television industry is subject to extensive regulation at various levels, and many aspects of such regulation are currently the subject of judicial proceedings and administrative or legislative proposals.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P22_S1	It is possible that rate reductions or refunds of previously collected fees may be required of us in the future.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Other existing federal regulations, currently the subject of judicial, legislative, and administrative review, could change, in varying degrees, the manner in which video systems operate.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Neither the outcome of these proceedings nor their impact on the cable television industry in general, or on our activities and prospects in the cable television business in particular, can be predicted at this time.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	by Congress, the FCC or other federal, state or local government authorities will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Our success in the local telephone market depends on our continued ability to obtain interconnection, access and related services from local exchange carriers on terms that are reasonable and that are based on the cost of providing these services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Our local telephone services business faces the risk of unfavorable changes in regulation or legislation or the introduction of new regulations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Our ability to provide service in the local telephone market depends on our negotiation or arbitration with local exchange carriers to allow interconnection to the carrier s existing local telephone network (in some Alaska markets at cost-based rates), to establish dialing parity, to obtain access to rights-of-way, to resell services offered by the local exchange carrier, and in some cases, to allow the purchase, at cost-based rates, of access to unbundled network elements.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P25_S3	Future negotiations or arbitration proceedings with respect to new or existing markets could result in a change in our cost of serving these markets via the facilities of the ILEC or via wholesale offerings.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	For more information about Regulations affecting our operations, see Part 1 Item 1 Business Regulation.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Loss of our ETC status would disqualify us for USF support.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The USF pays support to ETCs to support the provision of facilities-based wireline and wireless telephone service in high cost areas.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P28_S1	If we were to lose our ETC status in any of the study areas where we are currently an authorized ETC whether due to legislative or regulatory reform or our failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations, we would be ineligible to receive USF support for providing service in that area.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Loss of our ETC status could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Revenues and accounts receivable from USF support may be reduced or lost.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We receive support from each of the various USF programs: high cost, low income, rural health care, and schools and libraries.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P30_S1	This support was 26% , 24% , and 19% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P30_S2	We had USF net receivables of $131.8 million and $100.5 million at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P31_S0	The programs are subject to change by regulatory actions taken by the FCC or legislative actions.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Changes to any of the USF programs that we participate in could result in a material decrease in revenue and accounts receivable, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Additionally, the USF RHC Program subsidizes the rates for services provided to rural health care providers.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P32_S1	USAC received requests for support that exceeded the available RHC Program funding for the first time in the funding year that ran from July 1, 2016 through June 30, 2017.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P32_S2	We expect that the support requests will continue to exceed the program's annual cap for the funding year ending June 30, 2018 and possibly subsequent funding years.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P32_S3	We provide services to rural health care providers who may be impacted by funding caps and as a result may not receive the full subsidy that was expected under the program.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P32_S4	We cannot predict the impact of future RHC Program funding caps but they may negatively affect our financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P33_S0	See Description of Our Business Regulation Wireless Services and Products Universal Service and Description of Our Business Regulation Wireline Voice Services and Products Universal Service for more information.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We may not meet our performance plan milestones under the Alaska High Cost Order.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P35_S0	As an ETC, we receive support from the USF to support the provision of wireline local access and wireless service in high cost areas.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P35_S1	On August 31, 2016, the FCC published the Alaska High Cost Order which requires us to submit to the FCC a performance plan with five-year and ten-year commitments.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P35_S2	If we are unable to meet the final performance plan milestones approved by the FCC we will be required to repay 1.89 times the average amount of support per location received over the ten-year term for the relevant number of locations that we failed to deploy to, plus ten percent of our total Alaska High Cost Order support received over the ten-year term.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Inability to meet our performance plan milestones could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We may lose USF high cost support if another carrier adds 4G LTE service in an area where we currently provide 4G LTE service.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Under the Alaska High Cost Order, the FCC adopted a process for revisiting after five years whether and to what extent there is duplicative support for 4G LTE service in rural Alaska and to take steps to eliminate such duplicative support levels in the second half of the ten-year term.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P37_S1	As a result, if another carrier builds 4G LTE service in an area where we are the sole provider and the FCC decides to redistribute the support then our high cost support may be reduced which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Programming expenses for our video services are increasing, which could adversely affect our business.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P39_S0	We expect programming expenses for our video services to continue to increase in the foreseeable future.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P40_S0	The multichannel video provider industry has continued to experience an increase in the cost of programming, especially sports programming and costs to retransmit local broadcast stations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P41_S0	As our contracts with content providers expire, there can be no assurance that they will be renewed on acceptable terms or that they will be renewed at all, in which case we may be unable to provide such content as part of our video services and our business could be adversely affected.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P41_S1	If we add programming to our video services or if we choose to distribute existing programming to our customers through additional delivery platforms, we may incur increased programming expenses.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P41_S2	If we are unable to raise our customers rates or offset such programming cost increases through the sale of additional services, the increasing cost of programming could have an adverse impact on our business, financial condition, or results of operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The decline in our voice services results of operations, which include long-distance and local access services, may accelerate.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We expect our voice services results of operations, which include long-distance and local access services, will continue to decline.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P43_S1	As competition from wireless carriers, such as ourselves, increases we expect our long-distance and local access services' subscribers and revenues will continue to decline and the rate of decline may accelerate.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P44_S0	We may not be able to satisfy the requirements of our participation in a New Markets Tax Credit ("NMTC") program for funding our TERRA project.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We have entered into five separate arrangements under the NMTC program with US Bancorp to help fund various phases of our TERRA project.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P45_S1	In connection with the NMTC transactions we received proceeds which were restricted for use on TERRA.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P46_S0	The NMTCs are subject to 100% recapture of the tax credit for a period of seven years as provided in the Internal Revenue Code.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P46_S1	We are required to be in compliance with various regulations and contractual provisions that apply to the NMTC arrangements.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P46_S2	We have agreed to indemnify US Bancorp for any loss or recapture of its $65.8 million in NMTCs plus interest and penalties until such time as our obligation to deliver tax benefits is relieved.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Our obligation to deliver tax benefits is relieved in various stages from August 2018 through December 2024.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P46_S4	Non-compliance with applicable requirements could result in projected tax benefits not being realized by US Bancorp and could have an adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Failure to stay abreast of new technology could affect our ability to compete in the industry.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We test and deploy various new technologies and support systems intended to enhance our competitiveness and increase the utility of our services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S1	As our operations grow in size and scope, we must continuously improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure while maintaining or improving the reliability and integrity of our systems and infrastructure.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S2	The emergence of alternative platforms such as mobile or tablet computing devices and the emergence of niche competitors who may be able to optimize products, services or strategies for such platforms will require new investment in technology.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S3	We may not successfully complete the rollout of new technology and related features or services in a timely manner, and they may not be widely accepted by our customers or may not be profitable, in which case we could not recover our investment in the technology.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S4	There can be no assurance that we will be able to compete with advancing technology or introduce new technologies and systems as quickly as we would like or in a cost effective manner.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S5	Deployment of technology supporting new service offerings may also adversely affect the performance or reliability of our networks with respect to both the new and existing services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P48_S6	Any resulting customer dissatisfaction could affect our ability to retain customers and may have an adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P49_S0	and offerings, we must phase out outdated and unprofitable technologies and services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P49_S1	If we are unable to do so on a cost-effective basis, we could experience reduced profits.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Our business is geographically concentrated in Alaska and is impacted by the economic conditions in Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We offer products and services to customers primarily throughout Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Because of this geographic concentration, growth of our business and operations depends upon economic conditions in Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P52_S0	The economy of Alaska is dependent upon the oil industry, state government spending, United States military spending, investment earnings and tourism.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Prolonged periods of low oil prices will adversely impact the Alaska economy, which in turn could have an adverse impact on the demand for our products and services and on our results of operations and financial condition.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P52_S2	Oil prices have continued to remain low which has put significant pressure on the Alaska state government budget since the majority of its revenues come from the oil industry.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P52_S3	While the Alaska state government has significant reserves that we believe will help fund the state government for the next couple of years, major structural budgetary reforms will need to be implemented in order to offset the impact of lower oil prices.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P53_S0	The Alaska economy is in a recession that started in late 2015.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P53_S1	While it is difficult for us to predict the future impact of the continuing recession on our business, these conditions have had an adverse impact on our business and could continue to adversely affect the affordability of and demand for some of our products and services and cause customers to shift to lower priced products and services or to delay or forgo purchases of our products and services.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P53_S2	Additionally, our customers may not be able to obtain adequate access to credit, which could affect their ability to make timely payments to us.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P53_S3	If that were to occur, we could be required to increase our allowance for doubtful accounts, and the number of days outstanding for our accounts receivable could increase.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P53_S4	If the recession continues, it could continue to negatively affect our business including our financial position, results of operations, or liquidity, as well as our ability to service debt, pay other obligations and enhance shareholder returns.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P54_S0	The customer base in Alaska is limited and we have already achieved significant market penetration with respect to our service offerings in Anchorage and other locations in Alaska.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P54_S1	We may not be able to continue to increase our share of the existing markets for our services, and no assurance can be given that the Alaskan economy will grow and increase the size of the markets we serve or increase the demand for the services we offer.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P55_S0	The markets in Alaska for wireless and wireline telecommunications and video services are unique and distinct within the United States due to Alaska s large geographical size, its sparse population located in a limited number of clusters, and its distance from the rest of the United States.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P55_S1	The expertise we have developed in operating our businesses in Alaska may not provide us with the necessary expertise to successfully enter other geographic markets.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Natural or man-made disasters or terrorist attacks could have an adverse effect on our business.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P57_S0	Our technical infrastructure (including our communications network infrastructure and ancillary functions supporting our network such as service activation, billing and customer care) is vulnerable to damage or interruption from technology failures, power surges or outages, natural disasters, fires, human error, terrorism, intentional wrongdoing or similar events.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P57_S1	As a communications provider, there is an increased risk that our technological infrastructure may be targeted in connection with terrorism or cyberattacks, either as a primary target, or as a means of facilitating additional attacks on other targets.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P58_S0	In addition, earthquakes, floods, fires and other unforeseen natural disasters or events could materially disrupt our business operations or our provision of service in one or more markets.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P58_S1	Costs we incur to restore, repair or replace our network or technical infrastructure, as well as costs associated with detecting, monitoring or reducing the incidence of unauthorized use, may be substantial and increase our cost of providing service.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P58_S2	Any failure in or interruption of systems that we or third parties maintain to support ancillary functions, such as billing, point of sale, inventory management, customer care and financial reporting, could materially impact our ability to timely and accurately record, process and report information important to our business.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P58_S3	If any of the above events were to occur, we could experience higher churn, reduced revenues and increased costs, any of which could harm our reputation and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Additionally, our insurance may not be adequate to cover the costs associated with a natural disaster or terrorist attack.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P60_S0	Cyberattacks or other network disruptions could have an adverse effect on our business.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P61_S0	Cyberattacks against our technological infrastructure or breaches of network information technology may cause equipment failures, disruption of our operations, and potentially unauthorized access to confidential customer data.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P61_S1	Cyberattacks, which include the use of malware, computer viruses, and other means for service disruption or unauthorized access to confidential customer data, have increased in frequency, scope, and potential harm for businesses in recent years.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P61_S2	It is possible for such cyberattacks to go undetected for an extended period of time, increasing the potential harm to our customers, our assets, and our reputation.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P62_S0	To date, we have not been subject to cyberattacks or network disruptions that individually or in the aggregate, have been material to our operations or financial condition.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P62_S1	Nevertheless, we engage in a variety of preventive measures at an increased cost to us, in order to reduce the risk of cyberattacks and safeguard our infrastructure and confidential customer information.
75679_18_ITEM1A_P62_S2	Such measures include, but are not limited to the following industry best practices: application whitelisting, anti-malware, message and spam filtering, encryption, advanced firewalls, threat detection, and URL filtering.
